story:
Our Dead Friend's Porn is a new play about the awkwardness and old bruises of a friendship hurtling towards adulthood. 

The play originally premiered as a staged reading in July and will debut as a full production at the New York Theater Festival in January. 

It's a small, intimate show that focuses on the casual ways friends terrorize, joke with, and perform for each other to avoid having the tough conversations. We've wrangled an insanely talented cast who are ready to be squeezed of every nuance in their bodies. They're scared but we're not. 

Script Excerpt

As small as it is, it's still an expensive process, and we want to tell this story in the best way possible. Your donation is key in telling it right. 

WHERE DOES THE MONEY GO?

We've planned the budget so that every dollar goes to making this production look great. 

Here's the breakdown: 

$350 to pay each of our actors and stage manager a $70 stipend for their time and work. 

$250 to cover the festival participation fee.

$200 for set design. 

$100 to cover props.

$150 for social media marketing, postcards, and other promotional material. 

$250 for extra rehearsal space. 

$50 for food during longer rehearsal days. 

$150 for purchasing tickets for donors and generally funding any perks. 

Total: $1,500

THE TEAM: 

         Connor Wright - Playwright

Connor is a New York based writer and performer whose plays have been produced at Kimball Studios, St. Paul's Theater, Goldberg Theater and as part of the San Diego Fringe Festival, Bad Theater Festival, and The Actually Happening One-Act Series. He's a frequent performer who's worked The PIT, Pit Loft, and Reckless Theater. He recently graduated from N.Y.U. with a BFA in Dramatic Writing. 

         Joel Kirk - Director

Joel Kirk is a New York City theatre director. He has worked with Actors Theatre of Indiana, Phoenix Theatre of Indianapolis, NewYorkRep, WorkShop Theatre, Busted Space Theatre Company, Carmel Community Playhouse, Ethnic Theatre Alliance, Cave Theatre, and Alchemical Theatre Lab. Recent directing credits include Blatantly Blaine (The People's Improv Theatre, Best Bet for Theatre is Easy and Time Out) Freezer Burn (Dixon Place), Customer Service (Midtown International Theatre Festival and Manhattan Repertory Theatre), The Roof Play (The Secret Theatre), and High-Beam Daylight (Kimball Studios). Joel is a Ball State graduate with a B.S. in Theatrical Directing. 

FINAL WORDS

Any donation to this campaign is a chance for a bunch of young, poor people to get their work up and seen. It's a chance to learn and make something fun, and make something even better the next time. Plus, we're telling you it will be objectively good and you're going to absolutely love it. 

Thanks for reading this far down.

story:
We are the Crowbait Club. But we are welcoming to all. Art for all. Plays for the masses.Scripts a plenty!

We are a group of bombastic and cutthroat playwrights and actors who get together once a month to celebrate the collaboration of theater- with a little theater deathmatch thrown in. Playwrights are given a theme each month for which he/ she must write a ten minute or fewer play.  Actors are drawn randomly with two minutes to prepare before performing the script to the audience.  The audience then judges the winning script and actor at the end of the night.  The events focus on the magic that comes when artists ( the actors and the playwrights) marry their creativity together with their talents and share them with the community.   They also then get cool prizes and their picture taken and posted on our website, www.thecrowbaitclub.org.  
The King of Crows is a theatrical event dedicated to full staged performances of each winning script assembled from throughout the year from the Crowbait monthly meetings.
 This requires renting a theater, paying actors and directors, assembling a crew to manage lights, sound, props. (Did I mention that we are getting a live band to score the plays under the direction of the renown Victoria Stubbs?) 

What We Need & What You Get

What we need from you is you financial support. We would also like it if you were to join us in our monthly meetings.  Incentives will be posted. However, the most rewarding thing is the fact that The King of Crows is made possible: possible to share the artistic vision of the artists, the directors, playwrights, and for the community of professional theater folks and new comers to share a safe and common mission: to make theater collaborative, expressive, and a reality.  You also get to see some fine theater happen, and that's just awesome.

    Why are we so Important? I mean, really, we are...

    Because we are the hippest and coolest theater geeks in town!  Ok, really...Simply put: we are a community.  When Crowbait started it was a small concept;to have actors and playwrights share ideas to help develop the craft of theater.  What we are now is a community of over 50 members! Our playwrights have had scripts sent off to be performed in NYC, and we have had some new comers to the writing scene realize their talent and become passionate about theater in a way that they can feel involved. 
    Crowbait serves as a catalyst for the community of Portland theater makers and goers to grow, develop, and have a hootin-hollerin good time.  The amount of confidence actors and playwrights have achieved about their own work as a direct result of the Crowbait Club and the sense of belonging the Club offers has become a cornerstone in the Portland Theater community.  

    And we are also totally humble about our awesomeness. 

      Risks & Challenges

      If we fail in our mission to financially secure the future of the King of Crows, our talent goes hungry, without the rent paid we will not have the space to perform the events. Without that, that which is the Crowbait Club will no longer be able to serve the community and many driftless theater artists will fall into a deep despair; writer's block will ensue, actors will grow rusty, winters will seem longer without our monthly meetings, and the success that all our winning scripts have been will be snuffed out as if blown from a candle, their prize-winning glory never seen to the world. The King of Crows just wouldn't happen. Cancelled. Which would be sad, As sad as cancelling Christmas. No one wants that!

        Other Ways You Can Help

        - Come to our monthly meetings!
        - buy merch by visiting www.thecrowbaitclub.org
        - blank checks are accepted in the name of The King of Crows

story:
THIS CAMPAIGN IS CLOSED BUT YOU CAN STILL DONATE!.  GO TO OUR WEBSITE AT www.solosana.com and click on the Kono Gnaga Project!  or click here....KONO GNAGA

African folkloric music and dance has historically been an important tradition in African societies, but with the rapid pace of globalization, Africa-- like other parts of the world-- is starting to lose many of its ancient practices.  We started Kono Gnaga to preserve traditional dance and music and to keep it alive for generations to come by using the culture itself to create opportunities for local West African artists and assist communities in Mali.  Kono Gnaga achieves this mission through its three objectives: cultural preservation, arts education, and arts for development. We are a local organization in Mali with a 501c3 sister organization here in the US - with a fiscal sponsor (LMC Radio) that will ensure your donations are tax-deductible.  Projects will begin in Mali with future plans to open branches in Burkina-Faso, Senegal, Liberia, Guinea and other parts of Africa.

We need your help!  Your  assistance will go directly these particular 2015 goals:

1) Initial research and documentation of the dance and the music in   the Kologani region.  

2) The implementation of an arts and music program into a local school's curriculum.  The local school provides free education for many children in the poorest neighborhood in Bamako, Mali.  We will be providing badly needed structural repairs, newly constructed desks, and basic school supplies along with the dance and music program.  

95% of funds raised go directly to the program activities. We have structured the organization so that funds raised can accomplish specific activities even if we don't meet our total goal so your donation will not be wasted!

Further details on our objectives are below or go to www.solosana.com for more information:   

Cultural Preservation:

Research, preservation, and promotion of traditional African arts, specifically music and dance.  Projects will focus on travel to particular regions to explore cultural traditions in dance and music with the objective to carry out documentation, both written and recorded, that can be preserved, protected and used to assist in authentic transmission through the generations.   

Arts Education:

Programs centered on the transmission of accurate information, movement, and music to younger generations.  Specifically assists young individuals, particularly those coming from marginalized and vulnerable populations, to foster an interest in the arts through programs promoting self-confidence, pride in cultural and community traditions, and the importance of preserving their cultural heritage.  The program will complement the students’ academic pursuits and will include assistance in school fees when possible.  Eventual goal will be to open a performing arts school that is centered on the preservation of traditional arts in addition to an academic curriculum and a service centered theme.  

For this component we have partnered with the Dicko school in the Paradjicoroni neighborhood of Bamako, Mali.  As this school was opened privately by a local teacher to serve as a school for families that cannot afford to pay school fees, the school is in a makeshift structure with no desks and 1 crumbling chalkboard and thus needs basic structural repairs and supplies.  We will be assisting to complete construction as well as provide desks and other basic school supplies along with integrating a dance and music program in the school.

Arts for Development:

Create and implement programs using traditional arts as a means of disseminating information on current issues affecting communities. The impact of using art as a means of expression and learning has been proven to be extremely effective, particularly among illiterate populations.  In the majority of African cultures the traditional arts are widely respected and enjoyed by all generations.  A team of local  artists will be trained in Theater in Development (TID) techniques within the framework of traditional arts.  In using traditional theater, dance and music, artists can involve community members, regardless of language differences, and with methods that fit within cultural contexts. The participatory approach TID uses will greatly benefit women, children, and those from disadvantaged and rural parts of society as it will help to transcend  barriers to communication. This will promote communication between individuals, governments, and other stakeholders which is the foundation of positive community development.

.

story:
Les Foules return to the Vaults for VAULT Festival 2016! We need your support to make the kind of quality show that won an Origins Award for New Work there last year. 

The Team

We are Les Foules: The Crowds. We make theatre that asks questions. Intelligent, surprising, atmospheric stories that our audiences have described as beautifully brutal, fast-paced and brave creations that dare to say something important.

We’ve assembled an all-star team for this one, including:


Performance:                                        Sound:

Norma Butikofer                                         Tom MacLean

Nadege Adlam  

Lennard Sillevis                                      Lighting:

Brian Tynan                                                   Sarah Crocker


Design:                                                   Production:

Betsy Dadd                                                   Cass Fumi


Dramaturgy:                                         Direction:

Peter Wiedmann                                         Nathalie Adlam

                                          

                                                 

The Show

17-21 February 2016, 18:00, The Forge, VAULT Festival

Alaska, 66° north, or just shy of it. 

Childhood buddies Brett and Kathy confront a fissured friendship at the fossil-fuel frontier of the Arctic. 

Up here the day doesn’t start over every day.

From crass commie yarns to company spin, god-giving missions to perished prospectors, whale oil to petroleum, Brett heads northwards, where myths, money, and  politics crackle and spit in a fuel doused arctic dream. 

We’re drilling to the bottom of our outlandish orders of exploration and laws of extraction in a kicked-up Western gone North. An intimate portrayal of friendship and camaraderie opens out onto a narrative expanse of arctically proportioned disorientation and division. 


The Ask  

We’re gonna need cash for this operation, and we’re hoping you might cut us a deal: investing your hard-earned dollars, pounds, euros, pesos, shillings, yen, or other legal tender in our project in exchange for a guaranteed return. That is, the gratification of knowing that you are a true supporter of the art of theatre, not to mention earning yourself a nice little prize from the list of returns on our left (your right) as a token of our gratitude.

To get this show right, and make it the best we can, we're going to need your help. We've got some elements covered, such as graciously donated rehearsal space. 

Here's a breakdown of where your capital is going. 

Equipment: £900

A projector. That's the main problem. They're expensive; and we need one to bring Betsy Dadd's extraordinary work alive in the theatre. We'll be hiring one, but we need a good one to do the job. We'll also need a lot of sundries to take you with us on a madcap journey. 

Lights/Sound: £350

More gear. And the people to run it. Distinctive lighting design and sound are elements that have made Les Foules' shows so atmospheric and enjoyable. Without them, well, you won't see us. 

Costume: £100

With lights, you'll see us. But without costume, what you'll see won't be pretty. 

Publicity: £150

We don't want you to have to sit there all by yourself in the audience when you come to see us. 

Please spread the word.

story:
! English translation below !!

Spendemöglichkeit ohne Paypal:
Theater Dortmund
Sparkasse Dortmund
BLZ 440 501 99
Konto 001 050 060
Verwendungszweck: "Spiegel-Barrikade"
IBAN DE32 440501990001050060

Am 4. Juni 2016 werden rund 1.500 Neonazis in Dortmund erwartet, um gegen
die angebliche "Überfremdung" der deutschen Gesellschaft zu demonstrieren.
Es ist kein Zufall, dass dieser Aufmarsch 2016 in Dortmund stattfinden wird. Dortmund ist berüchtigt für seine international vernetzte rechtsradikale Szene.
 
Die Künstler von Tools for Action planen gemeinsam mit dem Schauspiel
Dortmund, dem Kommunalen Integrationszentrum der Stadt und zahlreichen Schulen eine luftige Gegen-Aktion: aufblasbare Spiegel-Barrikaden!

An verschiedenen Orten der Stadt sollen aufblasbare Barrikaden aufgebaut werden, um dann in einer konzertierten Aktion zusammen zu kommen. Diese Barrikaden wurden erstmals 2015 beim Pariser Klimagipfel auf der Straße erprobt. Unser Ziel diesmal: die Nazi-Marschroute in Dortmund verhindern und der Fremdenfeindlichkeit buchstäblich den Spiegel vorhalten.

Aktionstraining mit Dortmunder Schülern am Phönix Gymnasium, 29.04.2016.

An dieser sozialen Plastik können theoretisch Tausende teilnehmen, Dies wird engagierten Bürgern Dortmunds die dringend notwendige Präsenz und mediale Sichtbarkeit verschaffen. 

Zahllose Würfel mitten im Stadtbild - zum einen handfeste Nazi-Blockade, zum anderen atemberaubend schönes Kunstwerk, irgendwo in der Tradition von Andy Warhols "Silver Clouds" und Christos „Land Art"-Projekten!

Für die erfolgreiche Durchführung brauchen wir eure Hilfe: bei den Würfelbau-Workshops, bei der Aktion selbst und mit der finanziellen Patenschaft eines Würfels!


Würfel-Bau auf dem Dortbunt am Opernplatz, 8.Mai 2016.


Und so geht's:

Ab dem 25. April werden wir in 14 Dortmunder Schulen Würfel bauen und Barrikadentrainings durchführen! Zusätzlich wird das Respekt-Büro der Stadt Dortmund Schuldiskussionen über Rechtsextremismus veranstalten.

An den Mai-Wochenenden gibt's im Schauspiel Dortmund ebenfalls Workshops, bei denen selbst Würfel gebaut werden können. (Für die genauen Workshoptermine, siehe hier.) Dazu kommen sonntägliche Trainings an den Katharinentreppen, die für einen effektiven Barrikaden-Einsatz elementar sind! Zugleich erleichtern diese Übungen und Workshops auch das gegenseitige Kennenlernen.

Hier entsteht etwas auf der Straße, was viele Menschen wollen! Diese Würfel markieren eine rote Linie, die die Nazis nicht passieren dürfen. (Michael Eickhoff, Chefdramaturg Schauspiel Dortmund)

Dadurch entsteht ein starkes Bündnis mit Menschen jeder Couleur, in dem Fremdenfeindlichkeit und Intoleranz keinen Platz hat!

Neugierig, wie so ein aufblasbarer Würfel entsteht? Hier gibt's das Anleitungsvideo von Tools for Action:


Für den Erfolg der Aktion suchen wir noch Unterstützer - "Würfel-Paten", die uns bei der Finanzierung unter die Arme greifen. Die Materialkosten für einen Würfel belaufen sich auf ca. 50 Euro. Unser Ziel wären 200 Würfel. Zusätzlich benötigen wir noch Kosten für Organisation und Logistik (insgesamt ca. 2000€) und es werden auch Gelder fällig, um die Anwohner auf unsere Aktion aufmerksam zu machen. Geplant ist außerdem, die Vorbereitungen sowie den Ablauf am 4. Juni filmisch zu dokumentieren. Wir brauchen Hilfe, damit diese Aktion GROSS werden kann. Je mehr Unterstützung von euch, desto mehr Würfel haben wir am 4. Juni!

Die Würfel sind gefallen! (Julius Cäsar)

Jeder, der spendet, ist Würfel-Pate! Zusätzlich gibt es aber noch drei besondere Patenschaftsmodelle: bronze, silber und gold. Bei der bronzenen Patenschaft wird dein Name (max. 45 Zeichen) Teil der Barrikade! Steh mit deinem Namen gegen Rassimus und Antisemitismus ein! Bei der silbernen Patenschaft wird dein Spruch (max. 140 Zeichen) Teil des Kunstwerks! Wir sind gespannt auf kreative, lustige, und clevere Slogans! Du willst uns noch mehr unterstützen? Super! Dann kannst du mit der goldenen Würfel-Patenschaft deinen Namen UND deine persönliche Botschaft hinterlassen! (Namen und Slogans werden vor dem Druck von uns überprüft.)

Neugierig, wie andere die Spiegel-Barrikade empfunden haben? Hier gibt's einen Beitrag vom Nordtstadtblogger vom 29. Mai.

Wir freuen uns auf euer Kommen und eure Beiträge!


Tools for Action und das Schauspiel Dortmund!


Beispielfoto für die Postkarten. Dies war ein aufblasbares Barrikadentraining in Warschau am 16. April 2016. Unser Traum für Dortmund: 200 glitzernde Würfel mitten im Stadtbild!


Unser faltbares Poster mit Bedienungsanleitung, gedruckt in Paris während des Klimagipfels 2015. Grafik vom legendären Dominik Krauss.

Ein Beispiel von bronzenen Würfel-Patenschaft vom Helene Lange Gymnasium!

Luftaufnahme vom Aktionstraining am 29. Mai 2016!


Ein aufblasbares Barrikaden-Set, komplett mit Batterie, Schiffspumpe und Bauanleitung. Die Barrikade vom Foto stammt noch aus Paris (siehe die roten Linien). Ihr werdet ein echtes Spiegel-Barrikaden-Set bekommen, einsatzbereit für den Alltag!

________________

English translation
The Inflatable Mirror Barricade Against Nazis

On 4 June 2016, more than 1,500 neo-Nazis will gather in the German city of Dortmund, to riot against the so-called “foreign infiltration” of German society. The location of Dortmund is not coincidental: Dortmund is well known for its internationally interconnected neo-Nazi scene.

The artists of Tools for Action are planning an airy counter action. Together with the Schauspiel Dortmund Theatre, the Communal Integration Centre of Dortmund and many local schools, they will create inflatable mirror barricades!

During the neo-Nazi rally in Dortmund, inflatable barricades willbe erected in different locations in the city. Thwarting the neo-Nazi rally wherever it surfaces, the reflective barricades will travel through the city and merge together – coalescing into a colossal union of people power. They will come together to literally hold up a mirror to xenophobia and racism.

These barricades were tested for the first time at the United Nations Climate Change Conference in Paris, 2015 when they were used to block road intersections to enable a 10,000 person demonstration to take the streets.

Theoretically, thousands can participate in this social sculpture. This will give the much-needed spotlight and media presence to the engaged citizens of Dortmund rebuking the oppression the neo-Nazi espouse.

Partly a substantial Nazi blockade, partly a breathtakingly beautiful art piece, countless cubes floating through the cityscape will reinflate the tradition of Andy Warhol’s “Silver Clouds” and Christo’s “Land Art” projects.

For the successful performance, we need your help: at the cube construction workshops, at the intervention itself, and with the financial sponsorship of a cube!


Here’s how it works:

From 25 April onwards, we will build cubes and practise barricade movements at 14 schools in Dortmund. Furthermore, the “Respekt-Büro” of the City Dortmund will organize school discussions about right wing extremism.

Every weekend in May, there will be cube building workshops at the Schauspiel Dortmund Theatre. Additionally, there are trainings at the Katharinentreppen in Dortmund each Sunday. These trainings are essential for effective implementation of the barricades. Also, these trainings and workshops will help participants to get to know each other better.

In this moment, people of all ages and all stripes will form a strong alliance in which xenophobia and intolerance will not be able to face its own image.


Cube sponsorship

For the success of our campaign, we need supporters! “Cube sponsors” will help our financing. Our goal will be 200 cubes! The material costs of each cube amounts to 50 Euros. Additionally, we need money for organization, logistics, and to raise awareness for our campaign in Dortmund. It is also planned to document our preparations and the showdown on the 4th of June via video. We need help to make this campaign become BIG! The more support we get, the more cubes we will have!

Everyone who donates is a cube sponsor! But additionally, there are three special sponsorships: Bronze, Silver and Golden. With the bronze sponsorship, your name (max. 45 characters) will become a part of the barricade! Stake your good name against racism and anti-Semitism! With the silver sponsorship, your slogan (max. 140 characters) will become a part of the artwork. We’re curious about your creative, funny and clever slogans! You want to support us even more? Fantastic! With the golden sponsorship, you can leave your name AND your personal message on one of our cubes.
(Before printing, names and slogans will be reviewed by us.)

We look forward to your participation!

Tools for Action and the Schauspiel Dortmund Theatre

vorhalten. story:
Macbeth

These are historic times. 

We witness daily accounts of fake news, alternate facts, and self-interest. We experienced the largest political demonstration in American history, with millions of participants all over the world marching for equality on January 21st. We face the dissolution of the NEA, the threat of further regressions in social equality, and extraordinary greed modeled by elected politicians in our government. 

Now, more than ever, we need to look back to move forward. We need MACBETH. And we need to experience it. 
 

Our Macbeth

On March 10th and 11th, we - an ensemble of Juilliard students - are literally putting audience members in the middle of the action, placing spectators in rolling office chairs in the center of a Bushwick warehouse space, surrounded by the action. Using simple contemporary costumes and practical lights, we are framing this classic in a familiar, decaying environment. 

Our minimalist, direct, and actor-driven telling of Macbeth thrusts audiences right into the middle of this frenzied cautionary classic about greed, abuse of power, and witchcraft. The idea is to explore the very real, and very human magic involved in the play, both confronting and implicating the audience in questions of ambition, ritual, and fate.  After a successful workshop in January 2017, we are thrilled to share this production of Macbeth with audiences this spring. 
 

How You Can Help

As a student-initiated project, we are mounting this production with a modest budget. This project is made possible in part through a Project Grant with the Marks Center for Entrepreneurship at Juilliard. We need your help getting the rest of the way there!

Our Budget:

  • $1200 - Amazing Brooklyn warehouse space for three days of tech and performances
  • $190 - Renter’s Insurance
  • $30 - Clip lights
  • $40 - Props and Costumes
  • $40 - Audience seating (roller office chairs and benches)
  • $100 - U-Haul 

TOTAL UNMET NEED: $700

Your support helps us bring this cautionary epic to new light. Contributions of all shapes and sizes are welcome! 

As a play produced in the spirit of exposing the threats demagogues pose to humanity, all funds raised beyond our essential expenses will be donated to the ACLU. Please help us help them fight the good fight - and give, give, give!

Thank you for your support. See you in March!

All best,

The MACBETH Team
Alex Shaw, Director
Forrest Malloy, Producer
Victoria Pollack, Producer

Production
Savannah Kurtz, Stage Manager

Cast
Steven Robertson
Jayme Lawson
Medina Senghore
Marcus Crawford Guy
Maya Thurman-Hawke
Keshav Moodilar
Melissa Holliday
Eric Harper
David Rosenberg
Allen Tedder
Mathias Goldstein
Henry Jenkinson
Rosanny Zayas
Julian Abelskamp
Daniel Davila
Jacob Smith

story:
HEATHERS: THE MUSICAL

"Based on the classic 1989 film, Westerberg High is ruled by a shoulder-padded, scrunchie-wearing junta: Heather, Heather and Heather, the hottest and cruelest girls in all of Ohio. But misfit Veronica Sawyer rejects their evil regime for a new boyfriend, the dark and sexy stranger J.D., who plans to put the Heathers in their place - six feet under."  

Book, Music & Lyrics: Laurence O'Keefe & Kevin Murphy
Direction: Jack McCarthy  
Musical Direction: Sasha Bartol 
Stage Management: Carrie Hiramatsu & Jamie Salinger
Produced by Jackson Strike & Caitlin Kilgore  

PERFORMANCE DATES:
October 20 @ 7:30pm 
October 21 @ 7:30pm & 11pm 
October 22 @ 2:30pm & 8pm
October 23 @ 2:30pm

 

Who are we?

MUSICAL THEATRE REPERTORY at USC

Musical Theatre Repertory at the University of Southern California was established in 2005 and is dedicated to enriching students’ lives through the production of quality musical theatre. Our goal is to provide students with the opportunity to participate in musical theatre pieces supplementary to those produced by USC. Find us online at www.uscmtr.com for general info about the company, ticketing details, upcoming events, production stills, and even a few production videos! Thank you for supporting the arts and we can't wait to see you at our upcoming shows!

 

Why Heathers: The Musical?

An adaptation of the 1988 film, this cult classic musical follows
Veronica’s quest to survive the stress of senior year. In effort to define
and face her own damage, Veronica unites with the most popular clique of
her school (consisting of Heather, Heather, and Heather). Although she
disapproves of the other girl’s cruel behavior, she plays along until some
of her closest relationships become deadly. As each character attempts to
define their own identity, we are reminded how difficult it is to stay true
to ourselves past our teenage years and through life. This musical invites
us to not only explore the imperfections of our world and others, but also
accept and heal our own damage.

 

CAST
Veronica Sawyer | JULIANNA KELLER
J.D | SEAN SOPER
Heather Chandler | ALI GETZ
Heather McNamara | ADDY STAFFORD
Heather Duke| LUCY GREBIN
Martha Dunnstock | ASHLEY BUSENLENER
Ram | TRISTAN MCINTYRE
Kurt | PATRICK OLSEN
Ram’s Dad/Preppy Stud | TYLER ELLIS
Kurt’s Dad/Principle | MICHAEL TAKLA
Fleming | BANJO EDWARDS
Veronica’s Mom | ANDREA TORRE
J.D.’s Dad/Cop 2 | DAVID SHADMAN
Geek | SAMUEL MILLER
Hipster Dork | IAN TIGHE
Stoner Chick | NINA NELSON
Young Republican | TAYLOR KASS
Goth Girl | HOLLY CRONIN
Coach | CAITLIN ODEN
Cop 1 | AMY MELENDREZ
Ensemble/Dance Captain | DAMARIS EISON
 
UNDERSTUDIES
Understudy for Veronica/Heather Chandler: TAYLOR KASS; for J.D.: TYLER ELLIS; for Heather Duke: HOLLY CRONIN; for Heather McNamara: ANDREA TORRE; for Martha: AMY MELENDREZ; for Ram/Kurt: MIKEY TAKLA; for Ram's/Kurt’s Dad: DAVID SHADMAN; for Fleming: NINA NELSON
 

 

PRODUCTION TEAM:

Director | JACK MCCARTHY
Assistant Director | SARAH HAHM
Music Director | SASHA BARTOL
Assistant Music Director | HARRISON POE
Stage Manager | CARRIE HIRAMATSU
Stage Manager | JAMIE SALINGER
Assistant Stage Manager | LEXIE CHU
Associate Stage Manager | SOPHIA PESETTI
Choreography | SOPHIE THOMASON
Dramaturg | SABRINA SONNER
Costume Designer | ELLIE SOLOMON
Costume/Prop Tech | HAYLEY PIKE
Scenic Designer | MALLORY GABBARD
Assistant Scenic Designer | ZOE SCHACK
Lighting Design | JUSTUS BRADSHAW
Assistant Lighting Design | TRIET NGUYEN
Sound Designer | ETHAN ZEITMAN
Assistant Sound Designer | MIA GLENN-SCHUSTER
Producer | CAITLIN KILGORE
Producer | JACKSON STRIKE
Graphic Designer | AUSTIN DALGLEISH   

 

What We Need

MTR is run exclusively by USC students. We receive no outside support from faculty or professional companies. Since our company is entirely student-run, every one of us puts in an enormous amount of time and effort to bring each of our productions to life. That being said, our financial resources are limited and we need help raising money for our production designers.  Funds we raise will be used for lighting, set, props, sound, and costumes. These design elements are vital not only in helping our production reach its full potential but also in providing design students with valuable production opportunities! 

 

The Impact

This campaign will drastically increase the caliber of our performance! We are so grateful for all the support we have received in the past. MTR has been producing musicals for and by the students for two decades now. If you would like to see production stills from previous performances, check out our website. 

 

Other ways to help! 

We hope to exceed $2,500 so please help us surpass our goal and bring this show to life! 

Whether you can offer financial support or not, please join us in the Massman Theater October 20th through the 23rd. We look forward to seeing you. 

You can also support us by simply spreading the word. Please share this page and find us on Facebook. 

We are always interested in getting other students involved in MTR. If you have any interest in joining our team, working on one of our shows, or getting some more information, email us at uscmtr@gmail.com. We would love to hear from you! 

Also check out our website at http://www.uscmtr.com/

Thank you for supporting Musical Theatre Repertory!

We are also very thankful for the support of the USC Undergraduate Student Government.


Last but not least... PROGRAM ADS! 

We are selling AD space in our show program that will be distributed at every performance. Want to wish a cast member good luck? Are you a company looking to promote your own event? You've come to the right place. 

Contact Rebecca Mellinger, rmelling@usc.edu, to find out more!

This musical invitesus to not only explore the imperfections of our world and others, but alsoaccept and heal our own damage. CASTVeronica Sawyer | JULIANNA KELLERJ.D | SEAN SOPERHeather Chandler | ALI GETZHeather McNamara | ADDY STAFFORDHeather Duke| LUCY GREBINMartha Dunnstock | ASHLEY BUSENLENERRam | TRISTAN MCINTYREKurt | PATRICK OLSENRam’s Dad/Preppy Stud | TYLER ELLISKurt’s Dad/Principle | MICHAEL TAKLAFleming | BANJO EDWARDSVeronica’s Mom | ANDREA TORREJ.D.’s Dad/Cop 2 | DAVID SHADMANGeek | SAMUEL MILLERHipster Dork | IAN TIGHEStoner Chick | NINA NELSONYoung Republican | TAYLOR KASSGoth Girl | HOLLY CRONINCoach | CAITLIN ODENCop 1 | AMY MELENDREZEnsemble/Dance Captain | DAMARIS EISON UNDERSTUDIESUnderstudy for Veronica/Heather Chandler: TAYLOR KASS; for J.D.: TYLER ELLIS; for Heather Duke: HOLLY CRONIN; for Heather McNamara: ANDREA TORRE; for Martha: AMY MELENDREZ; for Ram/Kurt: MIKEY TAKLA; for Ram's/Kurt’s Dad: DAVID SHADMAN; for Fleming: NINA NELSON  PRODUCTION TEAM:Director | JACK MCCARTHYAssistant Director | SARAH HAHMMusic Director | SASHA BARTOLAssistant Music Director | HARRISON POEStage Manager | CARRIE HIRAMATSUStage Manager | JAMIE SALINGERAssistant Stage Manager | LEXIE CHUAssociate Stage Manager | SOPHIA PESETTIChoreography | SOPHIE THOMASONDramaturg | SABRINA SONNERCostume Designer | ELLIE SOLOMONCostume/Prop Tech | HAYLEY PIKEScenic Designer | MALLORY GABBARDAssistant Scenic Designer | ZOE SCHACKLighting Design | JUSTUS BRADSHAWAssistant Lighting Design | TRIET NGUYENSound Designer | ETHAN ZEITMANAssistant Sound Designer | MIA GLENN-SCHUSTERProducer | CAITLIN KILGOREProducer | JACKSON STRIKEGraphic Designer | AUSTIN DALGLEISH    What We NeedMTR is run exclusively by USC students. We receive no outside support from faculty or professional companies. Since our company is entirely student-run, every one of us puts in an enormous amount of time and effort to bring each of our productions to life. That being said, our financial resources are limited and we need help raising money for our production designers.  Funds we raise will be used for lighting, set, props, sound, and costumes. These design elements are vital not only in helping our production reach its full potential but also in providing design students with valuable production opportunities!  The ImpactThis campaign will drastically increase the caliber of our performance! We are so grateful for all the support we have received in the past. MTR has been producing musicals for and by the students for two decades now. If you would like to see production stills from previous performances, check out our website.  
Other ways to help! We hope to exceed $2,500 so please help us surpass our goal and bring this show to life! Whether you can offer financial support or not, please join us in the Massman Theater October 20th through the 23rd. We look forward to seeing you. You can also support us by simply spreading the word. Please share this page and find us on Facebook. We are always interested in getting other students involved in MTR. If you have any interest in joining our team, working on one of our shows, or getting some more information, email us at uscmtr@gmail.com. We would love to hear from you! Also check out our website at http://www.uscmtr.com/Thank you for supporting Musical Theatre Repertory!We are also very thankful for the support of the USC Undergraduate Student Government.
Last but not least... PROGRAM ADS! We are selling AD space in our show program that will be distributed at every performance. Want to wish a cast member good luck? Are you a company looking to promote your own event? You've come to the right place. Contact Rebecca Mellinger, rmelling@usc.edu, to find out more!

story:
"Money? Whatchoo talkin about, money?"

Some Yank's Theatre Company was set up in 2012 to put on productions of plays that aren't seen very often in Irish theatre. We explore dark territory with a light touch, finding the humor and hope in the bleakest of settings.

For our next play, we are putting on the Irish Premiere of Stephen Adly Gurgis' play In Arabia We'd All Be Kings. This hilarious and touching ensemble piece by a Pulitzer Prize-winning author is a powerful portrayal of life for the poorest of the poor in Hell's Kitchen, where Beauty and Brutality collide.

"Whass your name?"
"My name?"

  • Liam Hallahan (Director/Producer) is the founder and artistic director of Some Yank's Theatre Company. He is a graduate of DIT's B.A. in Drama (Performance). As a director, previous credits include The Shape of Things and Beyond Therapy.
  • Kyle Hixon (Producer/Skank) is a Dublin based actor who has trained with the Focus Theatre and the Lir. Performance credits include Some Baffling Monster and The Seagull and Other Birds (PAN PAN), Borstal Boy (Verdant Productions) and the feature film MONGED (Filmbase).
  • David Doyle (Producer) is a recent graduate of Trinity College Dublin who now works as a producer, designer, and director across Ireland and the UK. Over the past number of years he has won several awards for his work including the 2012 Emerging Artist of the Year Award at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival (Kiss Me And You Will See How Important I Am), and the 2014 First Fortnight Award at the Tiger Dublin Fringe (My Name is Saoirse).

"Hey man, you got, like, a coupla quarters?"

This play is a big one for us; this is the first time we're doing a two week run in a central Dublin venue! We will need all the help we can get to pull this off!

The €1,500 we're hoping to raise here will go towards the following;

-€1,000 : Set Design and building; this will allow us to create a space that will transport the audience into another time and world, right into a Hell's Kitchen dive bar.
-€300 : 2 weeks of rehearsal space in the Lab, Foley Street
-€200 : Advertising and printing costs


"You people got some surprises in store."

We're hoping to raise at least 1,500. But there's scope for going further!

Two thousand euro will allow us to cover the cost of two more weeks of rehearsal space, as well as our all costumes and props! If we reach 2,000, Everyone who pledges will receive an A6 flyer, signed by the cast! Everyone will also be entered into a draw to win a meal for 2 (Restaurant TBC)!

If we reach 3,000 euro, we're cookin'! That extra grand will allow us to further polish and expand the show's visual design (costume, props, and set), to bring the standard even higher! as well as give a little bit extra to the cast and crew! If we reach 3,000 euro, everyone who pledges will receive a personalized thank-you note from the director, and a complimentary ticket to any night of the run!

"You wanna hand out Chinese takeout? That's across the street. You wanna make commission? That's here."

Even if you aren't able to contribute funds, share our Indiegogo page! Spread the word! If you refer a friend to us and they pledge to the campaign (minimum €10), you'll receive a personalized thank-you from the cast!

Refer 3 friends who pledge, and you'll receive a free ticket to the opening night! 

Refer 5, and you'll receive two tickets to the opening night and a glass of wine on us!

So, if you know anyone who might be interested, send them our way!




"You know what? You got an attitude!"
"Also got a bar, and it's closed."

story:
Short Summary

The founders of Birdsnest Theatre are Beth and Emily. We met whilst working at the lovely Polka Theatre for children in London. Between us we have experience in theatre, schools and the music industry. Now with young families of our own, we are inspired to make our own theatre. We are based in the UK and will also tour other European countries in the coming year.

Birdsnest theatre are passionate about creating exciting theatre for children under 5 and their adults. Our theatre is very design led and always contains live music.

Birdsnest like happy faces; Something out of nothing; magical moments; beautiful things; Simplicity; Surprising people; playing; playing with words; sounds; rhythms; Touching things; Sharing; Intriguing spaces; Journeys; A good story.

Birdsnest would like lots of people to join in. As many as possible. They know what a gem it is to be gifted a shared experience with your child. Children are constantly blasted with virtual experiences and high technology. We believe in exploring the world through the magic of theatre.

Birdsnest know that the best way to create great theatre is  to learn from children and so we always involve children's groups in our devising processes through workshops and residencies. We get children involved before their theatre visit, sending out a music CD from the show for example. We invite children to stay and play after our shows.

We urgently need money to register Birdsnest theatre for charitable status. We need this to gain eligibility to apply to trusts and foundations for essential funding. Without this status, we cannot move forward with our work and many children will miss out on a unique experience.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $1000 to cover the costs of registering Birdsnest Theatre and to apply for charitable status.

If we don't reach the entire goal, the funds raised will still go towards this and we will fund the rest ourselves.

Our perks include opportunities to be involved with our unique rehearsal processes, thanks in our programme and free tickets.

The Impact

Birdnest believe that all children deserve to have access to high quality, creative experiences; allowing them to explore and learn about their world in an imaginative way; and to develelop various skills, including language. In a busy world, theatre allows time to reflect; slow down; experience together.

The current economical climate means that funding for arts projects is constantly being cut. We are very passionate that children should continue to have opportunities to engage with the arts. These opprtunities are as important  to a child's health and well-being as is access to sports, for example.

Our fledging project ''Blown Away'' drew praise from one of the UK's top theatre companies for young children Oily Cart. They are now mentoring us. We also have support from 2 other brilliant and leading companies Polka Theatre for Children and Royal and Derngate, Northampton. We are touring a show this Autumn and we have also recently won a European seeding fund to create a new show to tour in the Uk and Europe in 2013.

We have the skills and contacts to make fabulous theatre for a new generation of theatre audiences. Help us  and contribute whatever you can to our campaign. Any amount, big or small will be gratefully received.

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate that not everyone is able to contribute but you can also help us out by spreading the word. Please pass this on to everyone you know.

Thank you!

story:
Who We Are

ThreeFold Productions is a theatre collaborative committed to:

 -Creating theatre that provokes genuine emotion within our audience.

-Contributing to the thriving artistic community of the Metro-Detroit area.

-Testing the boundaries of the traditional theatrical experience through bold, individual choices in scripts, design elements and performance.

-Providing a platform where both professional artists and emerging talents are able to express and develop a distinct viewpoint.

-The idea that theatre is a mercurial art form that continues to evolve long after show has opened.

We are determined to build a company that will be an essential, authentic and representative voice of art in Michigan. 

What We Need

A large portion of our operating costs are reliant on donations from our patrons. Your contribution will help us produce the same caliber of work you have come to expect from TFP and keep our doors open. Your donation will help us maintain our performance space, employ local artists, and showcase the extraordinary work of our designers. 

Other Ways You Can Help

The best way to support local theatre is by seeing local theatre! However, we understand that times are hard, so even if you can't contribute, please tell others about our campaign and encourage them to make a donation. TFP would like to thank you for consideration and your time.

story:
Short Summary

Humble Play: New Play festival of Appalachian Ohio began in 2006 as a way to promote the craft of playwriting and introduce play development to an audience.

We are starting our campaign to raise funds to help with the expenses of offering our festival this year.

To have the funds from this campaign would enable us to present an even better play festival.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $2,000 - this money (regardless of our reaching or goal or not) will be used to help pay for travel, lodging and food for the theater professional who will join us this year.  It will also be used to pay for the rental of the facility in which the festival takes place and for advertising.

We have lots of unique perks for those who donate to our campaign such as free advertising in our program, signed scripts, photos of casts and directors, special reception, appreciation dinner, and more...

 

The Impact

Playwriting is different from other types of writing because theater is a collaborative art form. The play doesn’t exist until actors give the characters life and the production team brings the world of the play to an audience. Because of this collaboration, playwrights can’t develop their writing alone; they need collaborators. Only when playwrights are able to hear their words out loud and in front of an audience are they able to determine what works and what doesn’t. This process, called play development, is a labor-intensive and expensive endeavor, but absolutely necessary to creating new plays. That’s why it’s so important that new play festivals exist: to give playwrights the opportunity to develop their plays. This is the reason the Humble Play: New Play Festival of Appalachian Ohio was created.

Humble Play has had over 200 plays submitted over the past 6 years by playwrights both seasoned and aspiring from across the United States.  Each year the judges find it a daunting task to choose 4 plays out of all of the submissions.  Several of the plays presented at our festival go on to full productions with our festival being an important part of its development.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us to continue our festival with a donation - if you cannot, please share our campaign with your friends.  Thank you so much for helping the arts.

story:
The Company

www.wildheartandlyric.co.uk

We are Wildheart & Lyric, a brand new theatre company made up of professional actors and musicians with a shared passion for devised, comedic, physical storytelling. Earlier this year, we devised and performed 'Birdy' for the Brighton Fringe. The show had a fantastic response and now we would love to take it on tour.

Your contribution:

We are looking to raise 4000 dollars to pay for a tour booker and an arts council bid which will, in turn, fund the Uk tour in Autumn 2013.

By contributing to this project, you will give BIRDY wings!!

What We Need & What You Get

The main areas that we need financing are: 

  • Tour Booking: This is an arduous and important task that requires, patience, experience and contacts within the industry, something we don't have. Fortunately we have found someone who does and is willing to be on board. Her fee is £750 ($1200). This will guarantee us a minimum of six venues over a three week tour. 
  • Arts Council Bid: We were lucky to receive support from Arts Council England. The money we received allowed us to preview the show In the Brighton Fringe 2012. Our plans to tour Birdy will require a much bigger application, for which we will need help writing. We want to bring someone on board with the needed expertise to give us the best chance of receiving the funds. Her fee for this is £1250 ($2000)
  • Marketing: This is a key aspect of making the tour successful and securing the longevity of the company. Basically we need 'bums on seats' and that is where marketing fits in. £500 ($800) gets us a decent marketing pack that will serve our needs. 

In return for your contributions we would like to give you some unique perks. These range from mentioning you on our Facebook Page and bigging you up to all our fans, to inviting you as VIPs to one of our shows when we go on tour.

As we have broken down our campaign into these different sections, it means that even if we don’t reach our entire goal Birdy still has a chance of going on tour. We will prioritise the tour booking, followed by the Arts Council bid, and then the marketing pack. Every single penny is valuable!

 

The Impact

Birdy is a story that will resonate with anyone who has taken a risk with  their heart... and battled for a sense of self. And while its content is dark and questioning, it is told as a comedy, with infectious joy and playfulness.

At Brighton Fringe and Nova Festival this year we previewed Birdy, and it was enormously well received by audiences and critics;

**** 'Told with immense energy, originality and imagination.' Fringe Review

 ***** 'Birdy is imaginative, authentic and absolutely impossible to fault. The most fun I've had at the theatre in a very long time' What's On Stage

We are so excited about the possibility of touring Birdy and sharing the experience of this show with audiences in theatres, studios and village halls across the Uk.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute to our cause, you can still have a part to play in our quest to tour 'Birdy'. You can contribute with your love and support, simply upload this link onto your Facebook or twitter page and big us up, simple. 

Or  you can just use the most effective form of communication, word of mouth. Tell your friends and family about this worthy cause.

story:
We are the Tempest Ladies, an all-female company devoted to making Shakespeare accessible to all through clear, engaging, and physical storytelling. The video above is a tease trailer for our new show--Macbeth--which just had three successful workshop performances. We want to bring Macbeth to audiences in Istanbul in April and mount our first-ever long run in New York City in June.


We need our friends, families, fans, Shakespeare lovers, and strangers to come together and make it happen.

 

Who are we and why are you reading this?

For almost 5 years, the Tempest Ladies have been bringing our unique productions to venues and underserved communities around the world.
 

Our previous production of The Tempest has played in Scotland as part of the Edinburgh Fringe; in Istanbul's Sevgi Gonul Theater Festival, we were its first American performers. We have also reached out to educational groups both here and abroad to create character and ensemble building workshops to complement our performances. We have worked with toddlers and, in our most rewarding challenge, high school students who had never interacted with Shakespeare and had limited English skills. 

 
We want to continue this journey with Macbeth. A favorite of many English and literature programs, the tragic and powerful tale is best understood through performance. The objective of the Tempest Ladies’ return trip to Istanbul is to perform Macbeth for the Turkish public and students throughout the region with discussion and workshops to follow. Following our trip, we want to secure a decent NYC space for 3 weekends to have a proper run of the show, inviting industry/press and marketing to the vast NYC arts community. Those of you who saw our workshops can attest that our approach to the text is unlike anything else offered by other classical companies.
 
You're reading this because we think you can help us get this done!
 

Okay, so how much do we need?

The revenue from our workshop performances will go towards renting a venue for our 3 week-run in NYC this summer. Anyone active in the NY theater scene will know that most spaces charge around $3,000 per week. Therefore, the profit we recently made will be saved for now and used toward renting the theater for June.
 
The only expenses we have for our trip to Turkey are 6 airfares at $700 per person RT and $1000 for a theater rental. We have received funding for one plane ticket from one school so far and hope to receive more; as the departure date approaches, however, we do need to book our flights sooner rather than later. Any profits made from our trip to Istanbul will also go towards our June performance.
 
Either way, your donation will go towards Macbeth and is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law, thanks to Fractured Atlas, our wonderful sponsor.
 

So, what is the point of all this again?

Our experiences over the last few years have changed us all as artists and people. We want to continue and expand and broaden our reach to influence more young people and remove the stuffy stigma of our language's greatest playwright. In convenient bullet-point form, we want:

  • To give young people here and in Turkey the chance to see Shakespeare performed live and actually understand what's happening, and therefore to fall in love
  • To make Macbeth performances available in English to Turkish citizens and students, and show them that some 'Mericans are actually pretty cool
  • To make a mark on the NYC classical theater scene and occupy a niche we don't think has been filled in this community
  • To encourage women to seek endeavors (and roles) not usually meant for them
  • And finally, to keep the Bard's works alive, fresh, and wonderfully new for both well-versed and unfamiliar audiences.

Can you do things that aren't giving us money right now?

Of course! I mean, the minimum contribution is $1, but we get it.
You can:
  • Share this campaign on Facebook/Twitter/wherever else you exist online
  • Like us/follow us to receive updates and interact with us
  • Stay tuned for info about our upcoming SIDES OF MARCH fundraiser/performance event where a donation gets you a chance to upstage us in front of an enthusiastic audience
  • Let us know of any leads to cheap theater spaces or eccentric billionaries who love all-female role switching Shakespeare

The Tempest Ladies are: Stella Berg, Stacey Bone-Gleason, Laura Borgwardt, Julia Giolzetti, and Holly Hart.

Macbeth is directed by Lindsay Tanner.

We are the Tempest Ladies, an all-female company devoted to making Shakespeare accessible to all through clear, engaging, and physical storytelling. The video above is a tease trailer for our new show--Macbeth--which just had three successful workshop performances. We want to bring Macbeth to audiences in Istanbul in April and mount our first-ever long run in New York City in June.
We need our friends, families, fans, Shakespeare lovers, and strangers to come together and make it happen.
 
Who are we and why are you reading this?
For almost 5 years, the Tempest Ladies have been bringing our unique productions to venues and underserved communities around the world.
 
Our previous production of The Tempest has played in Scotland as part of the Edinburgh Fringe; in Istanbul's Sevgi Gonul Theater Festival, we were its first American performers. We have also reached out to educational groups both here and abroad to create character and ensemble building workshops to complement our performances. We have worked with toddlers and, in our most rewarding challenge, high school students who had never interacted with Shakespeare and had limited English skills. 
 
We want to continue this journey with Macbeth. A favorite of many English and literature programs, the tragic and powerful tale is best understood through performance. The objective of the Tempest Ladies’ return trip to Istanbul is to perform Macbeth for the Turkish public and students throughout the region with discussion and workshops to follow. story:
Infinite Variety Productions (IVP) is an all female not-for-profit theatre company, who has made it their mission to tell female historical plays, stories that unknown or not taught in history class.

Last year we presented Ms. Lauro's play, "A Piece of My Heart", about women who went to Vietnam during the war.  The play had two runs, starting at the Tank and finishing at the famous downtown Living Theatre. Most of our audience members did not know that women participated in the Vietnam war; these women and their bravery had been ignored and undocumented.

We have now uncovered another piece of women's history that has remained in the dark for too long.

Patricia Burke Brogan's play, "Eclipsed", tells the story of four girls sentenced to the Magdalene Laundries. 

Created as an institution for "fallen girls", these asylums started as a way to keep women from becoming prostitutes.  Over 30,000 girls were put into these laundries, by their families that no longer wanted them. The girls were told to find penitence at the local convents, the laundries. 

Told they were washing their sins away from lust, the girls were made to wash Ireland's laundry and at the same time fattening the Catholic Church's income. Suffering physical, emotional and mental damage, these institutions felt like prisons but were worse--there had been no trial, no sentence. Some of the girls were committed to the laundries for most of their lives.

These laundries could be found in Ireland, the United Kingdom, United States and Australia.

In 1993, this story came to light when 155 bodies in unmarked graves were discovered on the grounds of High Park Convent. The grounds were owned by Our Lady of Charity of Refuge, and were being sold to recoup heavy losses the order took from an investment gone bad. Those unmarked remains were those of the girls of the Magdalene Laundries. 

The last Magdalene Laundry closed in 1996.

So, why does no one know this story? 

Why does the government and church refuse to acknowledge this happened?

We at IVP wondered the same thing.  We may not know the answer but we can change the question.  Why did this happen and what can we do to stop it from happening again? By getting the story out there. Help us to bring this story to life, to educate audiences everywhere.

In September 2012 we will be presenting Ms. Brogan's play, "Eclipsed"  as an open-ended run. Our project is already in process with lead producer and IVP co-founding artistic director Ashley Adelman, IVP resident director Bridget Leak and co-producer Petol Weekes.

We would love for you to be a part of this team, a part in making sure this story is told.

story:
Summary

The Middle Theatre Company seeks to support improvisation through a variety of services provided to theatres, improvisers (advanced and beginning), and to the community at large.  We are a nonprofit company and we are reaching out to help us get the funds to help us settle into our new location.

Purpose

The primary purpose of this fundraiser is to help the MTC build a stage, setup lights and sound, and furnish the theatre.   We are working on a tight budget, but we want to work as best within our means to not let our financial limitations lower the quality of our services.  We want our classroom, rehearsal, and lounge areas to be comfortable, and we especially want our performance space to be a place that people enjoy performing in.

In addition, receiving financial support from a large amount of people is a sign of community support for the goals of the organization.  This support allows us to thrive and increase and improve the services we provide.

Our Services

Master Classes

These classes are for intermediate and advanced-level improvisers who are looking to compliment their current understanding of improvisation.  The unique thing about these classes is that every month, they are taught by a different teacher from a reputable LA improv school.  These are workshops that will challenge improvisers, help them integrate knowledge from different schools, and give them a broader perspective on improvisation.  In addition, these classes allow students to appreciate the wealth of diversity in improvisation.  Classes are $150 for four-weeks, but a sliding scale is available for students who have financial difficulty.

Rentals and Performances

We rent out our space for classes and rehearsals, and groups are free to sign-up to perform on our stage.

Community Outreach

This project is still in the works, but we are in the process of developing programs that facilate outreach to underserved schools through improvisation.

Other Stuff

We have lofty ideas that we're planning on bringing to life over the next few years: scholarships for improvisation, improv competitions between schools, and more!

Final Thoughts

If you're an improviser or just someone who loves theatre in general, then consider supporting us.  We're always open to your suggestions, so feel free to email us at themiddletheatre@gmail.com.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
BIG KITCHEN – A COUNTER CULTURE MUSICAL is an evolving production about former Detroit social worker Judy Forman - aka Judy the Beauty on Duty - and the inclusive community she has fostered at her eclectic southern California restaurant. Since 1980 Judy and the BK have been the center of the world for artists, musicians, gays and lesbians, political activists, hungry people and seekers of all kinds.

Every decade or so a work of art comes along that makes you feel glad to be a part of the human race. We feel this show has the potential to be that kind of work.

THE SHOW features music written by long-time collaborators (and BK supporters!) Robert Schleeter and Ricardo Pitts-Wiley. There’s something for everyone, from the swinging opener Can I Take Your Order?, to the kitchen staff’s rocking declaration I Wanna Be a Star, because after all, Whoopi Goldberg washed dishes there before her career took off. The personal and community impact of the AIDS crisis is reflected in the haunting ballad If I. Jerry Garcia’s influence can be heard in Rollin’ Out. And some songs that are just flat-out fun, like We Was Humpin’ and Judy Does Paree. 

THE CREATIVE TEAM: Bob Schleeter is a guitarist, producer and music educator. A graduate of Berklee College, he is the architect of one of the best popular music programs for high school students in the U.S. as part of Marin Academy in Marin County, California. Ricardo Pitts-Wiley is an acclaimed actor, playwright and director. The co-founder of Mixed Magic Theater in Rhode Island, Pitts-Wiley was a recent Martin Luther King Scholar at MIT in Cambridge. An outspoken advocate for cultural literacy, his page-to-stage adaptation ("remix") of Moby Dick was presented at the Kennedy center in Washington, DC.

Schleeter and Pitts-Wiley have been collaborators for more than 30 years. They've written four previous works for musical theater: Night Voices, Man Woman Chaos, The Spirit Warrior's Dream and Sara's Jukebox. Their shows have been produced at venues including The North Carolin Black Repertory Company, Shakespeare and Company, Brown University and the University of Rhode Island.

Author Corey Fayman has joined the team to collaborate on the script. Corey's 2nd novel, Border Field Blues, was a winner of the Genre Award at the 2013 Hollywood Book Festival 

We think the Big Kitchen stories are great entertainment with a sense of purpose!!

GOALS: We've set a financial goal of $25,000 to fund a script workshop and workshop performance. We need high-quality actors, singers, musicians, a theater director, a rehearsal venue, and a workshop performance space. We've gotten this far on the good will of our friends and colleagues, but the material is ready to move to the next level. If we are short of our goal, we'll forge ahead and work with what we have.

IMPACT OF OUR PROJECT: This is an original work of music and theater, not a remake or an adaptation. The Big Kitchen is also an original. It is both unique and universal: everybody needs to eat, and most of us seek communities of some kind. But most cafe owners aren't social activists. Judy the Beauty believes in investing in people as opposed to stocks. Life experiences have taught her that change comes from the grassroots....and she loves to water the grass! Profits at the BK are measured in terms of the impact on people’s lives. 

We'll say it again: Every decade or so a work of art comes along that makes you feel glad to be a part of the human race. We feel this show has the potential to be that kind of work.

WHY WILL WE SUCCEED?: A quirky lead character who believes in something, a alternative and inclusive community of people who defy stereotypes, a bunch of songs you can't get out of your head, a reflection of the times we live in...you'll find all of this and more. 

This is the story of a community. PLEASE JOIN US!! You can help us with cash donations - large of small. Or you can help us get out our message to your own friends and co-workers.
