story:
What is ABSOLUTELY FILTHY?

In August, 2011, a solitary man dancing in the desert kicked up a cloud of dust; three years later, that dust cloud is trying to get to New York City.

My name is Brendan Hunt. Three years ago I was dancing at sunrise at the Burning Man Festival in the Nevada desert.

When one dances in an alkali desert, you unavoidably kick up a bunch of dust; and I was kicking up so much of it... that I felt a little bit like Pigpen. 

You remember Pigpen, right? From Peanuts? One of the second-tier members of the gang, known for his lack of hygiene and his ubiquitous cloud of dirt?

While I was dancing there in dust, a story about Pigpen as an adult suddenly burst into my mind, fully formed.

But I wondered: if one was to try to play a Pigpen-like character- in, say, a play or something- how would one go about portraying that ever-present dust cloud?

Only one answer came to mind: a hula hoop. I would get a brown-and-black hula hoop, the least fabulous hula hoop possible, and that would probably do it. It would be kinetic, and it could be constant, while at the same time rocking the audience into a kind of sleep that would make them forget about it while the actual story- which is the far more important thing anyway- carried their primary attention. 

That story eventually became a play called Absolutely Filthy. 

Debuting at L.A.'s Sacred Fools Theatre in January, 2013, with cast of 15, it went on an extended and critically acclaimed run that would be recognized the following year with eight LA Weekly Theatre Award nominations, winning three.

The show would also be entered into that year's Hollywood Fringe Festival, where it won three more awards, including Best Comedy and Top of the Fringe, for best overall show.

It's a pretty good return for a simple cloud of dust.

Even after that, the show found further life. This year the play was selected for a short run at Orange County's prestigious South Coast Repertory, as part of their Studio SCR series. By this time the script had been streamlined to a tight two hours and a total of nine actors, all of whom were in the original run.

Now, Absolutely Filthy- the show that refuses to die- has been selected for the New York International Fringe Festival this August, roughly three years since the idea first popped into my head in the Nevada desert.

But we're not there yet- for that, we need your help.

The cast and crew from the Hollywood Fringe run celebrate their haul.

What is FringeNYC? And why?

The New York International Fringe Festival (or FringeNYC) is a potential springboard for a show in a way that most Fringe festivals cannot hope to duplicate. Nonetheless, like all Fringe festivals, FringeNYC is a down-and-dirty, low-rent affair. We're doing a total of five shows over two weeks, with a bare-bones set and minimal tech.

As you may have heard, theatre is not exactly the highest-paying gig in show business. We are a cast of nine actors, plus a director and a stage manager, who intend to spend two-and-a-half weeks away from homes- and day jobs- for not much more pay than the thrill of doing a show in New York.

These are people who have been with Filthy since the beginning, folks who have been given ample chance to escape the project at each of its new steps along the way; but here they still are. I am awed by the fact that they are all willing to go along for this, the craziest step on the Filthy road yet. Everyone knows we won't be paid much, this is the life we chose; the least I can do is try to help insure that it doesn't cost them anything.

With this campaign we hope to cover everyone's flight east, so that no one has to pay their own way; then, once they're there, we'd like to make sure they eat.

It breaks down this way: 

- we want to put $400 towards everyone's flights
- we want to give everyone $300 of food money
- that's $700 for 11 people, bringing us to a target of $7700

If we don't make our goal, we hope to make enough to at least put a dent in everyone's flight and food costs.

But we don't expect you to just give out of the kindness of your heart*! We know you come to Indiegogo for one thing and one thing only- THE SWAG.

                               Yeah, SWAG! Tell us about THAT!

Your fully tax-deductible contribution may qualify you for PERKS! 

Our list of perks will expand as we go, so please keep checking back- but for now, here's what were starting with:

- your name in our show program, spelled correctly and everything
- a script autographed by the entire cast
- tickets to the show in New York
- a one-hour hula-hoop lesson
- a jersey signed by one of the greatest soccer players who ever lived

AND THAT'S NOT ALL! Or it won't be. For now, that is all. But there's totally more coming.

But why should I support this particular show?

I have been alerted that there may be some among you who also enjoy supporting art that may be deemed worthy of public consumption. 

In my experience, this has been a show that has surprised people with the degree to which it has affected them. It is a dark comedy, but also a deeply emotional show that gets audiences smiling and crying simultaneously.

Since those of us involved with the project cannot be trusted to speak objectively, I will direct your attention to the awards listed above, and to these reviews:

"Intense and compelling... An ambitious play... grandly served by the consistently pitch-perfect ensemble and inspired, imaginative direction." - Myron Meisel, The Hollywood Reporter

"Absolutely stupendous... The ensemble performances are stellar." - James Scarborough, The Huffington Post

"Darkly hilarious... comedy gold." - Mayank Keshaviah, LA Weekly

(We would include a bad review to balance things out, but we never got one. BOOM.) 

More celebration; this time after the LA Weekly Awards, April 7, 2014.


How else can I help?

If you can't contribute financially at this time, maybe just share our page with Indiegogo's share tools? That actually would be a huge help for us. Or...
If you live in New York, and have an extra room or need for a house/pet-sitter for a few weeks in August, we have some nominees for your vacancy. :)
On behalf of myself, the cast and the crew: thanks for getting dirty with us.
- Brendan Hunt


    * Giving out of the kindness of your heart is, in fact, permissible.
story_txt:
What is ABSOLUTELY FILTHY?


In August, 2011, a solitary man dancing in the desert kicked up a cloud of dust; three years later, that dust cloud is trying to get to New York City.
My name is Brendan Hunt. Three years ago I was dancing at sunrise at the Burning Man Festival in the Nevada desert.
When one dances in an alkali desert, you unavoidably kick up a bunch of dust; and I was kicking up so much of it... that I felt a little bit like Pigpen. 
You remember Pigpen, right? From Peanuts? One of the second-tier members of the gang, known for his lack of hygiene and his ubiquitous cloud of dirt?
While I was dancing there in dust, a story about Pigpen as an adult suddenly burst into my mind, fully formed.
But I wondered: if one was to try to play a Pigpen-like character- in, say, a play or something- how would one go about portraying that ever-present dust cloud?
Only one answer came to mind: a hula hoop. I would get a brown-and-black hula hoop, the least fabulous hula hoop possible, and that would probably do it. It would be kinetic, and it could be constant, while at the same time rocking the audience into a kind of sleep that would make them forget about it while the actual story- which is the far more important thing anyway- carried their primary attention. 
That story eventually became a play called Absolutely Filthy. 



Debuting at L.A.'s Sacred Fools Theatre in January, 2013, with cast of 15, it went on an extended and critically acclaimed run that would be recognized the following year with eight LA Weekly Theatre Award nominations, winning three.
The show would also be entered into that year's Hollywood Fringe Festival, where it won three more awards, including Best Comedy and Top of the Fringe, for best overall show.
It's a pretty good return for a simple cloud of dust.
Even after that, the show found further life. This year the play was selected for a short run at Orange County's prestigious South Coast Repertory, as part of their Studio SCR series. By this time the script had been streamlined to a tight two hours and a total of nine actors, all of whom were in the original run.
Now, Absolutely Filthy- the show that refuses to die- has been selected for the New York International Fringe Festival this August, roughly three years since the idea first popped into my head in the Nevada desert.
But we're not there yet- for that, we need your help.


The cast and crew from the Hollywood Fringe run celebrate their haul.
What is FringeNYC? And why?
The New York International Fringe Festival (or FringeNYC) is a potential springboard for a show in a way that most Fringe festivals cannot hope to duplicate. Nonetheless, like all Fringe festivals, FringeNYC is a down-and-dirty, low-rent affair. We're doing a total of five shows over two weeks, with a bare-bones set and minimal tech.
As you may have heard, theatre is not exactly the highest-paying gig in show business. We are a cast of nine actors, plus a director and a stage manager, who intend to spend two-and-a-half weeks away from homes- and day jobs- for not much more pay than the thrill of doing a show in New York.
These are people who have been with Filthy since the beginning, folks who have been given ample chance to escape the project at each of its new steps along the way; but here they still are. I am awed by the fact that they are all willing to go along for this, the craziest step on the Filthy road yet. Everyone knows we won't be paid much, this is the life we chose; the least I can do is try to help insure that it doesn't cost them anything.
With this campaign we hope to cover everyone's flight east, so that no one has to pay their own way; then, once they're there, we'd like to make sure they eat.
It breaks down this way: 
- we want to put $400 towards everyone's flights
- we want to give everyone $300 of food money
- that's $700 for 11 people, bringing us to a target of $7700
If we don't make our goal, we hope to make enough to at least put a dent in everyone's flight and food costs.
But we don't expect you to just give out of the kindness of your heart*! We know you come to Indiegogo for one thing and one thing only- THE SWAG.
                               Yeah, SWAG! Tell us about THAT!
Your fully tax-deductible contribution may qualify you for PERKS! 
Our list of perks will expand as we go, so please keep checking back- but for now, here's what were starting with:
- your name in our show program, spelled correctly and everything
- a script autographed by the entire cast
- tickets to the show in New York
- a one-hour hula-hoop lesson
- a jersey signed by one of the greatest soccer players who ever lived
AND THAT'S NOT ALL! Or it won't be. For now, that is all. But there's totally more coming.





But why should I support this particular show?

I have been alerted that there may be some among you who also enjoy supporting art that may be deemed worthy of public consumption. 
In my experience, this has been a show that has surprised people with the degree to which it has affected them. It is a dark comedy, but also a deeply emotional show that gets audiences smiling and crying simultaneously.
Since those of us involved with the project cannot be trusted to speak objectively, I will direct your attention to the awards listed above, and to these reviews:
"Intense and compelling... An ambitious play... grandly served by the consistently pitch-perfect ensemble and inspired, imaginative direction." - Myron Meisel, The Hollywood Reporter
"Absolutely stupendous... The ensemble performances are stellar." - James Scarborough, The Huffington Post
"Darkly hilarious... comedy gold." - Mayank Keshaviah, LA Weekly
(We would include a bad review to balance things out, but we never got one. BOOM.) 

More celebration; this time after the LA Weekly Awards, April 7, 2014.How else can I help?
If you can't contribute financially at this time, maybe just share our page with Indiegogo's share tools? That actually would be a huge help for us. Or...If you live in New York, and have an extra room or need for a house/pet-sitter for a few weeks in August, we have some nominees for your vacancy. :)On behalf of myself, the cast and the crew: thanks for getting dirty with us.- Brendan Hunt  
* Giving out of the kindness of your heart is, in fact, permissible.

story:
Who Are We?

  • 16 student teachers and 3 faculty members have partnered with the Movement Exchange Organization. 
  • We are traveling to Panama for one week in March to bring dance education to children living in orphanages, the National Ballet School, the University of Panama, and various community organizations in Panama. 
  • We need your help to fund this amazing opportunity to expand our teaching practice across national borders and donate around 300 hours of much needed community arts education. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Movement Exchange's program requires a participation fee of $1,300 per dancer which does not include airfare, food and lodging. Between 16 student teachers, tuition alone comes to a total of $20,800 and after subtracting the Fine Arts Fee grant we received, each student teacher is responsible for $925 of this tuition. This campaign is designed to cover about 30% of each student's tuition cost. 
  • This goal is modest as it is part of our larger fundraising efforts. Our team of 16 student teachers are all responsible for raising portions of our financial goal, and every donation feeds into our larger fundraising effort. 
  • If you donate, we want to include you in our experience! We will give you credit in our post trip documentary, notes from our classes, pictures of us and the children we're teaching and many other gifts! 
  • Even if we don't reach our entire goal, any funds we do receive will still be split among us to keep all of our individual costs down as much as possible!

The Impact

The Panama Dance and Cultural Exchange has partnered with students in this exchange for the past 2 years and it has proved to be an incredibly powerful experience. This year we are bringing together Ballet and Modern Danceto allow the teaching to spread further within Panamanian communities. Not only will we introduce dance to children who might never receive that opportunity otherwise, but we will also be growing and learning right along with them. With your help, we can ensure that arts education will exist in this community for years to come.

The student teachers will emerge from this experience with more tools in their teaching belts, better equipped to enter and impact schools and communities worldwide. Each of these students, many of whom are on the cusp of graduation, have a proclivity for teaching and this experience will fast-track their teaching abilities. International movement exchanges offer extreme challenges and rewards of equal intensity. If finances were no object, every student-teacher would participate in a movement exchange. This is why we count on our peers, friends, and families to believe in the power of arts education as much as we do. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Every little bit helps us, but even if you can't afford to help, you can still support us! Please share our information with your friends and family, especially those who are as interested in dance and helping people as much as we are. Also, you can support our departments by coming to one of our shows!

story:
The show.

Do you like musicals? Love hating on hipsters even though you secretly know you kind of are one? Get jealous that NYC has tons of shows all about how great it is and just want a chance to laugh at Toronto-centric references for precisely 75 minutes in Toronto's little known art squat? Then SQUAT is the show for you.
 
When a heartbroken artist returns from a drunken bender to her old performance space she finds it taken over by a new hipster duo and their trendy fans. Will she win it back? Will the cops bust her spot before she has a chance? Will you hear cuss words you didn't know existed? Probably. 

THE COOLEST PART: This is a site-specific show. We are performing in a real art squat. A small building behind 401 Richmond, it used to be a coachhouse. Today the romantic exposed brick walls are covered in obscure art that mostly consists of bicycles and body parts. The dusty skylights light it like that old mansion in Jumanji. It's just awesome, and you'll get a limited-time view inside when you come see us.

 

How we got here

We've been working on this show for eleven months. We've written 11 original songs and music for a 5-piece band. It's been through 4 drafts, and two workshop performances, and we have an unbelievalbly talented cast on board. After putting so much time in, we know this is going to be an incredible show.

We just really don't want to go bankrupt to prove it.

 

Our costs

Rent for the venue: $1800

Fringe Festival fee: $650

Carpentry and sets: $700

Venue renovations (when you are performing in an old warehouse it takes some work to help the acoustics and try to stop it from leaking when it rains): $300

Lighting: $400

Sound: $1200

Costumes and Props: $200

Printing (scripts, programs, promotional materials): $300

Miscellaneous tech and moving costs: $500

Total cost: $5850

We've already raised about $4000 on our own, so we only have a little way to go! Every little bit helps (really, it does!) and we thank you kindly for your help and support.

Much love,

The Cast and Crew of SQUAT!

PS you can buy tickets here: https://www.fringetix.ca/scripts/max/2000/maxwe...

 

 

 

Cast

Suzie … Lise Maher
Hank … Luke Marty
Lex … Colin Asuncion
Baritony Danza … Anthony Botelho
Sal … Sundance Nagrial
Ensemble … Elizabeth Rose Morriss, Jenny Rockman, Jenny Weisz, Victoria McEwan

Creative Team

Written by Jacob Ulrich, Eyal Rosenblum, Leora Smith
Co-Producers … Daniel Bennett & Leora Smith
Director … Jacob Ulrich
Assistant Director … Eyal Rosenblum
Music Director … Alex Soloway
Choreographer … Daniel Bennett
Dramaturge … Jacob Duarte-Spiel
Stage Management … Daniel Bennett
Set Design … Anton Ermakov
Lighting Design … Trevor Guyton
Sound Design … Jyotsna Venkatesh
Costume Design … Mika Gang & Tamar Miller
Properties … Tamar Pister & Mika Gang
Graphic Design … Anton Ermakov
Photography … Max Thomson & Andrew Bryan
Publicity … Katherine Hales & Sheena Singh

story:
Catalyst Dance Company History

  • HELLO FRIENDS! My name is Jennifer Polins, I have been the Artistic Director of the Pioneer Valley Performing Arts High School's Modern Dance Company, Catalyst Dancers for the past 12 years. Catalyst has been a cornerstone at PVPA and proof of the value of arts education in Western MA, since the schools inception in 1998. The Company consists of 12-18 young dancers that present student generated choreography as well as professional work by guests and faculty annually at PVPA's home theater and on national tours. Catalyst commissions works by many world renowned professional guest choreographers most recently, Catalyst had the honor of being the first high school to be allowed to stage Bill T Jones/Arnie Zane's “Continuous Replay”. The company has trained dancers who have gone on to dance with professional companies and productions such as CATS in New York, The Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, Lucinda Childs, Ballet Austin, Wally Cardona, David Newman, Renee Harris Pure Movement and Disney Tours, Pilobolous and Momix. Catalyst dancers have also received scholarships to dance conservatories such as Juilliard, SUNY Purchase, Goucher College, Connecticut College, Ohio State and University of the Arts, and received scholarships to Leon Dance, Summer Stages, Bates Summer Intensive, and Hubbard Street Summer Intensive. Catalyst gives students the rare opportunity to work with a cross culture of dancers, its members come from many dance studios in the region who would not normally get to meet, dance and work together. In short, Catalyst has been a catalyst for creativity, excellence, vision, and personal discovery that makes the art form of dance so vital, so compelling, and so ... essential.

Supporting Catalyst 

  • Catalyst needs your help to get to Miami to attend the National High School Dance Festival, April 3-6, 2014! Attending the festival is a life changing experience, and a unique opportunity for students to get essential support by making national connections to teachers, choreographers and peers, and recieving full and partial scholarships to summer programs and colleges that have helped many previous Catalyst members go on to successful careers in dance and the arts. 
  • Catalyst has stemmed an aggressive fund raising campaign that greatly reduces the cost per student to attend the National High School Dance Festival and funds 3 families in need in full who would not be able to send their child. Fundraising efforts include; hosting bake sales, dance a thons, raffles, chocolate sales and creating products such as t-shirts and calendars to sell. This fundraising effort gives students valuable skills in self promotion and understanding the administrative and economic efforts needed to sustain artistic endeavors. Our fundraising also decreases costs for all families by hundreds of dollars and gives these talented students opportunities to get training they might not otherwise afford. We need your support. The average cost per child to attend the festival is $800.
  •  WITH YOUR SUPPORT, 18 students will represent PVPA and Western Ma, at the National High School Dance Festival in Miami, April 3-6 2014. This festival gives all students a chance to earn full and partial scholarships to summer programs and universities and is a life changing and incredibly valuable experience. They take classes with peers from across the country, from international teachers, and have the unusual opportunity to be seen by dance schools, dance colleges and summer programs simultaneously. The students make connections with dancers from all over the world, experience and learn all styles of dance, and get the chance to watch and learn from peers through collaboration, which is a key skill to making it in the dance world. Catalyst dancers and choreographers are chosen each year to present work at the festival.

Cost break down!

  • minimum cost per student is $800 ( $14400 total needed for all students to be fully funded). We have 18 students planning to attend this year!  This cost includes airfare, hotel and food. We are hoping to raise at least $10,000 to fund three families in full and reduce rate for all students to attend the festival.
  • Catalyst has raised: $5000 so far!
  • Students that attend festival get opportunity to receive scholarships that allow them to continue to careers in the world of dance. Everyone who auditioned last year got at least one full or partial scholarship. There have been 150 Catalyst members over the past 16 years who have benefited from the programs at the festival. Many Alumni come back to teach, share professional experience with PVPA students. 
  • If we do not reach our goal, whatever we raise will be distributed to families and deduct cost of festival.

The Impact 

  • Dance is the most marginalized art form, high costs of training block many talented young dancers from being able to get the training they need to become a professional. Supporting this company gives many kids a chance they would not otherwise have.  Not only are you supporting an inspirational student dance company and an amazing performing arts school, but you are supporting the potential for these young talented dancers to go on into the professional field of dance in ways they might not even imagine! Every drop counts, pledge now!
  • Over the past 12 years, we have averaged 6 students each year receiving scholarships. Last year every student who auditioned received at least one scholarship, and we had two works chosen to be performed at the festival. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please help us to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign, forward this campaign to all you know who can help!
  • Thanks for all your support! Forever Dancing, Jen and Catalyst!

Everyone who auditioned last year got at least one full or partial scholarship. There have been 150 Catalyst members over the past 16 years who have benefited from the programs at the festival. Many Alumni come back to teach, share professional experience with PVPA students. 
If we do not reach our goal, whatever we raise will be distributed to families and deduct cost of festival.
The Impact Dance is the most marginalized art form, high costs of training block many talented young dancers from being able to get the training they need to become a professional. Supporting this company gives many kids a chance they would not otherwise have.  Not only are you supporting an inspirational student dance company and an amazing performing arts school, but you are supporting the potential for these young talented dancers to go on into the professional field of dance in ways they might not even imagine! Thanks for all your support! Forever Dancing, Jen and Catalyst!

story:
The Mao Project

The Mao project is a non-political play about the private life of Mao, acted and written by Robert Lin and will be staged in Nepal in early 2014. Our project also supports theater education in Nepal.

  • The project will be co-produced by US-based White Cloud Productions, Oscar International College of Film Studies and Narrator Theater Troupe in Nepal.
  • Robert will be teaching acting in Nepal again and will include the rehearsal and staging of this project as part of the curriculum. The Project will enable involvement from local students and teachers in terms of casting as well as technical support.
  • Your support is needed so we can successfully produce this play in Nepal about the private life of Mao.

A strong independent art community is part of what makes a strong democracy in any country; your funds will help Nepali art education and development, while at the same time support the staging of a new play about the private life of Mao in a country where Maoism is a growing part of its political life.

What We Need & What You Get

All the funds will go toward the production and staging of the project. Robert is paying for his own travel and his expenses while in Nepal.

  • We need to rent a theater, design and produce sets and promote the production.
  • We would like to allow students and teachers to attend for free but that depends on how much funding we are able to raise.
  • We are offering simple rewards such as postcards, historical Mao souvenirs as well as dinner and meetings with Robert Lin (in the fall of 2014).
  • For those seeking to have a more lasting influence on democracy and art in Nepal we offer major endowment packages. 

The Impact

Nepal is a fledgling democracy and its art movement is experiencing a revival.   :

  • Help us bring world class arts education to Nepal.
  • Share the stories about Mao's private life.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word about this project by sharing and posting:

  • Please like and share the video.
  • Please share our project on Facebook, Twitter, Google+, etc.

We are still here because we need YOUR support...

We need to rent a theater, design and produce sets and promote the production.
We would like to allow students and teachers to attend for free but that depends on how much funding we are able to raise.
We are offering simple rewards such as postcards, historical Mao souvenirs as well as dinner and meetings with Robert Lin (in the fall of 2014).
For those seeking to have a more lasting influence on democracy and art in Nepal we offer major endowment packages. 
The ImpactNepal is a fledgling democracy and its art movement is experiencing a revival.   :
Help us bring world class arts education to Nepal.
Share the stories about Mao's private life.
Other Ways You Can HelpPlease help us spread the word about this project by sharing and posting:
Please like and share the video.
Please share our project on Facebook, Twitter, Google+, etc.
We are still here because we need YOUR support...

story:
What a marvelous start! But, we're not finished and we still need your help.

First of all, to everyone who has already donated - Thank you! Bonneville’s campaign for “Chop Your Own Wood” has now surpassed our initial goal of $5,000.  We are forever grateful to you. An incredible group of people who supported our brand new theater company and our brand new play, "Chop Your Own Wood".

Don't worry! You can still donate and be part of this effort.  As planned, this campaign will remain open until July 11th.  Any additional funding will allow Bonneville an even stronger debut performance and help set our company up for great things ahead.  More funding means higher-quality materials, dedicated board operators, a broader marketing strategy and more dedicated rehearsal time. 


Bonneville Theater Company is a new Brooklyn-based company dedicated to innovative storytelling through both new texts and classic plays. This summer, Bonneville is proud to present its inaugural production, Chop Your Own Wood by L.T. Hughes, as a part of the New York International Fringe Festival. 


Chop Your Own Wood  tells the story of an estranged husband and wife who reunite in the woods on the eve of the year’s brightest meteor shower. As they camp on the foundation of a crumbling homestead, they’re forced to uncover how much of their love and humanity has remained intact in the face of grief and longing. 

What is FringeNYC?

The New York International Fringe Festival is an exciting theater tradition that we are thrilled to be a part of. It can be a great launchpad for new companies like ours. The festival is the largest multi-arts festival in North America, bringing together more than 200 companies from all over the world performing for 16 days in more than 20 venues.

We need your help.

To mount this show, we need to raise a base of $5,000.

Here's where the funds will go:   

- the festival participation fee

- a stipend for cast and crew, including two Equity actors

- insurance for the production 

- set construction, props, and fire-proofing 

- design elements 

- publicity and marketing


We can't produce Chop Your Own Wood without your help.

But we can help you, too! Bonneville Theater Company is currently awaiting status as 501(c)(3) organization.  We will let our donors know as soon as our non-profit status is confirmed so that your donation can be tax-deductible!

We’re also offering some fun perks that we hope you’ll take advantage of. 

If you can't donate today, there are still plenty of ways you can help Bonneville Theater Company.

Visit our website: http://www.bonnevilletheater.com

Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/bonnevilletheater

Follow us on Twitter and Instagram: @bonneville_co

Spread the word! Share our Indiegogo page on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. Talk about the project. Every little bit helps. 

And last but not least, come out to see us in August! We couldn't do this without you. 

With Sincere Thanks, 

Bonneville

 *Note: Unfortunately, we cannot offer any discount tickets for the show as per rules of FringeNYC. *

story:
THE PROJECT:


Someone once said the graveyard is the richest place in the world. It is full of inventions, products, ideas, goals and dreams that were never realized.  My goal is for my gravesite to be the poorest of all. Starting with the fruition of my one woman show, “Evolution of a Love Addict”. After ten years of talking about it, it is finally finished.


The show is more than mere entertainment it is a conduit for other to evaluate their relationship choices, to move beyond their fears and bring their own life’s goals and dreams to fruition. Mariam Williamson said, “As we are liberated from our own fears, our presence automatically liberates others.” As an artist completing a project is the greatest sense of accomplishment.


The next step is for the world to see it.


“Evolution of a Love Addict” is taking on the theater festival circuit. Starting with our nations capital at The DC Black Theater Festival in June 2012. The show is also being submitted to the United Solo Artist Festival, in New York City and the Atlanta Black Theater Festival, both in October 2012. In 2013 I will submit to the New York Fringe Festival, National Black Theater Festival in North Carolina, and Edinburgh Fringe Festival in Scotland.  Against all odds I am determined to give people the opportunity to see the show. I will hang on to my courage and abandon my fears to share my journey with all who will listen.


Everyone has a story. We just have to step out and share it.
 
WHAT I NEED FROM YOU:


In two words: support and money.


Share the word. Talk to your friends! Get them to support the project!
Without your support, I cannot afford to fund the entire project on my own. I have come up with a range of creative perks that you can purchase that will help me make this adventure a reality.  


Some of the perks include: special thank you on websites, autographed poster of the show, the shows t-shirt,  autographed picture book of the show, associate producers credit, and an executive producers credit.

 
HOW IS THE MONEY GOING TO BE USED?

DC Black Theater Festival registration, participation, theater rental, travel and lodging, car rental, gas, food, stage prop shipping and handling… the basic production necessities. Anything extra will go into, PR, promotional materials and marketing.  

ENDLESS POSSIBILITIES:


The movie, My Big Fat Greek Wedding started out as a one woman show.  Tom Hanks and his wife Rita Wilson saw the show and were so compelled to make it into a movie.  Rita recently optioned another one woman show, Jamaica Farewell, to make into a movie. Robert De Niro made the one man show, Bronx Tale, into a movie. So the possibilities that will come out of touring the festival circuit are endless. Not to mention regional theaters are more interested in solo performances nowadays because of the low production costs. . . Did I mention the possibilities are endless.

OK! I'M CONVINCED! NOW WHAT?


Choose a sponsorship level on the right that interests you and follow the steps! Credit Card or Paypal, whichever works for you! Share it with your friends, family, social networks and more!
 
LAST WORDS


To me, this project is a way to move beyond life’s circumstances and prove to the world that you don't have to be locked into the constraints of your current situation. I also believe this project is bigger than me and is a conduit for growth and inspiration for anyone who sees it.

story:
The PepTides, a pop-noir band, are expanding into theatrical territory with a play entitled Love+Hate.  We are mounting the play at Undercurrents Festival, and need to create new sets.  With $500 we can create the backdrops to bring you an intimate and provocative portrayal of civilization livin’ at the end of the world.

We're talking costumes!  Props!  Backdrops! If we don't reach our goal, some funding is better than none!  And if we surpass our goal, well then, all the more elaborate the visuals shall be! 

Perks of donation range from signed posters to love/hate letters to dress rehearsal sit-ins! 

More about the play:

Pop-noir band The PepTides bring you an intimate and provocative portrayal of civilization livin’ at the end of the world—based on their albums Love Question Mark and For Those Who Hate Human Interaction.

Peer at love and hate—two of our most basic yet perplexing impulses—using The PepTides as your kaleidoscope. Using imagery of science, sex, history (and pre-history), the show cuts to the heart of what makes us human—but certainly not without a touch of humour and irony, darling.

The PepTides are noted for their smooth harmonies and extravagant stage presence. As MuchMoreMusic puts it, “They defy any genre or description. One must simply see them to believe them.”

Some press about Love + Hate:  

“An incredibly entertaining show… a definite must-see.” -  Apartment613 (full review)

“Perfect… On point… Gorgeous and fantastic.” - Onstage (full review)

“So intoxicating that you want to take a bath in it.” - Charlebois Post (full review)

If you can't donate but still want to help, then share this campaign by word of mouth and through the ether! And don't forget to check out the play itself: http://www.undercurrentsfestival.ca/lovehate

story:
Short Summary

The world just ended, the survivors are on the moon, they’re running out of food – oh, and somebody just outlawed sex. In Moonshine, a post-apocalyptic dark comedy, the survivors of an Armageddon caused by two competing superpowers have to reconcile ancient grudges to come together and survive in a new world.


How You Can Help

Hello! My name is Alexandra Shields, and I am currently a senior at Northwestern University. I am the fundraising director for Moonshine. Moonshine, is a post-apocalyptic dark comedy written by senior Gus Schlanbusch and produced through Vertigo Productions, Northwestern’s student-written theatre board. Our performances begin at the end of October, and we could not be more excited. I have watched Moonshine grow from its inception into a thoughtful and witty play that will delight audiences across Evanston. By supporting our show, you will be contributing to the artistic growth and expression of multiple Northwestern students.

We have already begun the process of imagining this new production in real time and space. Moreover, due to the nature of a new script, we are constantly workshopping and evolving, which is an incredibly valuable experience to everyone involved. However, and rather unfortunately, we can’t do it for free… That’s where we are hoping you will come in!

Our current budget demands that we raise $2000. Some of this money will be raised through campus bake sales and profit sharing events around Evanston, but we would be grateful if you would donate just ten or twenty dollars to Moonshine’s production funds. (If you are able and willing to donate more, we certainly wouldn’t complain! But even the smaller donations add up and are integral to the process.)

Thank you so much for taking the time to look at our project. We hope that you will be contributing to the first of many runs of this thought-provoking and hilarious piece of theater!

story:
WORDOFMOUTHmelb are a local arts collective with a focus on sustainable and ethical practices. WORDOFMOUTH support and create art of all mediums, focussing on projects that have an environmental conscience, as well as engaging community, and creating personal connections. 

As part of this years Melbourne Fringe Festival:

Gemma Vs. The Normal Worms by Pachali Brewster is a thought provoking 'buddy adventure' which explores political and social themes. Originally written for screen, WORDOFMOUTH have re-imagined Gemma Vs. The Normal Worms for the theatre. They will stage this science fiction space odyssey at Irene's Warehouse, a community arts warehouse. In collaboration with local artists: puppets & their universe are re-purposed from recycled materials and salvaged objects.


SUSTAINABILITY! COMMUNITY!

  • Creating sets, puppets and props using salvaged objects found within our communities. We will recycle, upcycle and create!
  • Local artists are engaged to contribute and promote their own work through this process, this involves painters, performers, builders and musicians! (to name a few!)
  • Location is at local not-for-profit arts community warehouse so money is re-circulated into the local arts community.
  • Printing and advertising sourced through local companies
  • Lighting sourced through local companies

How funds will be used

Funds will be used to assist Word-of-Mouth in putting on their first fringe show! 

Fringe Registration: $390.00 
Public Liability Insurance: $290.00 - Duck for cover
Photocopying: $200 - Office Works- using their recycled paper (not reflex paper or environmentally harmful varieties) 
Venue Hire: $500 (plus 20% of door sales)- Irene's Warehouse Not-For-Profit Arts Community Pitt Street Brunswick 
Posters: $220.00 - Distribution and print by PLAKKIT who have given us a 50% discount!
Set Design: $200- Materials such as glue and paint that cannot be sourced via our waste recycling 
Tech: $500 - Sublime AV with a 50% discount
Tech supporting equip: $100 gaffa tape, extra stands, rigging equip. 
Transport/Administration: $300 (transporting lighting equipment, phone calls, extra printing costs, pozible fees, paypal fees, bank fees)
Contingency: $200 -  a teeny lil buffer in case all hell breaks loose!

TOTAL:  $2900.00

Some of our other work

Word of Mouth is a relatively new collective, but its previous experience and that of its core members speak as a testament to its potential.
'Gemma vs. The Normal Worms' will be the second event hosted by the co-operative, with the first occuring last year with a pop-up play reading.

The play reading was three short plays Love in the Time of Vampires, Love in the Time of Zombies and Love in the Time of Lawyers also by writer Pachali Brewster. We have decided to use Pachali's work again as it is really SO diverse and SO different and just generally hilarious. We feel her contemporary and open minded approach to art is extremely relevant to our frameworks. 


For more information on the three main facilitators of Word-of-Mouth:

Alexandra Nel - www.alexandranel.com / www.youtube.com/alexastube

Hannah Ogden: www.iamhlo.com

Mondo: http://junkarmada.wordpress.com; www.facebook.com/missmondosaurus 

Challenges

BESIDES THE MONEY HONEY: As with all major projects, there will be many challenges that Word-of-Mouth will need to overcome. Obviously not all these problems are forseeable, but past experiences have provided a roadmap for this. 

The major problems we expect to encounter come hand-in-hand with issues found in many start up organisations. This includes gaining brand recognition, expanding networks, and ensuring our initial business decisions are in-line with our community focus. Being aware of these possible challenges is a great first step in finding solutions, however some works needs to be undertaken in order to combat them. For example; an ethical practices manager has been appointed in order to ensure community and sustainable practices are put first in all decisions.

Solutions for brand notoriety and networking can be found in our promotional scheme. Just being part of the Fringe Festival means our co-operative will gain wide-spread publicity in programs and web coverage, however we have also been quoted on a poster advertising campaign and have established ourselves in social media as a self-initiated marketing program.

story:
Aspire Dance Company Presents

SEASONS

A Concert to Benefit St. Luke’s Pediatric Oncology Department

May 8, Mountain View High School

​Boise’s Aspire Dance Company has invested this year in exploring the seasonal cycles and how they are mirrored in human lives. The result of this journey is SEASONS, a performance of new works by Aspire Company members, each with a unique perspective and each specializing in a different form of dance. The show will began with spring and move chronologically through the seasons as the dancers explore how elements of each season can be found in the human experience. Seasons will premiere May 8 at 5:00 pm and 7:30 pm at Mountain View High School. Birth and rebirth, Growing pains, spousal relationships, and depression are among the themes investigated in the new works. All profits from this concert will go to benefit St. Luke’s Pediatric Oncology Department.

 Working together with St. Luke’s Pediatric Oncology Department and Michael Hockman, Aspire hopes to raise funds to assist in building a playground for the children of St. Luke’s. With compromised immune systems, these children cannot risk visiting local playgrounds as their bodies would be unable to fight off many viruses and illnesses. With low platelets, a bruise or a cut means continued bleeding and slow healing.  A germ-free, padded playground would allow them to play and explore in a safe, uncompromising environment. Many of these children are in the clinic for up to 8 hours receiving treatment. The current outdoor play area consists mostly of concrete and risks potential safety. The proposed playground includes padded flooring and low level climbing equipment that is also antibacterial. The layout encourages imaginative play and allows safe exposure to the outdoors. 

About the company:  Aspire Dance Company is the Treasure Valley’s newest professional dance company. Based on the concept that all dance forms are equally worthy of exploration and each has a place in exploring ourselves and our world, Aspire has something that will please everyone. Each member of the company has a different background in dance. Because of this we are able to explore beyond most dance companies, as we embraces all styles: Modern, ballet, tap, Hip Hop, ballroom, ethnic dance, etc. All dances are unique works of company members.  

 

Performance Details:

Aspire Dance Company in 

Seasons

Date: May 8

Time:5 pm and 7:30 pm

Location: Mountain View High School

Tickets: $8 for adults $6 for students

Cash or check only at the door

www.aspiredancecompany.org
story_txt: Aspire Dance Company PresentsSEASONSA Concert to Benefit St. Luke’s Pediatric Oncology DepartmentMay 8, Mountain View High School​Boise’s Aspire Dance Company has invested this year in exploring the seasonal cycles and how they are mirrored in human lives. The result of this journey is SEASONS, a performance of new works by Aspire Company members, each with a unique perspective and each specializing in a different form of dance. The show will began with spring and move chronologically through the seasons as the dancers explore how elements of each season can be found in the human experience. Seasons will premiere May 8 at 5:00 pm and 7:30 pm at Mountain View High School. Birth and rebirth, Growing pains, spousal relationships, and depression are among the themes investigated in the new works. All profits from this concert will go to benefit St. Luke’s Pediatric Oncology Department. Working together with St. Luke’s Pediatric Oncology Department and Michael Hockman, Aspire hopes to raise funds to assist in building a playground for the children of St. Luke’s. With compromised immune systems, these children cannot risk visiting local playgrounds as their bodies would be unable to fight off many viruses and illnesses. With low platelets, a bruise or a cut means continued bleeding and slow healing.  A germ-free, padded playground would allow them to play and explore in a safe, uncompromising environment. Many of these children are in the clinic for up to 8 hours receiving treatment. The current outdoor play area consists mostly of concrete and risks potential safety. The proposed playground includes padded flooring and low level climbing equipment that is also antibacterial. The layout encourages imaginative play and allows safe exposure to the outdoors. About the company:  Aspire Dance Company is the Treasure Valley’s newest professional dance company. Based on the concept that all dance forms are equally worthy of exploration and each has a place in exploring ourselves and our world, Aspire has something that will please everyone. Each member of the company has a different background in dance. Because of this we are able to explore beyond most dance companies, as we embraces all styles: Modern, ballet, tap, Hip Hop, ballroom, ethnic dance, etc. All dances are unique works of company members.   Performance Details:Aspire Dance Company in SeasonsDate: May 8Time:5 pm and 7:30 pmLocation: Mountain View High SchoolTickets: $8 for adults $6 for studentsCash or check only at the doorwww.aspiredancecompany.org

story:
Short Summary

After working with Robert D'Avanzo in his highly touted scene study and on-camera classes, James Lujan and Jordan McRae knew they wanted to put on a production of the very excellent play "Red Angel" by Eric Bogosian.  Along with Hallie Cooper and Dan Creed, the cast and director bring a solid collection of experience to The Missing Piece Theatre in Burbank for a 4 show/2 weekend run. 

What We Need & What You Get

The funds we're looking for will help cover the rights and royalties due to Dramatists' Play Services in NYC, along with the rental of the theatre.  The rights and royalties are $600 total, and the theatre rental is $1200.  The remaining $700 is for publicity (posters, postcards, mailers), set furniture, lumber, hardware, costumes, and music.

The Impact

We chose this play due to its uncanny ability to create recognition in everyone who reads and or sees it.  Bogosian's "Red Angel" delves into the anxiety in all of us - stemming from our past relationships, childhood, finanacial issues - all the while swallowing us whole in what is the temptation of a better life.

The director and actors chose this work, as it tells a REAL story, with just enough sex and comedy to make you think "maybe not ALL theatre in LA is awful?"  Our primary goal, as Horace said, is to teach and entertain in order to have people leaving the theatre with a great conversation piece.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, hey... we get it.  Help us spread the word about the show!  It's only a 50 seat theatre, and we're running the last two weekends in June.  June 21, 22, 28, and 29th.  Tix are $15 at:

 http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/398438

story:
"Do you ever wonder... how many times your life is gonna totally change and then, like, start all over again?”

What do an Earth-mother-type teacher, her aging hippie husband, a flirty former actress, an introverted 16-year-old, and a divorced carpenter have in common?

Very little.....or at least that’s what they think until they take a six week community "creative drama class" and participate in acting games that become ever-more revealing and moving. 

In this hilarious and touching play we catch glimpses of the poignant drama that animates ordinary lives.

“When four lost New Englanders - who enroll in Marty’s six-week-long community centre drama class - begin to experiment with harmless games, hearts are quietly torn apart and tiny wars of epic proportions are waged and won.  A beautifully crafted diorama, a Petri dish in which we see, with hilarious detail and clarity, the antic sadness of a motley quintet.”

-Dramatists Play Services

Called an “absorbing, unblinking and sharply funny play” by the New York Times, Circle Mirror Transformation celebrates the subtle and surprising power of creativity.


Critical Acclaim and Awards:

    • Circle Mirror Transformation  was an Off-Broadway hit when it premiered in 2009.  It won the 2010 Obie Award  for Best New American Play. 
    • Voted one of the Top Ten Plays of 2009 by The New York Times, Time Out New York, and The New Yorker.
    “Circle Mirror Transformation" is deceptively simple in structure, but it packs a terrific punch. It reminds us of our inescapable need to come together and forge human connections — it reminds us, in short, of the very power of theater. -- Entertainment Weekly
    "..an unheralded gem... immensely lovable new play"                             
    The New York Times

    “Smartly, sneakily, Baker gives us the rare theater-centric play that's not self-obsessed. Circle Mirror Transformation is about real people exploring their lives through tiny leaps of faith and creativity..”  Backstage


    Cast & Creative:

    Marty ..... Jill Harland

    James ..... Mark Whelan

    Schultz ..... David Frisch

    Theresa ..... Pip Dwyer

    Lauren ..... Laura Jabalee


    Directed by Heather Braaten

    Stage managed by  Kyra Ritchie

    Designed by  Laird MacDonald


    Learn more about the company here: www.PlayPracticeToronto.com


    What We Need & What You Get

    We need your help to bring Circle Mirror Transformation to Toronto.  Seed money has been invested in this project by Pip Dwyer - producer. 

    But there is just so much more money needed to cover the costs of producing theatre.  They add up...fast.

    Our total budget comes in around $8600.     

    The list of costs below is an easy way for you to see how $6000 can help us make this play happen!

    • rights for the play  $1300
    • venue  $3750
    • rehearsal space  $1150
    • set and lights  $700
    • publicity  $500
    • marketing materials/media/printing  $575
    In addition to the above fixed costs, there are even more expenses:
    • administration
    • transportation
    • sound engineering
    • union fees -actors' Equity Insurance
    • liability insurance on the theatre
    • props/ wardrobe

    We hope that by reaching our fundraising goal, and possibly exceeding it...we will be able to  allocate as much of the box office revenue as we can to paying the dedicated cast and crew for their talent, time  and effort.

    PERKS!...if you want 'em...we got 'em!

    • Look at our perks list to the right...anything you like there? Grab it before its gone!


    Other Ways You Can Help

    We know all too well that sometimes you just can't afford to contribute $ ... but, hey! That doesn't mean you can't help!  We are grateful for all kinds of support!

    • SHARE our campaign on your FACEBOOK and/or TWITTER pages

    • ENCOURAGE your friends to make a contribution.

    • SPREAD the word, about our show and our campaign.

    • REACH OUT by email to any individuals and/or companies whom you think might be interested in sponsoring us, or let us know by emailing playpractice@yahoo.ca

    • Come and see the show! Tickets are available here: www.secureaseat.com

    FACEBOOK: https://www.facebook.com/events/1485723818352672/

    TWITTER:   https://twitter.com/PracticePlay

    EMAIL:   playpractice@yahoo.ca

    WEBSITE:  www.PlayPracticeToronto.com

story:
Nuestro Proyecto

Desde su estreno en 1904, Peter Pan del escocés J.M Barrie ha sido un referente de imaginación y juego para todos los niños sin importar la generación, manteniendo, después de tantos años, la firme creencia de que la infancia no se irá a ninguna parte siempre y cuando recordemos la existencia de un lejano lugar llamado “Nunca Jamás”.

En un país que más que nunca necesita creer, un grupo de jóvenes comprometidos con las artes decidimos emprender este proyecto que busca rescatar la inocencia del juego en los más pequeños y la importancia de creer en los más grandes, mediante un montaje musical inspirado en las hadas, los piratas, los indios, la familia, los niños y sobretodo: la imaginación.

El enfrentarse a las adversidades y apostar por nuestro país fue una decisión muy fácil de tomar para nosotros, pero lamentándolo mucho, no tan fácil de llevar a cabo. Por eso quisiéramos invitarte a ayudar a que nuestro proyecto (Sí, tuyo y de nosotros) pueda realizarse. Te invitamos a que... creas.

¿Quiénes somos?

Contamos con un elenco de 15 personas encargadas de darle vida a todos esos personajes que acompañaron nuestra infancia. Jóvenes formados en las áreas de canto, baile y actuación que ensayan arduamente para poder cambiar una que otra vida. Son: Gabriel Scampini, Giza Pavone, Julián Izquierdo A., Jonathan Collet, Lorena Lezama, Alfredo Osiglia, Irene Casanova, Valeria Puchetti, Luis Fernando Sosa, Fabiola Muro, Isabella Cerullo y Carmen Linares.

Un equipo creativo de primera, será el encargado de los aspectos artísticos que completan un espectáculo lleno de magia e ilusión. Como director de arte se encuentra Pedro Ignacio Muñoz, como productora general Marlys Carolina, coreografías de Taba Luis Ramírez, y como directora general, Victoria Salomón. A ellos se unen en diseño de vestuario, Claudia Aguirre, en diseño de maquillaje Marianery Amín, en dirección musical Daniel Antonini Zapata, y en diseño escenográfico, Lissy García.

¿Cómo ayudar?

Para lograr el resultado que queremos necesitamos de tu apoyo. Los gastos de producción, compra de materiales, alquiler de equipos y costo de publicidad, exceden nuestras posibilidades y por eso buscamos tu contribución.

  • 100 Dólares: Serás nombrado en el programa de mano como “Ayudante especial”. Te enviaremos el video de la obra (con subtítulos en ingles) y una camisa de nuestro grupo.
  • 50 dólares: Serás nombrado en el programa de mano en los agradecimientos y te enviaremos una camisa de nuestro grupo.
  • 10 dólares: Serás nombrado en el programa de mano de la obra en los agradecimientos.
  • 5 dólares: Nuestro más sincero agradecimiento por tu dedicación a invertir en la cultura de un país que necesita cada día más y mejor teatro. ¡Mil gracias!

    Finalmente...

    Algunos nos dicen crédulos, otros ingenuos, muchos más nos dicen disociados de la realidad, a nosotros nos gusta pensar que somos soñadores. Creemos que siempre podemos hacer más y mejor arte. Y sabemos que tú también lo crees.... 


    Incluso si no puedes colaborar, te agradecemos enormemente tu invaluable atención, se necesita más gente como tú. Ayúdanos difundiendo esta campaña con tus conocidos y con cualquiera que creas que puede colaborar. 

      ---------

      For those who do believe in fairies...


      Our Project

      Since its debut in 1904, Peter Pan written by the Scotsman J.M Barrie, has been a benchmark for the imagination and games for children, regardless of their generation, maintaining, after all these years, the firm belief that childhood is not  going anywhere as long we remember the existence of a distant place called “Neverland”.

      In a country that needs to believe more than ever, we, a group of young people committed to the arts, decided to begin this project in the hope of rescuing the innocence of little children playing games and the need to believe for the young at heart, through the assembly of a musical inspired in fairies, pirates, Indians, family, children and, above all, the imagination.

      Facing adversities and betting in favor of our country was really an easy decision for us to make; unfortunately, it wasn’t so easy to do so. That’s why we would like to invite you to help in our project (yes; yours and ours) so that it can be done. We invite you to... believe.

      Who are we?

      We have a cast of 15 people responsible for giving life to all those characters that accompanied our childhood. They are young people trained in the areas of singing, dancing and acting that work very hard to change other people’s lives. They are: Gabriel Scampini, Giza Pavone, Julián Izquierdo A., Jonathan Collet, Lorena Lezama, Alfredo Osiglia, Irene Casanova, Valeria Puchetti, Luis Fernando Sosa, Fabiola Muro, Isabella Cerullo and Carmen Linares.

      An A-list creative team will be in charge of every artistic aspect of the show, complementing it with magic and illusion. Pedro Muñoz is the Art Director, Marlys Lares is the Producer, Taba Luis Ramirez is the Choreographer and Victoria Salomon is the Director of the play. Working with them are, Claudia Aguirre as the Costume Designer, Marianery Amin as the Makeup Artist, Daniel Antonini Zapata as the Music Director and Lissy García as the Stage Designer.

      How to help?

      To achieve the result we want, we need your support. Production costs, purchase  of materials, equipment rental and advertising costs exceed our possibilities and  therefore we seek your contribution.

      100 US Dollars: You will be named in the playbill as a "Special Assistant." We will  send you the video of the play (with English subtitles) and group shirt.

      50 US Dollars: You will be named in the playbill in the acknowledgments and we  will send you one of our group shirts. 

      10 US Dollars: You will be named in the playbill in the acknowledgments.

      5 US Dollars: Our sincere thanks for your dedication to invest in the culture of a country that needs more and better theater every day. Thank you so much!

      Finally...

      Some people call us gullible, others think we are naive, many more say that we  are dissociated from reality. We like to think we are dreamers. We believe we can always do more and better art. And we know you think so too...


      Even if you can’t collaborate, we greatly appreciate your invaluable attention; the world needs more people like you. Help us by spreading this campaign with your acquaintances and anyone else that you think can help.

story:
About Vertigo Productions

Vertigo gives undergraduate playwrights the opportunity to have their original scripts realized into full-fledged productions. By producing student-written theatre, Vertigo hopes to be a creative and dynamic presence on campus, encouraging students to take artistic risk. Vertigo is the only student theatre organization on the Northwestern campus that produces entirely student-written work.

Now in its 20th year of producing student-written works, Vertigo has an exciting season ahead and needs your help to get it going!

Bucky D's

The first show of Vertigo's season, Bucky D's is a laugh-out-loud, side-splitting comedy! Set in a run-down arcade with a whole lot of heart, Bucky D's follows everyman Clu Flynn as he is forced to choose between attempting to save the struggling Scooter's Pizza Palace and selling out to the corporate Bucky D's. Along the way, we meet the loyal Jansen family, the enterprising Buckwaters, Mountain Dew addicts, quirky staff members, and of course, Scooter's animatronic band. Will Clu sell out or save Scooter's?

Performances are Thursday, September 25th at 10:00pm, Friday, September 26th at 8:00pm and 11:00pm, and Saturday, September 27th at 2:00pm and 8:00pm in Shanley Pavilion at Northwestern University. Tickets are $5.00 for Northwestern students, $10.00 for general public.

Your Donation

Your donations will help make Bucky D's and Vertigo's mission possible. Without contributions from people like you, there is no way we could continue to inspire student writers, directors, producers, designers, and performers. We value each and every donation, no matter how small, and thank you for your contribution to student theatre!

The People

Producer: Bailey LePage
Director: Garrett Baer
Writers: Anne Sundell, Nick DiMaso, Sarah Sherman, Wes Humphrey, Wyatt Fair
Cast: Anne Sundell, Caroline Reedy, Eddie Sánchez, Jared Corak, Kylie Mullins, Nick DiMaso, Sarah Sherman, Wes Humphrey, Wyatt Fair
Production Team: Anne Sundell, Annie Brennen, Bryan Matias, Cecilia Pappalardo, Gus Berrizbeitia, Lizzy Wigley, Mallory Harrington, Raphael Grimes, Sarah Mowaswes, Sarah Sherman, Sean Gunderson
Vertigo Productions: Aaron Lorenz, Annie Brennen, Dominique French, Elsa Gay, Eva Victor, Garrett Baer, Isabel Thompson, Kyle Sherman, Mallory Harrington, Max Abner, Natalie Rotter-Laitman, Sam Mueller, Scott Egleston, Wes Humphrey, Wyatt Fair

By producing student-written theatre, Vertigo hopes to be a creative and dynamic presence on campus, encouraging students to take artistic risk. Vertigo is the only student theatre organization on the Northwestern campus that produces entirely student-written work.
Now in its 20th year of producing student-written works, Vertigo has an exciting season ahead and needs your help to get it going!   Bucky D's The first show of Vertigo's season, Bucky D's is a laugh-out-loud, side-splitting comedy! Set in a run-down arcade with a whole lot of heart, Bucky D's follows everyman Clu Flynn as he is forced to choose between attempting to save the struggling Scooter's Pizza Palace and selling out to the corporate Bucky D's. Along the way, we meet the loyal Jansen family, the enterprising Buckwaters, Mountain Dew addicts, quirky staff members, and of course, Scooter's animatronic band. Will Clu sell out or save Scooter's?
Performances are Thursday, September 25th at 10:00pm, Friday, September 26th at 8:00pm and 11:00pm, and Saturday, September 27th at 2:00pm and 8:00pm in Shanley Pavilion at Northwestern University. Tickets are $5.00 for Northwestern students, $10.00 for general public.
  Your Donation Your donations will help make Bucky D's and Vertigo's mission possible. Without contributions from people like you, there is no way we could continue to inspire student writers, directors, producers, designers, and performers. We value each and every donation, no matter how small, and thank you for your contribution to student theatre!

The People
Producer: Bailey LePage
Director: Garrett Baer
Writers: Anne Sundell, Nick DiMaso, Sarah Sherman, Wes Humphrey, Wyatt Fair
Cast: Anne Sundell, Caroline Reedy, Eddie Sánchez, Jared Corak, Kylie Mullins, Nick DiMaso, Sarah Sherman, Wes Humphrey, Wyatt Fair
Production Team: Anne Sundell, Annie Brennen, Bryan Matias, Cecilia Pappalardo, Gus Berrizbeitia, Lizzy Wigley, Mallory Harrington, Raphael Grimes, Sarah Mowaswes, Sarah Sherman, Sean Gunderson
Vertigo Productions: Aaron Lorenz, Annie Brennen, Dominique French, Elsa Gay, Eva Victor, Garrett Baer, Isabel Thompson, Kyle Sherman, Mallory Harrington, Max Abner, Natalie Rotter-Laitman, Sam Mueller, Scott Egleston, Wes Humphrey, Wyatt Fair

story:
It's a short story written by Washington Irving right around the time Jersey City got its current name (1838) and Hudson County was marked 
as separate from Bergen County (1840).  

That quote says a lot about this story.

It turns out, Irving came to Jersey City, New Jersey - formerly known as
the Village of Communipaw - often, to write.
And in his time, it was still a quiet and very Dutch feeling place.

Fascinated by history since childhood, a writer and actor and conceptual artist,
I was drawn to this story by its themes, still fresh today:  
People from all different backgrounds, coming together here with personal drive,
partnering in hope of business success,
navigating a cultural divide,
dealing with the political realities of the time, and place.

This is where we are!

A hanging, a marriage, a haunting, a funeral...

That's just the beginning of the excitement of 
A Legend of Communipaw!

Seven years of research brought me to a first staging in 2013,
and now we're going to step it up, adding a prologue scene set in the 21st century 
to introduce background history of the Dutch in the 17th century, and more.

We're not giving anything away when we invite you to read Washington Irving's original short story.  In fact, we're counting on Irving's keen voice and mastery of the voice and fearsome chills of the time to inspire you to come see

A Legend of Communipaw! 


My goals as Executive Producer are many.  The most important ones are:

- to show this story and the creative works around it to as many people, world-wide, as possible.  This story is part of ALL of our history!
- to pay the committed, talented artists involved for their work.  That means a reasonable stipend for each actor, musician and creative contributor.
- to provide a safe, professional environment for the volunteers and crew.

    My Background

    I produced and directed my first plays in grammar school! I acted in many school productions and continued in community, regional and NYC productions, with roles and technical positions in projects small and large.


    More recently, I acted in several _gaia studio productions (Louis LaRusso II's "The Flora Dora Girls Weekly Sewing Circle," the penultimate monologue in The Vagina Monologues, and an ensemble singer/actor role in "Galileo: The Musical," in Planet Connexions Festivity.)


    Also in my portfolio are several conceptual installations;
    published writing in fiction and nonfiction, including pieces about
    Jersey City history in local magazines;
    vocal training and performances in opera, rock, blues, jazz and oratorio, and more.


    As an artist, I do what I am moved to do

    and I have rarely been so inspired as I am to bring A Legend of Communipaw out of obscurity and to illuminate the heritage in Communipaw -
     today's Jersey City, New Jersey - that belongs to all of us.
     

    A Legend of Communipaw is my first feature production.  I've produced and directed many live performances and small theatrical works, but this play is the largest project I've helmed.  I am LOVING IT!


    Why We NEED Your Donation!

    I've crowd-funded my way out of homelessness, raised money for numerous non-profits, drawn financial support for community groups, solicited contributions to pay musicians and other performers at more events than I could count.  As a live music producer, I consistently present top talent in neighborhood venues in Jersey City and beyond.

    In 2013, we attracted investors who made it possible to bring the play to fruition.  We received strong critical success, but every dime offered was spent, and investors received no return.  This year, we're straight up asking for public support.

    Meeting our minimum target of $4,000 will allow us to meet our most fundamental financial obligations.  At this level, we can cover uncompromisingly requisite expenses, including printing of promotional materials (showcards, posters, etc.), stipends for creative professionals, and technical obligations such as sets, lighting, sound and costumes.
    Raising more will allow us to pay every performer and support person a minimal stipend acknowledging their work and ensuring their expenses are covered.

    When you support this project, you will know that you are part of a new way to experience heritage, literature and the performing arts, all at the same time.

    This project is a unique example of how the arts can expand our views and open our minds.


    Risks & Challenges

    Don't let us hang out to dry!

    A Legend of Communipaw is an important part of early American literature and of our shared cultural heritage.  
    We're always trying to learn from history....


    Through the arts, we can!
    Help bring our story


      Other Ways You Can Help

      We understand that times are particularly hard, and you might have barely a spare dime, if that, to send to a theater project, even a very cool and unique one like
      A Legend of Communipaw.  

      But you can still be a part of The Legend!  Here are some ways you can help us make this show a reality:

      • PROMOTE THIS CAMPAIGN!  Share this campaign with your network - by email, social media, word of mouth, however you can. 
      • LIKE our facebook PAGE!  And Invite your friends to Like our Page too.  Page Likes translate into better publicity for every ad we run on facebook.
      • Share my LinkedIn page with your creative professional network.  
      • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
      • Volunteer!  We need people to staff our concessions table, the box office, help the actors in the dressing room, move set pieces and more. 
        Contact info@ALegendOfCommunipaw.com for more information.
      • And use the Indiegogo share tools!


                        Be a part of history!
                                      Join


      Thank you!

Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.

story:
The Project

We have been invited by Assembly Festival Ltd., the longest running and most prestigious of the multi-venue operators and promoters on the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, to perform Kafka's Ape at their venue:  George Square Studios - Five. Infinithéâtre and the Ape have toured within Canada before but bringing the show overseas is a new and exciting challenge. With a total of 24 performances over 26 days, it is an ambitious project to say the least. 

Kafka's Ape was first produced by Infinithéâtre in January 2013.  Due to popular demand, we remounted it in November 2013. After a successful run at the 2014 Toronto Summerworks Performing Arts Festival, Kafka's Ape completed a 1-month tour of Ontario & Québec, Canada in fall 2014. It was after completing that first tour that we had the confidence to bring the Ape to international stages.

"The first thing we notice about Kafka's Ape... is the eerie quality of the makeup and costumes ... The second remarkable thing... is Howard Rosenstein's uncanny mastery of the role of Mr. Redpeter"

                                                                               -Pat Donnelly, Montreal Gazette

                     

Captured on the Gold Coast and imprisoned in a cage, Redpeter's only escape route is to become a walking, talking, spitting, hard-drinking member of the Peace Industry, the entrepreneurial world of mercenary soldiers that is one of the biggest growth industries of the 21st century. In detailing the journey of his enforced evolution from Apedom to Humandom, Mr. Redpeter is a living embodiment of the irony that perhaps now he is more animal than he ever was as an Ape. Based on Kafka’s short story A Report for an Academy. 
 


Note from Director Guy Sprung:

In Kafka’s original short story, Redpeter’s journey from Apehood to Humanhood culminates with him as a celebrated variety act on the stages of the world. Kafka’s themes of assimilation, freedom and civilization, posit the ultimate irony that Redpeter as an ape was much more humane than any human. I have taken the liberty, for our adaptation of the story, to have Redpeter end up as a celebrated member of the ‘private security industry’, a euphemism that white-washes his reality as a mercenary soldier. Kafka, I hope, will not object too much to this contemporizing of his work. 

Redpeter has been assimilated into one of the most heinous occupations that Homo Sapiens has embraced, that of privatizing the killing and the subjugating of other human beings – for profit. Just as Redpeter, in the original, had to distort his animal nature to be accepted into humanhood, so in our version, he has to distort his ape nature even more to become a successful corporate military citizen. A good 85% of the text is still true to the original story. I have blended in the dark humour and the central maxim of “obedience” from one of Kafka’s other stories, In The Penal Colony.                                                  

                                                 

The image of the Statue of Liberty with a sword, not a torch, in her hand (which is the logo of Redpeter’s employer, Graywater Corporation) we took from a description of the statue in Kafka’s unfinished novel, Amerika. Kafka’s central thesis, that other animals have a dignity and a respect for their own species which Homo Sapiens, on its evolutionary journey, has lost, has been nudged into the 21st Century.


What We Need

Touring a show, even a small one like Kafka's Ape, is expensive. Touring a show internationally - even more so. With this campaign we are aiming to raise $5,000, which represents roughly 11% of the total cost for this project. We have been working our tails off since January to raise the funds necessary to cover registration, shipping/building our set, paying and transporting our hard working crew and advertising. The $5,000 that we raise with this campaign will go towards the cost of food and accommodations for our traveling crew of 3.
Due to budgetary restrictions we are sending a lean and mean team of 1 stage manager, 1 technician and 1 actor to the Edinburgh Fringe. These are definitely among the hardest working people in existence and in order to keep them at their supernatural functioning levels, they need to eat. As you will have read in the majority of campaigns for the Edinburgh Fringe, Edinburgh thrives on it's tourism industry and that is reflected in the prices for food and most everything else. If we (conservatively) estimate food costs per person to be £25 per day (thats $47.57 CAD at the current exchange rate), we are easily looking at $4,281.30CAD for the 30 days they will spend away from home. If we do not reach our goal, all funds raised will go toward food costs, but if we do reach it, any remaining funds after food will be used to help with accommodation costs. 

Impact

Participating in the Edinburgh Fringe Festival would grab some attention for Québec English-Language theatre on international stages. Infinithéâtre believes that Québec is teeming with talented playwrights and top-notch plays and we are committed to having our work noticed both nationally and internationally. This is a big year for Québec theatre at the Fringe - with a handful of other companies from the province performing alongside us in the festival, our province is being solidly represented. 
As a company, Infinithéâtre has successfully executed tours in the past and we have learned that the most important component in a successful tour is the human  element - a hardworking, well cared-for crew - which is exactly what every cent of the funds raised in this campaign will go towards. Without skilled actors and behind-the-scenes heroes, going to the theatre would be a very dull experience for everyone. 

Who We Are

We are Infinithéâtre, a small theatre production company located in Montréal, Québec, Canada. Our mandate is to develop, promote, produce and broker new work written by Québec English-Language Playwrights. If you have a minute, check out our company history video below!


In addition to our 3-play seasons of new works, we also hold an annual playwriting competition called Write-On-Q!, where we get to read scripts from English-Québec's upcoming, as well as established, playwrights. The finalists get cash prizes as well as a public reading by professional actors in The Pipeline Play-Reading Series held in December of each year. Many of the plays that we read in The Pipeline go on to be programmed by large Montréal theatre companies such as The Centaur Theatre. We have recently also taken it upon ourselves to begin touring with our critically acclaimed production Kafka's Ape. You can learn more about our company though our website, www.infinitheatre.com


Other Ways You Can Help

Helps us get the word out! Do you have friends living in Edinburgh or know someone who is travelling there for the Fringe? Let them know about the show!

Also, don't forget to share this campaign with your network on Facebook etc. using the Indiegogo share tools!
