story:
The Drama

In June 2013 Project Shakespeare was invited by the Royal Shakespeare Company to perform at their outdoor theatre, The Dell, in Stratford-Upon-Avon, England. We were thrilled! But there was a catch-- we had to rehearse the show (Hamlet of all things, no small feat!) and get ten student actors, director and chaperones, plus costumes and sets from New England to Olde  in just 8 weeks. We did the math and realized it would cost upwards of $30,000. Daunted but not deterred we begged the RSC to defer our participation until August 2014. Then we dove deep into earning and raising funds. Our summer 2013 season was the most successful in Project Shakespeare's 20 year history and we've spent the last eight months growing the company, expanding our offerings and pursuing every possible funding opportunity. PS students have taken part-time jobs and their families have plunged into helping to fundraise. We're nearly halfway there but we need help!

Get In On the Act!

We're seeking to raise $10,000 towards the $30,000 necessary to bring Hamlet to Shakespeare's birthplace. These funds will subsidize the expenses of students who need financial aid and cover some of the many costs associated with moving one of Shakespeare's greatest dramas across the Atlantic. 


Project Shakespeare is a 501c3 non-profit organization that provides high-quality educational theatrre instruction to students in the Monadnock region of New Hampshire. More than half the students particpating each summer receive financial aid and the program never turns anyone away if they can't pay. The chance to bring their work to England is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for students whose lives have already been changed by the power of theatre and the dedication of Project Shakespeare's powerhouse founder and director, Deborah Shakespeare Thurber. 
Your tax-dedcutible donation will help in-need students experience the educational adventure of their lives, providing them with the chance to bring over a year's worth of intense work and dedication to one of the world's greatest stages in the birthplace of one of humanity's greatest artists. 

Help Behind the Scenes!


If you can't contribute financially, you can still help support our project! Please share this campaign and our story with friends and family via email or on Facebook and Twitter- the more people know, the better!


Hear What Some Alumni Say!

David Jette

story:
ABOUT THE PROJECT:

Do you ever wonder where your sh%t comes from?

THE AGONY AND THE ECSTASY OF STEVE JOBS is one of most controversial plays in recent theatre history. It is also one of the most frequently performed - since Mike Daisey made the play available for free license, TATESJ has been produced some 57 times all over the world, translated into numerous languages, and even performed in China.  

... And now it's a musical.

THE AGONY AND THE ECSTASY OF STEVE JOBS: THE MUSICAL will premier this summer in Washington, DC at the 2013 Capital Fringe Festival.  Adapted by Timothy J. Guillot from Mike Daisey's play, the musical will be directed by Ronee Penoi.  

 

HOW YOUR DONATION HELPS:

THE AGONY AND THE ECSTASY OF STEVE JOBS: THE MUSICAL is Junesong’s most ambitious project to date and we need your help to make it happen.  Funding raised through this Indiegogo campaign will go to directly support the production and all associated costs: purchasing props and costumes, renting rehearsal space, and most importantly paying everyone involved for their time and talents.  We value the work of our actors, musicians, and creative team, and are committed to paying everyone involved in the production.  For those who are more interested in funding the nuts and bolts, we will also use funds to purchase envelopes, to print scripts, and buy highlighters!  (Who doesn’t love office supplies!)

Here’s an idea of what your donation supports:

  • Fringe Participation Fee: $575
  • Insurance: $200
  • Costumes: $200
  • Sound & Lighting Equipment: $150
  • Weekly Travel for an Actor to Rehearsal: $25
  • Lunch for Cast & Creative team: $75
  • Musicians: $450
  • Postcards & Programs: $350
  • General Admin. Supplies: $75

Any donation - from $1 to $1,000 - will be put to good use in getting this production off the ground.  We THANK YOU for your support!!

WHAT IS JUNESONG? 

Junesong, founded by Meghan Long and Timothy J. Guillot, is a multi-disciplinary arts organization exploring and shattering boundaries between art forms to create an entirely unique theatrical experience.  Previous Junesong productions include Insurgent Sonata by Timothy J. Guillot produced at the 2011 Capital Fringe Festival, We Fight We Die by Timothy J. Guillot produced as part of the 2011-2012 Mead Theatre Lab Program, and The Webcam Play by Timothy J. Guillot produced at the 2012 Capital Fringe Festival.  Junesong produced, in association with Artists’ Bloc, a workshop presentation of Timothy J. Guillot’s The Last Night of Caroline’s Blues. 

THE AGONY AND THE ECSTASY OF STEVE JOBS: THE MUSICAL is:

  • Timothy J. Guillot - Writer & Producer
  • Ronee Penoi - Director
  • Meghan Long - Producer 
  • Lorna Mulvaney - Associate Producer & Stage Manager

STILL HAVE QUESTIONS? WANT TO KNOW MORE?

We’d love to hear from you. 

Feel free to send us an email at junesongarts@gmail.com. 

You can find us on Facebook here - https://www.facebook.com/pages/Junesong-Arts/23.... 

If you prefer 140-character or less interactions we’re on Twitter, too! Tweet us @junesongarts.

story:
JAMES MACLEAN:
MUSICAL THEATRE TRAINING

I would like to continue my performance training focusing on singing and dancing with Neptune Theatre School's Musical Theatre Foundation Program (MTFP).

This one-year conservatory course offers classes in Singing, Voice, Acting/Text, Ballet, Tap, Ensemble, Creative Movement and Musical Theatre History. Allowing me to grow upon my previous training at the National Theatre school becoming a more diverse performer. (Neptune Theatre: Musical Theatre Foundation Program)

Your support is critical as this program is not supported by the Canadian Student Loan Services.

WHAT YOU GET:
Any donation over $10 will receive a handmade Heart Pin! The pin symbolizes your support, and sharing of love. You can wear it on your sleeve, hat, or heart to express love and compassion, while spreading it around the world!

A donation of $100 or more gets you a personalized song and dance, either performed live at your doorstep/office space, or on the world wide web for your continued enjoyment.

Your support will also allow me to make more silly videos with my fellow musical theatre students which will go online for free viewing pleasure.

BUDGET BREAKDOWN:
Tuition: 2,990.00
Indie GoGo %4: $119.6
Credit Card Fee %3: $89.70
Processing fee: $25
---------------------
Total: $3,224.3

Other Ways to Support:
Spread the word! To your family, friends, patrons of the arts! Every little bit helps. Share on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram!

THANK YOU! <3
I can't thank you enough for your support. It means the world!
And I'd like to thank the following for their help in producing the video and this campaign: Danielle Doiron, Avery Brennan, Alice MacLean, Laura Thronton, Nathan Carson and Alex Beal.

story:
Feed Your Obsession

Stillpointe Theatre Initiative 2013/2014 Season Fundraiser


The People

Stillpointe is a group of writers, performers, musicians, singers, actors, technicians, and theatre enthusiasts working and living in the Baltimore area.  While they all come from various artistic backgrounds and disciplines, they were brought together by a belief that theatre should be magical, moving, and above all, an escape.  A sensory-filled world where the audience could come and forget about their daily troubles, even if only for a moment. The Stillpointe Theatre Initiative was created to promote the art of re-imagining the old and creating the new.  Years have passed, our size has expanded, and like-minded dreamers have joined this ever-growing Co-op of exciting NEW theatre.


The Productions

It has now been THREE years Since our humble beginnings and Stillpointe has produced over 15 pieces of theatre.  Productions have ranged from classical plays, such as Titus Andronicus, The Country Wife and Arsenic and Old Lace, to contemporary plays and musicals written by local (Baltimore) and non local (New York) playwrights, such as Kimberley Lynne's The Return of the 5th Sister , Ryan Scott Oliver's 35MM,  Kirsten Child's The Bubbly Black Girl Sheds her Chameleon Skin and Stillpointes own original musical, Shovel in the Dirt. Recently, Stillpointe has dived into a few American Musical Theatre Classics, with our productions of HAIR: The American Tribal Love Rock Musical  and our current production of Little Shop of Horrors, all with great success and rave reviews

The Return of the 5th Sister, Winter 2012


Titus Andronicus, Summer 2011


Arsenic and Old Lace, Fall 2012

Each Stillpointe production is hand crafted, tastefully paired, and site specified to meet all sensory needs.  From the payroll office of an abandoned shoe factory (The Return of the 5th Sister), to the sprawling country fields of western Maryland ( Titus Andronicus), Stillpointe Theatre Initiative provides each audience member a true escape from reality.  Don't believe us? Just try any of the eight cocktails purposely paired with the eight new works of Musical Theatre in our bi- yearly original event , 4 over 3: A Night of Musicals and Mixers ,you too will relish in the escape.



A segment from FOUR OVER THREE: A Night of Musicals and Mixers



The Press

"...Stillpointe’s production is an engaging riot of a good time..." - Bret McCabe, Baltimore City Paper, HAIR 2013
"Never straying too far from this look, Haase has managed to bring a certain cohesion to all of Stillpointe’s productions, creating a familiarity for the audience that keeps them coming back for more." - BEST OF BALTIMORE 2013, Baltimore City Paper
"...the Stillpointe production certainly preserves the essence of “Hair” -- needy, moody, rebellious youth; the struggle between idealism and hedonism; the equally tough struggle between conscience and convenience..." - Tim Smith, Baltimore Sun, HAIR 2013


WYPR Interview - Bubbly Black Girl Sheds Her Chameleon Skin

What Weekly Magazine - Stillpointe Theatre: Love and Magic

Ryan Scott Oliver: 35mm in Baltimore


The Cause

Stillpointe has been lucky enough to to join the ranks of the Baltimore Theatre Community, a very vast, diverse, and rapidly-growing group of artists that are united in their vision of beautifying and diversifying the city of Baltimore.  We strive to make every production more engaging than the last, and in order to do so, budgets must also rise.  However, the money spent on sets, costumes, lights, props, rental fees, licensing costs, printing, and advertising is only done in service to our main goal as an artistic group.  Since the very beginning, Stillpointe has striven to treat each artist we work with as professionally as possible.  Recently, we have begun to offer each artist (musician,actor,director,designer technician, etc.) a stipend for their work with our company.  Although this gesture is gratifying, well-deserved, and entirely necessary, we find ourselves now turning to you, the audience members, most of whom have been with us since the very beginning, to give just a bit more.  We are asking you, our audience base, for $10,000.  This money will go towards producing our largest season to date.  With your help, we can keep our tickets prices affordable, while still providing you with the same high-caliber theatre and hospitality you have come, or will come, to expect from Stillpointe.  Our upcoming season, simply titled "Feed Your Obsession", will shock, excite, and provoke your senses with a fun, fancy, affordable night at the theatre.  

The Season

FEED YOUR OBSESSION  2013/2014 Stillpointe Season

LITTLE SHOP OF HORRORS
by Alan Menken and Howard Ashman
Oct. 18th - Nov. 2nd
The Strand Theater

FOUR OVER THREE**
A Night of Musicals and Mixers
Dec. 13th - Dec. 21st
The Parlor

SWEENEY TODD
The Demon Barber of Fleet Street
by Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler
Feb. 14th - Mar. 2nd
EMP Collective

THE MOTHERFUCKER WITH THE HAT*
by Stephen Adly Guirgis
Apr. 3rd - 19th
Venue - TBA

DARLING**
by Ryan Scott Oliver and Brett Ryback
May 8th - 24th
Venue - TBA

* - Baltimore Premiere
** - Brand New Work


The Perks

We're all about giving as much as we get!  Which is why, when you donate even $1 to our campaign, you will be cordially invited to our super exclusive and super deluxe Funder's Ball. A night of music, food, drinks, and debauchery the only way Stillpointe knows how!  So don't miss your invite to the party of the year, and come on out!
In addition to awesome prizes, we want you show your Stillpointe pride, even when you aren't at the theatre!  We're having buttons and stickers pressed to give to our donorso spread the gospel of Stillpointe in their every day lives!  Check them out below!

BUTTONS!!

MORE BUTTONS!

AND STICKERS!  PIMP YOUR RIDE!

In addition to the amazing prizes and perks we've outlined below, based on how much you donate, you will be getting one extra perk.  No matter if you donate $5 or $500 you will be gifted with the ability to keep enjoying the Stillpointe shows you've come to love.  In turn, we get the perk of being able to keep local talent supported and produced, as well as bringing new works to Baltimore from all corners of the country.  


In Conclusion...

Our goal of $10,000 may seem extreme, but we believe that our work has proven itself to the city of Baltimore and now it deserves to grow.  This season will be our biggest and best yet, but it's also risky.  Big shows come with big price tags, and we can't do it without your help.  

Even if we don't reach our $10,000 goal, every cent donated will go towards helping to fund our season to the fullest extent possible. So, please, give what you can. We have some excellent incentives for you to peruse, and if you find yourself unable to give, please share our campaign with anyone who may be interested in helping to bring strong, imaginative theatre into Baltimore.


THANKS FOR STOPPIN' BY!
xoxo
Stillpointe

story:
This year marks the 35th Anniversary of the Anahid Sofian Dance Company based in New York City, and we are celebrating this milestone with a Gala performance at the Manhattan Music and Art Center on June 28 and 29, 2014.


“Ms. Sofian has worked tirelessly to present Middle eastern dance in all its many forms”
--Robert H. Browning, Executive & Artistic Director, World Music Institute

The Company specializes in dances of the Near and Middle East including many variations on Raqs Sharqi, known in the West as "bellydance." Since its professional debut at Carnegie Hall in 1980, the Company has been instrumental in presenting music and dances inspired by cultures as diverse as the gypsies of Turkey to the Awalim style harem dancers of Egypt. 


“We would recommend and support any project that the
Company undertakes.”
--Alan Pally, Manager of Public Programs, The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts


The Company covers a wide range from traditional to contemporary interpretations, resulting from Ms. Sofian’s training in ballet and modern dance. While drawing inspiration from the rich diversity of Middle Eastern cultures, integrating it with artistic elements of Western dance styles has made the Company’s works accessible to a broader audience. 


The Company is proud to have performed at venues including Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors, the Cleveland Museum of Arts, and have participated in programs including the Downtown Dance Festival and Women’s History Month.


The Company has also premiered two acclaimed off-Broadway productions, Marrakech: Inside the Magic Circle at Baruch Performing Arts Center (2005), and Passage Through Light and Shadows: The Children of Ararat at the Theatre of St. Clements Church (2010).


The Company will showcase 14 representative numbers at the Gala Show. Featuring over 25 dancers and musicians, there will be folkloric dances—a powerful tribal dance from Morocco and women’s dances from Armenia that reflect grace and lyrical beauty. Contemporary pieces include a dance inspired by an old Greek song sung by Irini Pappas, and a dream-like interpretation of "Gazli," written and sung by the young Uzbeki star, Sevara Nazarkhan. Guest artists include Nourhan Sharif and Dancers, Sera Solstice Ensemble, and Carlos Fittante and Robin Gilbert of BALAM Dance Theatre.


“Sofian and her dancers evoked the bazaar, the
nightclub, the harem—and also something essentially female, essentially powerful, that transcends the mercantile.”
--Elizabeth Zimmer, Dance Magazine


The cost of the two-day show is $25,000. We expect to raise $15,000 through ticket sales, fund-raising events and already committed donations.
We are still short $10,000 and need your help.


Your contribution will not only go toward a dance company with a solid track record of quality productions, but one with a unique and important imprint on the cultural history of New York and beyond. 

       


We have some limited number of very special perks. Donate early!  Even sharing this link with all your friends goes a very long way. Thank you for sharing and re-posting! 

Not a good time? No worries. Even after the campaign expires, you can still donate by contacting us directly. 

For tax-deductible donations, please follow this link and select ANAHID SOFIAN STUDIO And DANCE COMPANY from the dropdown menu:

 http://thefield.org/form/donate-artist


Thank you so much for taking an interest in our campaign. We hope to see you at our show! 


Ticket info: 

Saturday June 28     http://www.ticketfly.com/event/584355 

Sunday June 29        http://www.ticketfly.com/event/584359

story:
Dig Infinity!

Dig Infinity! is the story of Lord Buckley (1906-1960), a nearly forgotten jazz comedian, visionary storyteller/philosopher, hipster saint, and premier beatnik rapper. Lord Buckley was best known for transforming Bible stories, Shakespeare soliloquies, myth, legend and history into one-of-a-kind hip-talk monologues combining black street argot and the King’s English into a jazzy patois and worldview that anticipated psychedelia and rap by decades.

What makes Lord Buckley’s life and art still so resonantly timely and why each new generation seems to rediscover and revere his legacy are the ways in which it confronts and comments on controversial components of contemporary American life: religion, politics, language, art, sex, drugs and (most slaiently)... race.

Yet despite being a secret bohemian hero to the likes of Bob Dylan, the Beatles, Lenny Bruce, Grateful Dead, Robin Williams, George Carlin, Whoopi Goldberg, and scores of others, Buckley's legacy has remained tragically underacknowledged.

As Lord Buckley's biographer and a keeper of the flame, I have shared His Lordship's work in a variety of settings and media for more than two decades.

We are all proud that Dig Infinity! has been selected to be presented at this year's Planet Connections Festivity -- NYC's premier eco-friendly/socially-conscious arts festival. Fostering a diverse cross-section of performances, the Festivity seeks to inspire artists and audiences both creatively and fundamentally, in a festive atmosphere. At the heart of the Festivity are like-minded individuals striving to create professional, meaningful theatre, film, music and art while supporting organizations which give back to the community at large.

More about the Planet Connections Festivity can be found here:http://planetconnections.org

And the specific link to the Dig Infinity! portal can be found here: http://planetconnections.org/dig-infinity/

Dig Infinity! is a play drawn from my research invoking the Buckley muse in lively and surreal fashion. After presenting a staged reading in the autumn of 2012, the play has been selected to again be presented as a staged reading at the Planet Connections Festivity in June 2013.

I have assembled a dedicated and talent circle of actors and crew who have thus far worked for the love of the project. In addition to compensating them for their time and efforts, I will need to rent rehearsal space and projection equipment to present a staged reading in the most compelling and transformative manner possible.

The tentative cast, crew and main roles are as follows:

Cast
Oliver Trager … Lord Buckley
Russell Jordan… Orpheus
Katie Baker… Lady Elizabeth Buckley, Ensemble
Michael Fiorillo… Mink Head, Ensemble
Ian Finkel… God, Ensemble
Ridley Parson… Folkie Man, Ensemble
David Lamberton… Narrator, Jazzbo

John Kruth (Music)
Eric Feldman (Lighting and Design)
Leyla Modirzadeh (Lighting and Design)

Dig Infinity! unfolds on four interdependent and intermingling levels: a real-time Lord Buckley performance, an interview with Orpheus (the mythological Greek poet and musician here imagined as a wizened jazz musician), visual representations of Buckley’s more famous pieces, and flashbacks visiting each epoch of his career.

Lord Buckley’s jazz club performance (which turns out to be his last) introduces most of the major characters in the film, creates a central locale to which the main story periodically returns, and allows the audience a glimpse and appreciation of Buckley’s act up-close and personal.

The midnight interview with Orpheus takes place in a surreal radio station. As Buckley tells his life story via flashbacks and demonstrates his art via stylized visual representations of his material, he also engages in a cat-and-mouse argument with Orpheus as the edgy elements of his life and art are bared. This dialogue evolves into the play’s dramatic crisis -- complete with a journey to Hades and a cameo by God -- as it becomes increasingly apparent that Buckley is bargaining for his very soul.

The visual representations of Buckley’s material strive to match the tone of each specific piece with a cinematic environment that best represents its atmosphere.

The flashbacks visit each phase of Buckley’s career: childhood, minstrelsy, the dance marathons, Capone’s Prohibition-era Chicago, the black church, the Swing band era, bebop, and the Beat Generation. Each flashback at once demonstrates the evolution of his art, reveals his self-destructive tendencies, and establishes the liaisons which inspire and destroy him.

I wish I had the time, energy and resources to produce a slick and fancy video to make the pitch Mad Ave. style -- just the little clip above a friend caught at our staged reading of the play presented in conjunction with the Red Harlem Readers at the Indian Cafe on Upper Broadway in early November 2012. And a nice review of the show that might give you an better sense of its power and potential can be found on this wonderful blog: http://hannahmenziesblog.wordpress.com/2012/11/06/dig-infinity-lord-buckley-gets-mythical-at-the-indian-cafe/

We are already working hard to shape the best possible presentation of Lord Buckley's grand revelation and your generosity will ensure an elegant and vital production.

$1,500 will pay for...

Festival Entry Fee: $200

Mobile Projector: $350

Projection Screen: $100

Rehearsal Space Rental: $120

Costumes: $100

Sound Design: $100

PR: $600

And, of course, I'd like to compensate my colleagues in this endeavor who have thus far been essentially donating their time and talents to making Dig Infinity! all that it can be with any extra green gravy we are able to generate through this campaign.

And, finally, this performance of Dig Infinity! is slated to benefit Democracy Now! But, because admission is free, I'd like to earmark 10% of any funds we receive over our stated goal to this fine and cutting edge media outlet. For more information on Democracy Now!, visit thier website: http://www.democracynow.org

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We welcome your contribution, no matter its form.

If you’re unable to contribute financially, you can help by spreading the word about A Day for Grace to as many friends and family as possible.

You can:

  • Copy and paste this content into an email and send it to your email list

  • Share our campaign link on Facebook, Twitter and Google+

  • Come see the staged reading in New York City

    Thursday June 13

    11 AM

    Gene Frankel Theater

    24 Bond St.

story:
Hello, my name is Thomas Wright. I'm a 12 year old dancer and I'm writing to you to ask for your help. Here's a little bit about me:
At the age of three I was so full of energy I could never sit still, so I began taking gymnastics classes and joined a bumper bowling league. This wasn't enough so I also began little league baseball. I excelled at all of these activities and even when I broke my collarbone on the first day of baseball season, I wouldn't let it stop me. At five years old, I tumbled my way into the dance studio. Baseball, bowling and dance were now competing for my full attention. Though I can hold my own on the field and in the lanes, I felt more at home on stage.
After the first dance studio I attended closed when I was 9,
I spent the next year traveling 120 miles every day in order to continue my training. I also competed throughout this year for my first time, while still maintaining my grades at school.
It was towards the end of that year when I decided that I wanted to truly follow my dream of becoming a professional dancer and I convinced my family to move to Las Vegas so I could be closer to the dance studio and surround myself with industry professionals.
For the past four years I've been training, competing and winning awards in Las Vegas.
I've had many opportunities in the last four years. I've performed at Disneyland, competed at several regional competitions and attended many conventions where I've met and trained with Robert Hoffman, Mia Michaels, Mandy Moore, Brian Friedman, Tyce Diorio, Rosero McCoy, Ian Eastwood, Brooke Lipton, Trisha Miranda and Dave Scott, just to name a few.
This year, I won a scholarship and earned the chance to train in Southern California at a six day summer dance intensive called JUMP.
I'm asking for your help to raise enough money to cover travel and lodging for the convention.
The chance to continue training with Mia Michaels, Mandy Moore, Travis Wall, Stacy Tookey, Twitch, Willdabeast and many more, will just help enhance my training and continue to let my God-given talent soar.
Thank you for taking the time to read about me and my goals. Any help you are willing to give will be greatly appreciated, even if it's sharing my link to others.

Thomas Wright

story:
About MULTIPLEX DANCE

Founded in 2013, MULTIPLEX DANCE is the brainchild of Choreographer, Assistant Professor of Dance at UC Irvine, and former member of Diavolo Dance Theater, Chad Michael Hall. Based in Los Angeles, CA, Hall has been choreographing original dance works since 2006. His highly-athletic and acrobatic movement style and edgy, cyberpunk aesthetic have made him a sought-after choreographer and teacher among dance companies, festivals, schools and universities around the country. His obsessions with computer technology, electronic music, and science-fiction drive him to create dances that integrate our visceral and virtual experiences through intense and intricate choreographic structures intertwined with digital media.  Hall is now joined by seven dancers committed to creating original dance works in Hall's unique brand of Techno-Industrial Modern Dance - tumbling, rolling, sliding, supporting, pivoting, dropping, inverting, rebounding, launching, and flying soon to a theater near you!

subSTRATA

subSTRATA is our first new work as a dance company.  We began rehearsals in September of 2013, and we most recently set the overall structure for the piece at Idyllwild Arts Academy in December as artists in residence.  Now we need your help!  We have been invited to premiere the piece at the 2014 Breaking Ground Festival in Tempe, AZ, a significant honor for a new dance company, but we need your support to get there.  Your donation will help to cover the costs of travel expenses, lodging, per diem for the dancers, production costs including costumes and props, and most importantly artist fees for the dancers.  The dancers in MXD are so committed to the vision of making this work and this company come to life that they have been rehearsing mostly for free to make it happen so far.  As a new dance company, I am working full-time to provide as much as I can and compensate them for their amazing talents and dedication, but we do not yet have the resources needed to facilitate a tour to another state to premiere this work on our own.  Through our hard work, dedication and resourcefulness, we have been able to develop "subSTRATA" through exploratory workshops, residencies, in-kind donations, and personal sacrifice.  We have overcome many challenges already to make it this far.  Our last obstacle is the financial hurdle of producing and presenting the work in Arizona to its first audience.  With your support, we will overcome this final challenge!  Please help us to launch our vision with this first debut!

story:
Duvall Productions proudly announces  casting opportunities for the roles of “Production Contributors.” Come partake in the launch of an artists dream by playing the role you were destined for.

Semi-controversial in context — this important theatrical dance production is a rare multi-media endeavor which cries-out for your funding assistance; enabling this modest stage production to metamorphose into the international theater sensation it’s predestined to become. Earn a place with your name in the Performance Program with a contribution of $10 or more and make a visionary’s life work become realized.

NEW PERK ADDED: We all know that dance is back-breaking work; making chiropractic adjustments common among dancers. To that end -- we wish to treat our contributors (of all levels -- $5 and above) to a FREE CHIROPRACTIC VISIT. YES-- we have YOUR back. Now do your part and SAVE a Butterfly....

STORYLINE

The true story of a young Swedish woman en route to Jerusalem to discover her roots, finds unexpected love. Upon being asked to marry, the Synagogue Rabbi declares Lavana (the story’s heroine) not Jewish enough for an Orthodox wedding. As despair ensues, the struggle of a lifetime begins.

Set in the 1940s, this tragicomedy – elevated by an original music score – performed live by Swedish composer Elin Palmer; a lighthearted Charlie Chaplin mime motif; and breathtaking aerial theatrics by former Cirque du Soleil artist Sara Joel, is a rare theatrical feast for the senses for all generations.

Come dress the part; 40s attire suggested.

http://www.soulofabluebutterfly.com

GOALS:

  • To compensate our artists for their hard work and commitment
  • To generate positive/effective media coverage
  • To generate strong patronage for three performance dates
  • To establish our brand and continue building a national and international presence

NEEDS: Our bare bones minimum adds up to $5,000

  • STAGING/TECHNICAL: Lighting, sound, stage management, photography/filmography, venue space, rehearsal space, costumes, sets, and props
  • CAST/CREW: actors/directors/musician(s)/admin salaries; transportation; lodging
  • COLLATERAL/PROMOTION RELATED: programs, flyers, website maintenance, advertising/publicity

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word. Share our campaign information with friends, family, and colleagues.
  • See the performance. June 17, 20 & 22 at the Cabrini Repertory Theater in Washington Heights, NYC. Tickets available via: http://bit.ly/1nZ4CnN / 
  • Advertise in the performance program. Contact publicist Mina Rios at minacomm@outlook.com
  • Buy a tee shirt orCD

                   EVERY BIT HELPS. THANKS IN ADVANCE.

story:
The Dream Continues!

Dear Family, Friends, Fans, Supporters and Believers of Dance City,

In December of 2012, you were with us as Dance City debuted on the Philly CW Network and received tremendous ratings! Since then, we continued to achieve so much to be proud of. The time has now arrived to take our dream and hard work to the next level. Join us as we prepare for a much larger stage with a national audience.  In order to play in the big leagues we will require an established advertising team, state of the art studio, high end equipment, the hottest effects software, and a nest egg capital for miscellaneous production necessities.

Through contributions on Indiegogo, you can help propel us to accommodate these needs. Every donation is truly appreciated and will be personally acknowledged.  From the Hearts of three guys who want to give back to their community and help teens everywhere to investigate their aspirations, we "Thank You".

(Rome, Paul, Chris)

About Dance City TV

Dance City is a dance, lifestyle and reality entertainment show which mentors teenagers focused on pursuing specific career goals. From professional dance to broadcast journalism, the teens are mentored by Dance City’s celebrity “career coaches”; whose advice will guide the teens in overcoming obstacles associated with their vocations of choice. Over a number of episodes, shrouded in a teenage dance party, Dance City chronicles their accomplishments and struggles as they pursue their dreams of becoming successful.

Video of Our Mentorship

The Dance City TV Dancers

Dance City  TV cast members are a whimsical and scintillating group of teens between the ages of 15 – 19, consisting of males and females. The cast members are divided into three groups, studio dancers, guest dancers and premier dancers. The studio dancers are Dance City’s regular background dancers with dance training who specific purpose is to fill the dance floor perform various dances. The guest dancers are teens invited to taping to participate in the dance party. These cast members are considered extras and may or may not have any dance training but will enhance promotional opportunities.

The Dance City TV Premier Dancers are the top ten featured cast members of the show. The premier dancers have backgrounds in dance, a specific career goal and will be featured in segments of the show. The Dance City premier dancers were selected through auditions and the viewers are able to connect to the authentic characters of the teens, career goals and lifestyles.

The Dancers are Talking About Giving Back on an Interview with Dance Mogul Magazine.

Dance City TV CW Philly Promo 2012

story:
BRINGING ALTERNATIVE MUSICAL THEATRE TO SANTA BARBARA.

Out of the Box Theatre Company is a theatre company producing contemporary musical theatre in Santa Barbara, CA. Starting as small as one actor with a desire to self-produce, we've built an organization, collected an Advisory Board of local creative minds, achieved our own non-profit status, and made it through five seasons of fully-staged productions, concerts, and educational workshops -- producing 12 musical productions from Reefer Madness to Andrew Lippa's The Wild Party, all Santa Barbara premieres. We hope to continue developing and evolving in our 2015-2016 season, and need your help in order to take the next step!

    SO WHAT'S THE NEXT STEP?

    We are one of the few community theatre companies to offer a small paid stipend to ALL actors, musicians, and production team members. This can be a challenge when finances are tight, but we believe that everyone's time and hard work is valuable. As we continue to grow and take on larger, more complex shows, we would like to expand our budget to ensure that we can continue to keep paying our performers and also include one Actors' Equity Special Appearance contract per season, which will introduce us to an expanded pool of talent (both local and LA-based).

    OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

    • Find us on Facebook to stay up-to-date on all of our upcoming auditions, performances, and workshops! Liking and sharing our updates helps us reach new audience members... which we love!
    • Please help us get the word out about our project by sharing this page with friends, family, and everyone else you know. Seriously, be that person, and share as often as you can!
    • Last, come see our shows! We're not ready to announce our new season QUITE yet, but information will be on our Facebook and website announcing our next shows this summer. (Color us stoked!)
story_txt:
BRINGING ALTERNATIVE MUSICAL THEATRE TO SANTA BARBARA.
 Out of the Box Theatre Company is a theatre company producing contemporary musical theatre in Santa Barbara, CA. Starting as small as one actor with a desire to self-produce, we've built an organization, collected an Advisory Board of local creative minds, achieved our own non-profit status, and made it through five seasons of fully-staged productions, concerts, and educational workshops -- producing 12 musical productions from Reefer Madness to Andrew Lippa's The Wild Party, all Santa Barbara premieres. We hope to continue developing and evolving in our 2015-2016 season, and need your help in order to take the next step!  SO WHAT'S THE NEXT STEP?
We are one of the few community theatre companies to offer a small paid 
stipend to ALL actors, musicians, and production team members. This can be a challenge when finances are tight, but we believe that everyone's time and hard work is valuable. As we continue to grow and take on larger, more complex shows, we would like to expand our budget to ensure that we can continue to keep paying our performers and also include one Actors' Equity Special Appearance contract per season, which will introduce us to an expanded pool of talent (both local and LA-based). 
  OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
 


Find us on Facebook to stay up-to-date on all of our upcoming auditions, performances, and workshops! Liking and sharing our updates helps us reach new audience members... which we love! 

Please help us get the word out about our project by sharing this page with friends, family, and everyone else you know. Seriously, be that person, and share as often as you can!
Last, come see our shows! We're not ready to announce our new season QUITE yet, but information will be on our Facebook and website announcing our next shows this summer. (Color us stoked!)

story:
What would it be like to live in a city where joy was in the air? A city where citizens were invited to dream on a large scale? What would happen if we had more opportunities to celebrate together and everyday life was imbued with magic and wonder?

You can be a part of creating this magic by supporting Lullaby Moon 2010!

Lullaby Moon 2010 is a free, large-scale, site-specific public performance celebrating the new moon. The spectacular continues the joy and mythology of the 2008-09 series that enchanted thousands of Seattle residents. Lullaby Moon celebrates our precious place in the Milky Way galaxy and the promise inherent in everyone’s dreams.

If you are excited to see the return of Lullaby Moon and would like to support the work, here is your opportunity to give. Any donation, small or large, to Lucia Neare’s Theatrical Wonders may be made here. Your entire donation is tax-deductible and goes directly for support of Lullaby Moon.

story:
FIVE DAY FIRE SALE!

Our last 5 days of campaign are here.  So we want to really see how much money we can raise for our next production!  That's why we have reduced the donation amounts of our two highest Perks (Dragon and The Goat)!

Please have a look at the new affordable donation perks!



We've chosen the title of the play!  Our show title place holder was "Hero Quest," but we knew that wasn't going to cut it.  So from the drawing board we've come up with... "Son of a Dwarf!"  It's fresh, it's fantasy, it's going to be freaking awesome!


WEEKLY TICKET DRAW UPDATE:

This Weeks Winner: Steven Tran

Who are we?

Accidental Humour Co. is an Albertan based Theatre company that has been making great multimedia theatre since they first met at a Dairy Queen in Lethbridge back in 2005. Their goal is to create quality productions that draw audiences that do not typically attend theatre.  Our unique blend of film and stage creates the fast pace action that movie goers are used to, with the human element you can only find in live theatre. Previous hit productions include "For The Love of A Zombie," 2009, "Happy Whackin' Jim McCrackin'" 2010, and "Cowboy: A Cowboy Story" 2011.

Our 2012 project entitled "Hero Quest", thrusts our comedic style into the Fantasy genre.  There will be dwarves, there will be wizards, there will be elves, and there will be Neil LeGrandeur!  Fantasy at its best.  This otherworld production is set to tour Alberta this summer in Edmonton, Calgary, and Lethbridge, with more locations in the works. Updates on additional stops will be posted as booked.

 

Happy Whackin' Jim McCrackin, 2010 and Cowboy: A Cowboy Story, 2011           


Ok... Why do we need your help?

Let's not mince words; our shows cost a lot of money. Marrying both theatre and movies doubles our production costs, not to mention we are always pushing to top ourselves in both style and substance. This self-destructive behaviour results in two things: empty bank accounts, and amazing theatre spectacles!

We want you to help us with the empty bank account problem. In order for our company to continue to grow and make creative, cutting-edge theatre, we need the support of wonderful people like you. We do it for the love and for the joy we get from sharing our work with you.

Every penny we receive from you goes directly into upgrading our equipment and bringing our new production to life. We have a lot of work to do before then, so any help you can offer will go a long way!

 

For the Love of A Zombie, 2009 | Photo by Andrew Suderman         



Well, what are we going to do with that money?

Funding from this campaign will be used towards our next production.  We are asking for $5000.00 which is less than half of what the company has contributed in the past.  Why do we need more money, you ask?  We always want to make a bigger, better, and more entertaining product for you, our audience.  Unfortunately, we cannot afford to make it happen on our own. Here is a breakdown of where all $5000.00 is going.

Projection Screen: $500.00

We are more than doubling the size of our projection screen, to accommodate more elaborate projections, and more stage and film integration.

Projector: $3500.00

We need to upgrade our Projector to match the size of our screen, and ensure the image is bright and clear for audience to see.

Show Props: $1000.00

This includes but is not limited to stage combat grade fantasy weaponry (swords, axes, staffs, knives, shields), and construction of "dummy bodies" to use as stunt doubles, instead of placing our actors in the line of danger (we have been there and done that, and we are running out of actors).


Above and Beyond $5000.00

Any donations above and beyond our goal will also be going toward "Hero Quest," in the form of costumes, sets, promotional media, film locations, venue rentals, touring costs, and most importantly paying the artists!

 
If we are unable to reach our entire goal, the donations we do receive will be going towards projector and screen costs before anything else.  We are grateful for any donations we receive. 

 
Here are some more details on the Perks for your donations!

$10 - Wood Gnome - Pretty much explained to the right, every little bit helps us, and we are very thankful for any contribution people can give.  Your name will appear in the Thank You section of our website, we'll probably yell it from the roof tops to boot.

 

$25 -  Dwarf - You will receive a pin back button, with the Accidental Humour Co. Logo on the front.  Now you can show your support everywhere you go!  You'll also appear in the thank you section of our website.

 

$50 - Human - You have your choice of one previous production's poster.  Choose your favourite poster from "For The Love of A Zombie," "Happy Whackin' Jim McCrackin'," and "Cowboy: A Cowboy Story."  (Tabloid posters are 11" by 17" in size.)  You will also be thanked in our next productions Playbill!  Plus you still get the pin back button and a thank you on our website.

 

$100 - Giant - You will receive all of our previous Production Diaries, which brings you behind the scenes on the creation of our three previous productions.  Plus you still receive your choice of poster, a thank you in our Playbill, and a button.

 

$250 - Half Elf -  By sending us your donation and a small biography of yourself, our company will create a personal ring tone for your cellphone.  You can listen to two of our previous show themes here: Happy Whackin' Jim McCrackin &  Cowboy: A Cowboy Story.  In addition, you will receive a producer credit in our Playbill, a copy of the production diaries, poster of your choice, and a button.

 

$250 - High Elf - If cellphones aren't your thing, you can also donate to receive advertisement space in our next Playbill.  You will receive a quarter page advertisement in which you can promote anything from your business to your pet cat.  We will contact you with more information if needed.  In addition, you will receive a producer credit in our Playbill, a copy of the production diaries, poster of your choice, and a button.

 

$500 - Sorcerer - With this donation you are invited to our film shoot (location to be announced), you will also be cast as an extra in the film portion of our next production.  (transportation not included)  In addition, you will receive a producer credit in our Playbill, a copy of the production diaries, poster of your choice, and a button.

 

$500 -  Wizard - You will receive on half page advert. in our Playbills.  Promote your company, promote our company, promote anything you'd like. In addition, you will receive a producer credit in our Playbill, a copy of the production diaries, poster of your choice, and a button.

 

$1000 - Queen - With this donation you are invited to our film shoot (location to be announced), you will also be cast as an extra with a speaking role in the film portion of our next production. (transportation not included) In addition, you will receive a producer credit in our Playbill, a copy of the production diaries, poster of your choice, and a button.

 

$1000 - King - You will receive on full page advert. in our Playbills. Promote your company, promote our company, promote anything you'd like. In addition, you will receive a producer credit in our Playbill, a copy of the production diaries, poster of your choice, and a button.

 

$1999 - Dragon - See Brent and Will kiss on the lips.  It will be filmed, and you will see it, heck the whole interweb will probably see it.  Brent Felzien has kissed a lot of people.  On the lips.  Willie Banfield has never been one of them.  This will be history in the making.  History you will make happen, whether Will wants it to or not. In addition, you will receive a producer credit in our Playbill, a copy of the production diaries, poster of your choice, and a button.

 

$30 - Goat - The one and only Neil James LeGrandeur will take you out on a date.  Dinner and a movie, and dressed to the nines.  Ladies have been on a waiting list for months to get this chance.  You get to skip the lineup, and enjoy the company that some will only dream of.  In addition, you will receive a poster of your choice, and a button!

 

 

In addition to these great perks, everyone who donates, will be entered into a weekly video draw!  What are the prizes?  Tune in to find out!  Also, because the draws happen weekly, the earlier you donate the more chances you will have to win!


Alright, you donated. What do you do now?

You need to tell everyone!  Tell your neighbours, tell your neighbours dog! Shout it from the mountain tops! Shout it while waiting in line at the Tim Hortons! Even if you get one more person to donate a little, it will make all the difference. Word of mouth is our best friend, and our best chance to make this campaign a success.  We can not do it without you.


And while your at it, stay tuned for news on the show... it's going to be huge!! And we very much want you to see it.


Love,


AccHum

story:
Hi Everyone -

Thanks for visiting our IndieGoGo page! InVersion Theatre is a young theatre company in Philadelphia specializing in producing shows that explore questions of what it means to be human. InVersion is currently raising for our two upcoming shows - MISS JULIE by August Strindberg and our yet unnamed BECKETT/SHEPARD show. And we need your help to reach our goals!

By supporting this project, you will be supporting the following:

1) Space for our shows

2) Stipends for actors, designers, and rehearsal staff

3) Performance rights

4) Technical capacities

All of these things are integral to the success of our project, and we won't be able to support them all without your help!

By helping out this project, you'll not only be helping Will and Johnny with their own goals, you'll be helping create a new home for artists in Philadelphia. We don't want to build a convential new theatre company: we want to build a new home for artists. The more money you donate, the more of an opportunity we'll have to support our actors and designers who do so much for us and don't get as much recognition as they deserve in the beginning stages of their careers. As wev'e shown, we're not afraid to take risks that help develop artistic development - MISS JULIE will be performed in a townhouse in South Philadelphia - and your support will help us take bigger and better risks.

Even if you can't support us financially, the best thing you can do for us is SHARE THIS WITH AS MANY PEOPLE AS YOU KNOW! We can really use the support. Thank you all so much!

 InVersion Theatre is supported by FRACTURED ATLAS. For more information, visit http://www.fracturedatlas.org/.

story:
Our Story

We are two polyamorous trans ladies who are in love and want to party about it with all of our diverse and wonderful families. We want to make sure we can afford to rent an accessible, safe place for our ceremony. Plus, our guests are traveling from all over to join our wonderful, queer chosen family and we want to give them food and shelter when they get here.

We're also working-class grrrls who give a lot to our communities and are broke. Show us some solidarity and mutual aid cause we don't get paid enough for our hard work! :)

For more information about the wedding and what marriage means to us as radical trans feminists, check out http://dianaandsadie.wordpress.com.

The Impact

According to Focus on the Family, for every one gay marriage, three straight people will be automatically converted to homosexuality. One in ten isn't enough, let's make Ronald Reagan cry!

What We Need

We made our "goal" on here $1000, but we really need more like $2000 to make this happen. Here's our total budget:

Two plane tickets from DC to Michigan: 600-700
A shuttle to help our guests travel: 100
The venue: 500
Catering: 800

If you're coming to the wedding, it's like you're helping us feed you!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can help with anything on this list, we would greatly appreciate it:

  • Food/Cakes (to accommodate all people including vegans and those with wheat/gluten allergies and nut allergies. Also Diana loves carrot cake!)
  • Rides for those coming from far away to and from events
  • Places to sleep in west Michigan for those coming from far away
  • Dishes/Silverware
  • Booze/Sparkling cider
  • Juice
  • Music (live, DJ, or whatever)
  • Decorations
  • Photography

story:
Our Story

 

Less than two years ago, Sky Candy started with an 18 foot tall A-frame aerial rig and a dream.  Today, Sky Candy is Austin's most celebrated aerial arts studio and troupe with acknowledgement as Austin's Best Circus Art Revivalists (Austin Chronicle Best of Austin 2011).  We've grown from teaching classes outdoors during an unforgiving Texas summer, with lots of sunblock, bug spray and misters - to filling our very own 2400 square foot studio complete with climate control!  However, when we want to take our show on the road, we are still relegated to our old friend - the A-frame rig.

Extending 25 feet into the air, Aeria is a wholly unique and elegant aerial rig, constructed by the immensely talented Rich Martin, founder of Opulent Temple at Burning Man, now doing his own design work as Fury Six Design.  The structure would allow Sky Candy to perform more outdoor performances on a structurally sound, artistically aspirational work. 

The Impact

With this new aerial rig, Sky Candy will be able to perform in a wider variety of outdoor and indoor venues that do not have sufficiently safe rigging options.  Our current rig has served us well, but can only be used on soft, even ground outside.  Having Aeria would mean more performances in more places!  Furthermore, Aeria is considerably taller than Sky Candy's current rig, allowing us to perform a greater range of dynamic tricks and drops, particularly on the silks and corde lisse/rope.  Additionally, Aeria will become a key fixture of Burning Flipside and Spin Camp for years to come.


What We Need & What You Get

Rich Martin is generously building this structure with none of the funds raised going directly to him.  The vast majority of the expense of Aeria comes from the steel needed to construct this 25' tall beauty and the transportation of the rig from San Francisco to Austin in late May.  Aeria will make its debut at Burning Flipside and then afterwards will live with Sky Candy and be used for outdoor gigs around Austin and beyond!


Estimated Steel Costs: $2500

Estimated Expendable Materials Cost: $500

Estimated Transportation* Cost: $1000

* Transportation Costs include one way truck rental and fuel.


In exchange for your generous donation to this project, both Sky Candy and Rich Martin are offering a variety of sweet prizes, including classes with Sky Candy, beautiful unique metalwork fro Fury Six Design, and much more.  Check out our prize levels for details.


If we exceed our goal for this project, additional funds will go towards offsetting the cost of safety equipment (currently, Sky Candy will be providing a brand new crash mat for the rig), lighting and sound equipment for the rig.


Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word about this project!  Send out the link to this fundraiser to folks you know who would like to support Sky Candy and the further spread of the aerial arts in Central Texas.  Also, if you have a hook up for a more affordable transportation solution from San Francisco to Austin, let us know!
story_txt:
Our Story
 
Less than two years ago, Sky Candy started with an 18 foot tall A-frame aerial rig and a dream.  Today, Sky Candy is Austin's most celebrated aerial arts studio and troupe with acknowledgement as Austin's Best Circus Art Revivalists (Austin Chronicle Best of Austin 2011).  We've grown from teaching classes outdoors during an unforgiving Texas summer, with lots of sunblock, bug spray and misters - to filling our very own 2400 square foot studio complete with climate control!  However, when we want to take our show on the road, we are still relegated to our old friend - the A-frame rig.

Extending 25 feet into the air, Aeria is a wholly unique and elegant aerial rig, constructed by the immensely talented Rich Martin, founder of Opulent Temple at Burning Man, now doing his own design work as Fury Six Design.  The structure would allow Sky Candy to perform more outdoor performances on a structurally sound, artistically aspirational work. 



The Impact
With this new aerial rig, Sky Candy will be able to perform in a wider variety of outdoor and indoor venues that do not have sufficiently safe rigging options.  Our current rig has served us well, but can only be used on soft, even ground outside.  Having Aeria would mean more performances in more places!  Furthermore, Aeria is considerably taller than Sky Candy's current rig, allowing us to perform a greater range of dynamic tricks and drops, particularly on the silks and corde lisse/rope.  Additionally, Aeria will become a key fixture of Burning Flipside and Spin Camp for years to come.



What We Need & What You Get
Rich Martin is generously building this structure with none of the funds raised going directly to him.  The vast majority of the expense of Aeria comes from the steel needed to construct this 25' tall beauty and the transportation of the rig from San Francisco to Austin in late May.  Aeria will make its debut at Burning Flipside and then afterwards will live with Sky Candy and be used for outdoor gigs around Austin and beyond!

Estimated Steel Costs: $2500
Estimated Expendable Materials Cost: $500
Estimated Transportation* Cost: $1000* Transportation Costs include one way truck rental and fuel.

In exchange for your generous donation to this project, both Sky Candy and Rich Martin are offering a variety of sweet prizes, including classes with Sky Candy, beautiful unique metalwork fro Fury Six Design, and much more.  Check out our prize levels for details.

If we exceed our goal for this project, additional funds will go towards offsetting the cost of safety equipment (currently, Sky Candy will be providing a brand new crash mat for the rig), lighting and sound equipment for the rig.



Other Ways You Can Help
Help us spread the word about this project!  Send out the link to this fundraiser to folks you know who would like to support Sky Candy and the further spread of the aerial arts in Central Texas.  Also, if you have a hook up for a more affordable transportation solution from San Francisco to Austin, let us know!

story:
Hey everyone!

I am a dance team member raising funds to go to NDA Competition in April, with the Bryant University Dance Team. Being a college student means that personal funds are limited. 

Any amount will help, even a $1! It will be a huge help and will be very appreciated. 

Stephanie Paradis

story:
UPDATE*: We are starting Ticket Tuesdays and Ticket Thursdays! Any perks claimed on Tuesdays and Thursdays come with a ticket to the show!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We are the Drexel Players!

As the university's only undergraduate theatre student organization, The Drexel Players apply foundations in art, science, and industry to engage students in the creation of fresh and thrilling ensemble work. Drawing from a core of artists and collaborators with interdisciplinary backgrounds, we strive to empower student theatre artists, to stimulate audiences, and to ignite a passion for theatre in all.

And we are RETURNING to the Philadelphia Fringe Festival...

Last year we united against the hole in the sky in MONUMENT.

This year we are pulling together again as a community of student artists of all backgrounds and disciplines to devise another original piece for the 2013 Philadelphia Fringe Festival.

Our show is entitled "Parts: A Speed-Through"...

"It's Hell Week. You suffer rivals, make friends, and make believe. It happens, it ends, and you leave. The Drexel Players invite you to belong, just for a moment, and experience an interactive orignal work about the parts we play, the parts we hide, and the parts we can never forget."

The piece is a theatrical "undressing" about the unique, beautiful, and tragic relationships young artists share with each other and will be loosely based on the stories, rituals, and experiences of the Drexel Players. We are in the process of devising and writing it as an ensemble currently.

And we are half-way there!

So far we have secured our registration fee, a venue for the event (The URBN Annex Black Box Theatre in University City), our insurance fee, and a modest budget for artist fees.

Here's what we need...

  • $500 - Food Items: Our show will incorporate food and drink very purposefully as a part of our story telling. Certain consumables will be shared with the audience and will be crucial to key moments of our piece. We will need to purchase enough for rehearsals and performances.
  • $500 - Scenery/Props: Our piece will make use of our space by creating different enviornoments for our audience to experience and live in and tangible items for our actors and audiences to manipulate. We will therefore need money to purchase or rent pieces for set dressing and props.
  • $400 - Lights/Sound Equipment: Since our piece will have little to no set pieces, we will be relying on our designers to create a highly theatrical environment through lights, sound, and music. We will need this money for rentals and transportation.
  • $200 - Costumes: Our show will also make use of costuming as an important story telling device. We will need to purchase or rent costume pieces to transform our actors.
  • $200- Incidentals: This will be our petty cash fund for things like making copies of scripts, doing laundry, and other costs of day-to-day operations. 
  • $200- Contingency: We will need a contingency fund to cover ourselves incase an unseen expenditure is needed that we didn't budget for. 

Here's how you can help...

Please contribute to our campaign. We urge you to take advantage of our perks! We will be able to use whatever contributions we receive toward some aspect of our production so no contribution is too small!

If you are not able to support us financially now, we would appreciate your verbal and or social networking support by sharing our campaign with others on Facebook, Twitter, E-Mail, and other creative avenues.

Thank you!

-Drexel Fringe

Parts: A Speed Through

Sept 6 + 13 at 8pm
Sept 7 + 14 at 6pm
Sept 8 at 2pm

The URBN Center Annex is located at 3401 Filbert Street near the 34th Street stop. Tickets will be available online through TicketLeap by mid-July.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, you wonderful Indiegogo supporters.  We are in the midst of creating a brand new musical revue about the fair city called Los Angeles – the title of our show is L.A. Now and Then – a celebratory and contrasting look at the city that was and the city that is.  The show is conceived and directed by Bruce Kimmel, who has also written some songs and sketches.  Additional great collaborators include Richard M. Sherman (of the Sherman Brothers), Bruce Vilanch, Paul Gordon, Michele Brourman, Shelly Markham, Adryan Russ, Doug Haverty, Lissa Levin, Gary Stockdale and others.  The production will take place at Los Angeles City College, where author Kimmel attended (as did contributors Paul Gordon and Gary Stockdale). 

We are very excited about this show and its potential as a perennial valentine to L.A.  If you loved things past you’ll hear about them here – the show will be funny, touching, illuminating, and covers the 1940s up through now.  The songs are tuneful and wonderful, and the monologues, scenes, and sketches will take you on a journey through the most amazing one-off city in the world.  From the opening number (“This Is the City”) to the paean to the much-missed C.C. Brown’s, to a kaleidoscopic portrait of the Sunset Strip circa 1965 to 1968, to the Golden Age of Los Angeles wrestling, to a history of the gay scene from its hidden beginnings to its proud coming out and beyond, to the infamous Black Dahlia, to the artistic haven that was Laurel Canyon in the 60s and 70s, to the more current scene, if you love L.A. you will love L.A. Now and Then.  Our endgame for this show is to get the city involved in funding a sit-down production.

What We Need & What You Get

The purpose for doing the Indiegogo campaign is simple: Community colleges, especially in the arts, are having hard times, with barely enough budget allocations to produce a normal season of theater.  Los Angeles City College has been one of the foremost theater arts departments in the nation for over eight decades, with such stellar alumni as Donna Reed, Alexis Smith, Robert Vaughn, James Coburn, Cindy Williams, Diana Canova, Debbie Gravitte, Mark Hamill, Clint Eastwood, Morgan Freeman, Paul Winfield, Michael Lembeck, and many, many other show business notables.  Because musicals, especially new musicals, are expensive to produce we are trying to raise $12,500 (the bare minimum we need - more would even be more helpful), which will pay for the band and the sound package we’ll need.  The department simply has no budget for that kind of thing anymore.  So, we need your help!

We have devised a set of perks that we hope will make contributing fun and easy.  While the department can’t really give away tickets for this campaign (they live and breathe by box-office sales), we’ve come up with some perks that will hopefully appeal to you, that cover every budget range.  Please check them out – they’re over there on the right.  There’s everything from a season pass to the LACC shows (which are really good), to CD packages from Kritzerland, to receiving the cast album we’ll be recording, to being an associate or full above-the-title producer, to thank yous in the program, to sheet music from the show, to a signed musical quote by Richard M. Sherman (song of your choice), to a head shot photography session, coaching sessions, and for those with cash to spare you can have a wonderful dinner with the legendary Richard M. Sherman and Bruce Kimmel at a great restaurant.   

The Impact

This show has the potential to become a long-running LA tourist event, something that out-of-towners can see when visiting, as well as the millions of Angelinos who live here, who love the melting pot that is this city.  The band is a hugely important part of the show, as is the sound package rental, something the theater department simply doesn’t have.  The show is also important to the college – an original musical with some amazing writers, performed by an all-student company.  It will also be eligible for the American College Theater Festival.

Risks & Challenges

Doing a new musical is always a risk and a challenge, but the team behind this musical has had many huge successes over the years, both here and elsewhere.  The biggest challenge is overcoming the budgetary restraints of community college arts programs, which is, at this point in time, shamefully low.  That is where we need your help so very badly.  Whatever perk you choose, the money will help us do this production the right way.  The students will have a once-in-a-lifetime experience of working on the creation of a brand new musical.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand how many of these campaigns there are and how many are asking for your dollars.  Again, we’ve tried to make the perks make sense – so you’re actually getting some stuff that doesn’t have to come out of the LACC budgets – things like the coaching sessions and the headshot photography are being donated by people who believe in this project.   If you find yourself unable to donate, you can still help by spreading the word on Facebook, Twitter and other social media, especially to the L.A.-centric Facebook groups, of which there are many.

story:
Censored from the public eye in its first publication, Tess of the D'Urbervilles has wrung the hearts of millions for over a century. I first read this book while en route from Boston, MA to Stockholm, Sweden and then on to Malmo and Copenhagen, Denmark. As breath-taking as the journey was I could not put this novel down. I am almost ashamed to admit that instead of looking at the beauty of the landscape, I had my nose buried in print. Tess' plight, the irrevocable tragedy of her circumstance, and the desperate need to be good when living in a deceptive world, grappled me further into her tragic end. Tess of the D'Urbervilles has remained my favorite novel since. I share this love with my fellow creators, Harlan Baker (Director)and Mark Honan (Producer), as well as myself, (April Singley).
Bringing Tess to the stage is an arduous task of love, stubbornness, and some audacity. Ridden by the themes of love, lust, revenge, and hate, Tess stands out as a work of art that is both timeless and courageous.

story:
Summary

      My name is Skye Van Rensselaer. My passion for theater was born here on St. Thomas at the Pistarckle Theater. When I was 8 years old, I participated in their first summer camp and played Peaseblossom in A Midsummer Night’s Dream. For the last four years, I have been extremely fortunate to attend Skidmore College in upstate New York, and in May 2013 I graduated Magna Cum Laude with a Bachelor of Science, and Honors in Theater Arts. My dream is to start my own theater company, with a focus on creating new and innovative theater. In addition to the training I received in all areas of Theater Arts in the Skidmore Theater department, I was selected for a theater program in my junior year at the Moscow Art Theater in Russia. This was a life changing experience that truly engaged me in a performance model that pushed me intellectually, physically and emotionally in ways I could not have imagined.

What We Need & What You Get & The Impact

     I received the news a few days ago, that I have been invited to attend a nine month intensive acting conservatory program with one of my favorite theater companies, SITI Company, which will start this fall in New York City. Twenty actors, of all ages, from all over the world have been selected for this inaugural conservatory program and I feel very honored and humbled to be among the group. Never in my life have I been exposed to such a fantastic group of theater artists. They are driven, hard working, intellectual, and challenging. I had the opportunity to train with them last summer, and, once again, I was pushed way beyond my bounds - body, mind, and spirit. Their training, a combination of Suzuki and Viewpoints, unlocks something powerful inside of me. It ignites my passion. It is constantly challenging me without a second to rest in it: testing my determination and will, and strengthening all parts of my ‘performing’ self. I know that attending the training program in the fall is 100% the next step I need to take in my professional theatrical training. It is going to provide me with tools, skills, ideas, and opportunities that I wouldn’t be able to get anywhere else and it will provide me with a great foundation to make my dream of creating my own theater company a reality.

      Like many things in this world, it comes with a fairly high cost with not a lot of time to pay it. I have $12,000 dollars left to pay towards my tuition by August 15th.  While I am working two jobs this summer to make and save as much as possible, it is not going to be anywhere near $12,000. Once the program starts, it will be intensive, but I will be working at least one or two nights a week to help pay my living expenses in the City. I am reaching out to as many people in my community for thoughts, ideas, grants, loans; anything to help make this opportunity a reality. I am a hard working, passionate, and determined individual and I am eternally grateful to my Virgin Islands community where I was born and raised, which has helped mould and develop the values I hold today. Once I have acquired the tools I need, I plan to create a way to share what I have learned with young people here at home. Theater helped save my life and I want to provide others with the same opportunity.

    I truly appreciate you taking the time and care to read this. Please let me know if you are interested in working with me to help me make this happen. I am open to all creative financing ideas. SITI Company is a non-profit 501C3 classified organization. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any creative ideas and suggestions for fundraising or part time job opportunities I can take on while I am in New York City. Any information would be extremely helpful. Thank you so much.

story:
The story

We are Inspiracion Dance Chicago, a twelve-member Latin dance company from diverse backgrounds that performs new, exciting choreography in Chicago and offers free/subsidized community education to high school, college, and adult teams. As a 501(c)3 non-profit organization, our goal is to make Latin dance accessible and available to our community. Our next project is to increase our visibility and augment our training by traveling to train and perform at the 2013 Canada Salsa Congress in Toronto!

By October 14, we need to raise about $500 each to cover the cost of registration, costumes, gas, hotel, and food. So in addition to other fundraising activities, we are turning to YOU- our friends and family- for support to raise a portion of these funds. Our goal for this campaign is just $720, which would provide an $80 travel stipend to each of the nine members attending. (Any further funds raised will cover even more of the travel cost.) In exchange, we offer our heartfelt thanks and a video of the performance in Toronto. Your contribution will help us step up our game, and further, contribute to the vital work of offering community dance education in Chicago. What's more, your contribution to us is tax-deductible. Thank you!

The Impact

We provide low-cost training to our adult team, and free training to our college and high school teams-- training that would cost thousands of dollars per year through regular studios! When we do professional development at conferences like the one in Toronto, we gain new insights that we pass along to each of our teams, disseminating dance technique and knowledge to those who would otherwise not have access to it-- while providing a positive environment for youth to grow through dance.

Please help us advance our team's impact by sending us to Toronto for the 2013 Canada Salsa Congress!

To learn more, visit our website, www.inspiraciondancechi.org

In exchange, we offer our heartfelt thanks and a video of the performance in Toronto. Your contribution will help us step up our game, and further, contribute to the vital work of offering community dance education in Chicago. What's more, your contribution to us is tax-deductible. Thank you!



The Impact
We provide low-cost training to our adult team, and free training to our college and high school teams-- training that would cost thousands of dollars per year through regular studios! When we do professional development at conferences like the one in Toronto, we gain new insights that we pass along to each of our teams, disseminating dance technique and knowledge to those who would otherwise not have access to it-- while providing a positive environment for youth to grow through dance.
Please help us advance our team's impact by sending us to Toronto for the 2013 Canada Salsa Congress!
To learn more, visit our website, www.inspiraciondancechi.org

story:
Short Summary

Following our sold out reading at Dixon Place this past January, we are currently developing our play, Bad Egg, as Artists-in-Residence at The Tank NYC. The Tank has granted us meeting, rehearsal, and performance space so that we can develop the script. Our Winter development period will culminate in a Works in Progress showing on April 27, 2019 @ 3:00, which we are raising funds to support.

About  Us: 

Michelle Tailor is an Artist-in-Residence at The Tank NYC. She received her MFA in Acting from the University of Florida and teaches theatre at the Borough of Manhattan Community College in New York. Michelle’s artistic and academic focus has been on feminist performance practices, including a guest artist lecture on "Performing Feminism: Gestus and Top Girls by Caryl Churchill" at Franklin and Marshall College in the department of Women’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies. Michelle’s fiction writing can be seen in The Windsor Review. She is a company member of The Hippodrome Theatre. SAG-AFTRA/AEA. 

Megan Pinto is an Artist-in-Residence at The Tank NYC. She is also a Playmakers Playwright and Resident Artist at the Purple Rose Theatre Company, where she wrote and developed Winter in Eden, which was seen at Dixon Place this past Spring. She received her MFA in Poetry from Warren Wilson, and her poems are forthcoming in Ploughshares, Four Way Review, and Indiana Review. 

What We Need 

We aim to raise $2,600. This money will support costs for:

  • 10 Actors
  • Lighting Designer 
  • Movement Choreographer
  • Fight Choreographer
  • Stage Manager
  • Props
  • Costumes
  • Poster Creation

The Impact

One of our main goals is to create a rule-breaking re-telling of Shakespeare’s Hamlet that provides women actors the opportunity to portray dynamic, challenging characters in a contemporary text. The play speaks to current topics of disrupting gender roles, the psychological toll of ongoing war, and the catastrophic consequences of greed and revenge. Our riff on Shakespeare’s Hamlet includes more than just re-gendering the roles: it involves inventing a world in which it is the norm for women to hold power, to externalize forces of power and to drive the action. As theatre artists, we recognize the immense gift Shakespeare left us with his body of work—the complexity of feeling and thought, the precision of language, the beauty of imagery—we hold this dear to our hearts. And yet, we need a new Hamlet, a female Hamlet. 

This play is in part a response to canonical feminist theatre theory—such as that by Sue Ellen Case, who asks us to “read against the text” when analyzing the lack of representation of women in classical Greek theatre and Shakespeare. If we as female theatre practitioners find our reflections lacking in these classical works, then in response to Case, indeed to our fellow theatre-makers, is how do we act against the text? How do we create opportunities for women and men that ring truer to the ideals of equality we’d like to experience in and outside the theatre – both for other theatre-makers and the audience? First, we do that by changing the conceptual narrative.  

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share our campaign!
  • See our Works in Progress Showing! April 27th @ 3:00, The Tank NYC
  • Follow us on Instagram @cyclopstheatre or like us on Facebook

Thank you for your support.

Warmest,

Megan and Michelle
