story:
Our Story

Rachel Klein Productions, an NYC-based company of theatrical dance, movement, and visual storytelling, has been generating original work since 2007. Rachel Klein Productions has produced several full-length plays (both movement and text based) including Metro, Sir Sheever, Aenigma, and Go-Go Killers! and co-produced Hound, All Kinds of Shifty Villains, and Stage Blood is Never Enough. The Rachel Klein Theater Dancers have been presented all over the city in different festivals, art gallery openings, nightlife events and venues including the Kitchen, Theater for the New City, the House of Yes, Night of 1,000 Stevies, the Highline Ballroom, La MaMa Moves! at La MaMa E.T.C. in 2009 and 2010, Dixon Place, the premier of Banzai!  at the Red Lotus Room, Low Life @ HOWL Festival, (le) Poisson Rouge, Sticky with BlueBox productions, legendary rock n roll venue Don Hill's, the Hiro Ballroom, the Bushwick Site Fest at 3rd Ward,  the Bushwick Open Studios Festival, the World Famous Bob’s Give Thanks!, Galapagos Art Space in DUMBO, the NY Downtown Clown Review, and Off-Broadway at the Bleecker Street Theater (45 Bleecker, Main Theater). Upcoming RKP projects include A Midsummer Night's Dream with CoLab Theater Company in New Brunswick. NJ, and a commercial Off-Broadway production of Gay Bride of Frankenstein coming this fall. Rachel Klein Productions was the recipient of a 2010 Emerging Artists Grant from the Field in association with the Tides Foundation, curates a monthly performance art review at Bowery Poetry Club, will be featured at the prestigious DUMBO Dance Festival this fall, and has received a dance commission for Dixon Place's 2012 season.


The Impact

RKP has been devising the Tragedy of Maria Macabre since January 2010 upon receiving an Emerging Artists rehearsal space grant from the Field in association with the Tides Foundation. RKP has continued the development of this piece further after the end of the residency, performing workshop presentations of The Tragedy of Maria Macabre including the Field’s program at the Kitchen in March 2010 (13 minutes of the work), La MaMa Moves! in June 2010 (13 minutes), at the Bushwick Site Festival at 3rd Ward in association with Armory Art Week.


In the summer of 2010, Rachel Klein and filmmaker Sean Gill made the (then) existing excerpts of The Tragedy of Maria Macabre into a 22-minute short film. 


On March 2nd, 2011, The Tragedy of Maria Macabre performed its first full length presentation at Dixon Place in NYC to a sold out audience and tremendous acclaim. Macabre then delivered two full length encore performances at the Access Theater in Tribeca, and further excerpts were presented at the House of Yes in their circus variety show, the Lower Manhattan Arts League's Spring Downtown Gala (in association with SoHo Rep and HERE Arts Center) and most recently at the Lower East Side Arts Festival at Theater for the New City.


The Tragedy of Maria Macabre stars the talents of Elizabeth Stewart, Michael Porsche, Abigail Hawk, Danielle Maria Fusco, Eric Schmalenberger, Megan O’Connor, Preston Burger, Freddy Mancilla, and Brian Rubiano. Production design by Rachel Klein, sound design by Sean Gill, makeup design by Anita Rundles, and stage managed by RKP's Marina Steinberg.


The Tragedy of Maria Macabre will finally perform a long awaited full run in October of 2011 at the Wild Project in NYC's East Village.  The performances will be every Thursday, Friday, Saturday, and Sunday from October 20th through October 30th, 2011.


Without support and resources, the project will be unable to continue moving forward!


Audience Quotes from the March 2011 Production at Dixon Place:


“Rachel Klein is an original. Her work is immediately recognizable. She has created her own aesthetic, and physical language. Her work is bold, original, bizarre, amusing, provocative. I invite you into her world: if you dare!”

             -- Bill Connington writer/performer, ZOMBIE. zombiethefilm.com  zombietheplay.com

 

 

"The Tragedy of Maria Macabre was a delightful romp through a Gothic inspired death and rebirth of Maria Macabre! Presenting a darkly choreographed and costumed piece is never easy...Rachel Klein & Co. have accomplished the balance of humor and tragedy through their marvelous efforts and great talents.”

            --Lee Chappell, Nightlife Impresario, “Café Panache,” “Foreign Affairs”

 

“I'm a huge fan of Rachel Klein's work! The shows are always outrageous, fun and crazy creative!”

            --Sherry Vine, Legendary Actor, Drag Performer, and Artistic Director of Theater Couture


What We Need & What You Get

RKP has been fortunate enough to gain so much acclaim over the past couple of years, and are excited to embrace the upcoming performance opportunities of 2011. In order to accomplish our goal, we need to raise $5,000 by October 26th, 2011. The funding would be broken down as follows to fulfill several professional requirements: $400 for rehearsal space, $400 for professional costume construction, and $1200 towards PR/Publicity. $3,000 for performance space.

Rehearsal space is an invaluable resource that has become very difficult to afford. As for costuming, several of the costumes for The Tragedy of Maria Macabre have already been constructed, but there are four dancers that are without proper detailing and wigs that would make the ensemble look cohesive. And lastly, the most helpful way to move forward with the project is to have proper publicity to get the word out.


You will be helping an emerging theater company fully realize an ensemble production that has been in development for nearly two years! All donors will be mentioned in the playbill for the production, as well as receive complimentary tickets to the show.


Other Ways You Can Help


Please spread the word! Thank you so much for your support!

story:
What is this Mishegas?

In A Modest Suggestion, four businessmen meet in an anonymous conference room over a pad of paper and a box of donuts to discuss the next item on their agenda: whether the world is a better place with or without the Jews.

Comedy ensues.

As the four yes-men weigh the pros and cons (and interview a couple of mensches along the way), A Modest Suggestion brings up some pretty tough questions: why do racism and anti-Semitism exist? what does it mean to be Jewish? how does racism turn into violence? and do Jews eat bacon?

Apple Core Theater Company is thrilled to produce this daring, new satire by Israeli-American playwright, Ken Kaissar, at the Studio Theatre at Theatre Row in midtown Manhattan, May 10-27, 2012. In producing this unique work, we seek to inspire an honest, thought-provoking discussion around these complicated, often forgotten topics. Oh, and to make you laugh.


Our Schtick

Apple Core Theater Company produces emotional, entertaining plays by American writers.  Valuing the immediacy and intimacy of theater, we strive to present plays that cut down to the core and go straight to the heart.  Believing that theater should be accessible to all people, we are committed to providing affordable theater to New York City. For more information on our schtick, visit us at  www.applecoretheatercompany.org.


The Spiel 

If we wanna shlep this play to Theatre Row, we're gonna need some cash -- in fact, we're gonna need about $3,000. Oy! And that, my bubbala, is where you can make all the difference.

** You think the set is going to build itself? Your donation will help pay for everything that goes on the stage, from the office chairs and neck ties to the blindfolds and jars of herring.

** We don't want our actors, designers, and production team to feel like they're chopped liver. Your gift will allow us to -- get this -- pay our actors and production team! (Not much, but better than bupkis.)

** As affordability and accessibility are primary components of our mission, your support will also keep our ticket price at a remarkable $15. You can't beat that in NYC.

** And of course, you'll make a lot of working theater artists who are passionate about this project very, very happy.

Can't contribute now?  You can still help make A Modest Suggestion possible: 

** Help us fundraise by sharing this link with your family and friends! Feel free to consider Facebook, Twitter, email, smoke signals and semaphore.

** Are you a baker? A business owner? Can you provide us with donuts or office chairs (or many other items) through an in-kind sponsorship? Contact allison@applecoretheatercompany.org for more information.

** We always need friends to get the word out about the shows. Tell them to like us on Facebook (and in real life), to follow us on Twitter, to read our blog, and to sign up for our mailing list at www.applecoretheatercompany.org.

** Or maybe you want to see the show? Well, we want to see you too. Remember: tickets are only $15. At the beginning of April, you can find us on www.telecharge.com.

Thank you -- really, thank you for all your support. And when May comes around, don't be a stranger, eh? We'll see you at Theatre Row, May 10-27.

story:
Short Summary

We are Amber Marshall (an accomplished actress, a theater major, and the Director of this show) and Leora Burnett (a somewhat less accomplished actress, a theater nerd, and the person trying to pull all the details of this together). 

The two of us share the ideal that anyone, no matter what they look like, what size they are, color, or height, or gender, should be allowed to get a chance at leading or important roles. We are trying to create a standard in refusing to type-cast, as we know so many obscenely talented people that rarely get considered for lead parts based on the "terrible toos" (too fat, too ugly, too tall, too short, etc).

It is our intention to buy the rights to put on Legally Blonde, The Musical in Boulder. Eight shows at the end of July/first weekend of August as our VERY FIRST PRODUCTION! We intend to bust our backsides to make this a reality, to show the theater community at large that talent is more important than appearance in putting on a worthwhile production.

Who we are, a little more in-depth

We are the co-founders of Blind Eye Theatre Company, a pending non-profit theater company formed with a very simple mission statement: It is our goal to re-create the standard for theater by utilizing type blind casting to emphasize the importance of talent over type, which allows us to showcase the talents of all performers regardless of type, race or gender whenever possible while still remaining true to the story and characters. Blind Eye Theatre is not just “doing” theater, we are changing it, improving it, and making the idea of theater more community-friendly, one performance at a time.

Basically, Amber and I have both experienced being typecast, or not cast at all, because of appearance. We know several others who've had the same problem. We have been told that it's a very small problem, but we feel differently, and we intend to cast every show we ever do based specifically on talent and personality unless the character role specifically requires a certain type of person (like Tracy from Hairspray, for example). 

Together, we're slowly forming a very excellent and reliable team of people to help us put this on. Several members of the community are excited about our mission statement, and have agreed to help us. We've already secured theater space in Boulder and a rehearsal/audition space. The next step is to earn the money to afford the rights and the pieces we need to put on the show. 

What We Need & What You Get

The rights for this show cost an estimated $2,500 (or more, we're waiting for the exact quote) all by themselves. That gets us the legal right to put on the show as it is scripted, which is something we really want to do. The rest of the money we're asking for will go toward renting a venue, paying a good musical director and choreographer to help us prepare, lighting, set pieces, costume pieces, paint, props and so on. If we go above our goal (which we very much hope to do!), that just means we can put on an even more amazing and accurate show.

Our goal is to do the best version of this production that we possibly can! There are many amazing rewards for you, as well, if you decide to help us, some of which include vouchers for tickets to the show, company related goodies, the chance to be recognized in our show program and much, much more!

If we make enough, we can create an amazing production and maybe even have enough to beginning planning for a second show!

The Impact

Your contribution, even if it's small, can help us in so many ways. Every dollar that gets donated is one step closer to making this a reality. It's important to us to see that there are other people out there who understand how it feels to be different and be forced out of the spotlight as a result. We want to give the already rich theater community here in Denver something to look at that they've never seen before. 

Neither Amber nor I are your typical vision of stage perfection, but we both work really hard to be good at what we do, and we want other people like us to have a chance to shine. It is our hope to not just do our thing, but also change the way the theater community sees theater as a whole. We want to rekindle the ideal that theater is about talent and not just appearance. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to donate, please spread the word! Pass this along to theater companies you know of in your area, theater friends, or people who might understand our cause. It is so important to us to make this happen.

You can also attend our fundraising gala on March 21st! More information for that can be found on our Facebook page, so like us to get notifications! :) 

https://www.facebook.com/BlindEyeTheatre

Thank you for looking, and talking about us to your connections. We hope you get to come and see the show!

~Amber and Leora

We have been told that it's a very small problem, but we feel differently, and we intend to cast every show we ever do based specifically on talent and personality unless the character role specifically requires a certain type of person (like Tracy from Hairspray, for example). Together, we're slowly forming a very excellent and reliable team of people to help us put this on. Several members of the community are excited about our mission statement, and have agreed to help us. We've already secured theater space in Boulder and a rehearsal/audition space. The next step is to earn the money to afford the rights and the pieces we need to put on the show. What We Need & What You GetThe rights for this show cost an estimated $2,500 (or more, we're waiting for the exact quote) all by themselves. That gets us the legal right to put on the show as it is scripted, which is something we really want to do. The rest of the money we're asking for will go toward renting a venue, paying a good musical director and choreographer to help us prepare, lighting, set pieces, costume pieces, paint, props and so on. If we go above our goal (which we very much hope to do!), that just means we can put on an even more amazing and accurate show.Our goal is to do the best version of this production that we possibly can! There are many amazing rewards for you, as well, if you decide to help us, some of which include vouchers for tickets to the show, company related goodies, the chance to be recognized in our show program and much, much more!If we make enough, we can create an amazing production and maybe even have enough to beginning planning for a second show!The ImpactYour contribution, even if it's small, can help us in so many ways. Every dollar that gets donated is one step closer to making this a reality. It's important to us to see that there are other people out there who understand how it feels to be different and be forced out of the spotlight as a result. We want to give the already rich theater community here in Denver something to look at that they've never seen before. Neither Amber nor I are your typical vision of stage perfection, but we both work really hard to be good at what we do, and we want other people like us to have a chance to shine. It is our hope to not just do our thing, but also change the way the theater community sees theater as a whole. We want to rekindle the ideal that theater is about talent and not just appearance. Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't afford to donate, please spread the word! Pass this along to theater companies you know of in your area, theater friends, or people who might understand our cause. It is so important to us to make this happen.You can also attend our fundraising gala on March 21st! More information for that can be found on our Facebook page, so like us to get notifications! :) https://www.facebook.com/BlindEyeTheatreThank you for looking, and talking about us to your connections. We hope you get to come and see the show!~Amber and Leora

story:
Go Play Producing Presents

Othello


Go Play Producing presents, a thrilling production of Othello – the classic story of manipulation, power and jealousy seen through a new lense: all the males are played by women and all the females are played by men. This retelling aims to challenge our expectations of gender roles and inform our perception of relationships and societal norms. The classical text allows us to live in a heightened emotional reality while breaking through assumptions and examining how we connect, fight and love in a new perspective. 

Director Tanya Rintoul connects the actors to their characters motivations physically and viscerally in order to find the heart of the story and dives deep into the classical text to answer: what happens in a world where women hold the power? 

The Impact

This Fall, we decided to embark on a journey. Since then, we have collected an amazing group of talented actors and artists that is bringing the world to life. We have felt overwhelmed with the amount of insight, dedication and support we have received so far. However, we need a little more help to keep us going. 

Our Campaign helps support the work we have been doing for the past month. From rental fees to production costs, the campaign's impact will go towards covering those costs. The more money we raise, more costs covered.

Costs Covered:

  • Venue Rental 
  • Lights and Sound Rental 
  • Production Costs: Repairs to Set 
  • Specific Costume Pieces 
  • Printing Costs: Media, Programs etc

In addition to the perks to your right, every person that donates to the campaign will get a special thank you on the Go Play website. Thank you for taking the time to read and support the project. Any donation is appreciated - We couldn't do it without you.  


Othello

Directed by Tanya Rintoul

Join us as for this experimental theatrical experience and see what happens when we rewrite the rules.

November 20th- 23rd at 8pm - November 23rd &  24th at 2pm

LOCATED AT: ZUKE STUDIOS 

1581 Dupont St. Toronto, Ontario

$15 GENERAL ADMISSION . $10 STUDENTS AND ARTISTS

story:
Belly Dance Evolution

Hello, my name is Michael Turkic from interCulture management, and along with Jrisi Jusakos, we aim to bring BELLYDANCE EVOLUTION to Australia in March 2014. Devised by the world's most recognised Belly Dance exponent, Jillina, BELLYDANCE EVOLUTION combines the ancient dance styles of the Middle East, with contemporary theatre design and production.

Of our $16,000 budget we need:

*   $5000 for marketing, web and print advertising including:

*   Newspaper adverts in Middle East press, and

*   TV Placement

*   Web Advertising

Why do we need this?

Because this troupe is sourced from LOS ANGELES and we have funding in place for travel and accommodation.

The Good Stuff

There is very little culturally specific entertainment in Australia for those of Middle Eastern heritage. Australia has a vibrant and active community drawn mostly from Lebanon, Iraq, Iran, and other Middle Eastern countries, mainly centred around Western Sydney. BELLYDANCE EVOLUTION would provide:

  • A Major cultural experience for the community, and;
  • The chance for Anglo Australian's to join with the Middle Eastern community in a positive way by sharing some of their culture, and;
  • Provide young artists the chance to work in masterclasses with Jillina and her company

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us by contributing directly or telling other's about this wonderful production and enterprise

You can find out more by visiting Hathor Dance Studio:

http://www.hathordancestudio.com.au/

And that’s all there is to it.

Who am I??

My name is Andreanna and I am Sophias Mom. Unfortunately I  have been unable to secure employment beyond babysitting for the last year. I hate that my child will suffer because of this. My  daughter  would live her entire life on stage if she could. Everything she does is an act or performance. Luckily we belong to a studio that understands this and has let us slide for quite a few months. But the end of the season is upon us and even though I have secured a babysitting job I cannot get caught up on everything and pay the studio back so she can participate in the recital, national convention, and enter her in her final competition. This would have been her very first National Dance competition and Convention.

WHAT IS A DANCE CONVENTION??

At the National  convention Sophia will have the opportunity to  learn from some fo teh top choreographers in the country in all styles of dance. She will learn the importance of technique and learning choreography quickly which will come in handy for auditions.

WHY IS THIS IMPORTANT AT ONLY 9??

Sophia has goals in life and  to be on the stage is  a huge part of it. You are never too young to begin the planning and hard work it takes to reach your goals. Especially with dance. it takes years of training and hard work to make it.  This convention is a huge step.

WHY NOT TAKE TIME OFF WHILE FAMILY IS  HAVING FINANCIAL ISSUES? 

FREAK ACCIDENT AND 3 SURGERIES?

I know this doesnt seem important to many but you see my daughter has already missed a lot of what she loves. 2 years ago my daughter  sustained a FREAK injury while attending a friends birthday party. At the party she  had her finger severed off and 2 other fingers and her hand severly injured. After 3 surgeries and physical therapy Sophia's surgeon was able to save most of her finger. It was a rough year for a 6 year old. She missed playing outside, dance, recess and many things she enjoys. It was crucial to her healing that she didnt do these things. Her finger may not grow as she grows, and is still deformed, but we are grateful to God she even has one and that the injury didnt  take more. Now finances may cause her to  take another long  break from her love of performing. I know  once we are caught up with our studio and get through this year that things will be better. But she has worked all year sooo hard and now to have her year end recital , convention, and  first National competition sooo close and ripped away because my lack of finding a good job earlier breaks my  heart. Not to mention dissappointing her teammates  as well.

SOPHIA IS GIVING!

 I sure hope you can find it in your heart to help this sweet girl. She has always been  big in community service and helping others and will conitnue to do so. My daughter is a give back pay it forward type of person and your generosity will not be lost on her or us I promise you that.

 $1300 will go  to our studio for  fees  I owe for her classes and other competitions and allow her to participate in the year end recital and continue her training as well.. We owe our studio more than money.  They  have been very supportive through everything.

$300 will go towards her participation in the national convention where she will have the opportunity to take dozens of classes from the best in the industry. It really is an amazing opportunity for her. She will also have the opportunity to earn scholarships at this event as well.

story: Keep "Death of a Salesman" alive in its newest manifestation: a South Asian family as the Lomans, using all of Miller's original words, to demonstrate the universal themes of complicated family relationships and pursuing the American Dream. Funds raised at this site will be used for: * Rental of a theatre in midtown Manhattan for a 15-performance run. * Approximately 8 weeks of rehearsal time and space. * Scenic, costume, and lighting designers. * Scenic elements, props and costumes. * Publicity for the show, including hiring a publicist to contact meida and theatre critics. * Paying our stage manager. * Insurance. Always Love Lucy theatre is in the process of becoming a 501(c)3, and can provide information to make all donations tax-deductible. All funds raised will be used exclusively for production purposes. (And we already have ideas for 2015's production in the works ..... stay tuned!) Thank you and shukriya! See you on Opening Night!
story_txt:
Keep "Death of a Salesman" alive in its newest manifestation: a South Asian family as the Lomans, using all of Miller's original words, to demonstrate the universal themes of complicated family relationships and pursuing the American Dream.  

Funds raised at this site will be used for:

* Rental of a theatre in midtown Manhattan for a 15-performance run.

* Approximately 8 weeks of rehearsal time and space.

* Scenic, costume, and lighting designers.

* Scenic elements, props and costumes.

* Publicity for the show, including hiring a publicist to contact meida and theatre critics.

* Paying our stage manager.

* Insurance.

Always Love Lucy theatre is in the process of becoming a 501(c)3, and can provide information to make all donations tax-deductible.  

All funds raised will be used exclusively for production purposes. (And we already have ideas for 2015's production in the works ..... stay tuned!)

Thank you and shukriya! See you on Opening Night!

story:
(VERSIONE ITALIANA)
                     
          clicca qui        .

The eVolution dance theater company (www.evolutiondancetheater.com), directed by the american choreographer Anthony Heinl (a former Momix and Daniel Ezralow dancer) is searching for funds to tour its new production "ElectriCity".

The company, known for its excellent creativity, imaginative athleticism and fascinating visionary, found great success in recent years and 'sould out' in major theaters in Italy and around the world with "FireFly".


 

ElectriCity - the new production by “eVolution dance theater”

a surprisingly suggestive display...

The multi-sensory journey of Evolution Dance Theater's latest production, is transformed from the more free-spirited imaginings of "FireFly", to a more tangible reality in ElectriCity,  exciting and vibrant choreography, vibrating with vivid colors and shadow, a composition in which the different "energies" give rise to the surprising and unexpected.  Every stand individual scene ushering in this technological scenario, in full agreement and harmony with the human body. A blast from the future and the past, a present that acknowledges what has been while pointing towards an intriguing future. An other worldy atmosphere is brought to life balancing precariously the concepts concept of truth and astonishment. To open a portal to the existence of other ways of seeing. As usual, the choreographer Anthony Heinl has not sought a dramatic arc to the full evening work, sure of the idea that art and creativity is a journey down a wonderful path that does not have a final destination. The sole purpose is to inspire and fascinate, to lead you on a trip with the intent to transmit a contagious positivity that can bring any audience to dance, smile, and wonder with intellectual curiosity and physical agility. Always exploring the freedom of eclectic expression , combining years of experience and research related to technology, movement, sound and color, Electric City assures:

Bursting with energy and originality in the excited state!

 

--- versione italiana ---

La eVolution dance theater (www.evolutiondancetheater.com), diretta dal coreografo americano Anthony Heinl (ex componente dei Momix e della compagnia di Daniel Ezralow) è alla ricerca di fondi per ultimare la sua tournèe italiana di "ElectriCity".

La compagnia, conosciuta per la sua eccellente creatività, fantasioso atletismo e affascinante visionarietà, ha riscontrato negli ultimi anni ottimi successi e  'sould out' nei maggiori teatri italiani e in tutto il mondo con "FireFly".

Nella programmazione 2013/2014, oltre a nuove date in Italia, si aggiungeranno anche spettacoli in Israele, Cina e Sud-America.

 

ElectriCity - la nuova produzione di “eVolution dance theater”

una sorprendente esposizione di suggestioni…

Il viaggio sensoriale dell’ultima produzione di Evolution Dance Theatre, si trasforma da un’atmosfera più rarefatta e d’immaginazione di “FireFly”, ad una realtà più concreta di una Città Elettrica, contenitrice ed Le nuovissime e vibranti coreografie, accese nei colori e nei toni immaginifici, rappresentano un grande quadro elettrico in cui le diverse "energie" danno vita a stimoli e sensazioni sorprendenti e inaspettate. Saranno nuovamente scene singole a introdurci in questo scenario tecnologico, in pieno accordo con ciò che è l’armonia del corpo umano. Un tuffo tra futuro e passato, tra vecchio e nuovo, un presente che elabora ciò che é stato e ciò che si delinea come suo "futuro ideale". Un’atmosfera onirica nella quale viene rivisitato il concetto di verità e lo stupore nel percepire l'esistenza di altri modi di vedere. Come di consueto, il coreografo Anthony Heinl non ha ricercato una drammaturgia finale, sicuro dell’idea che l‘arte e la creatività possano essere un percorso stupendo di ricerca che non sempre necessità di un fine concreto. L’unico scopo è il piacere di percorrere un altro viaggio con l'intento di trasmettere una positività contagiosa che possa avvicinare qualsiasi tipo di pubblico alla danza, con onestà intellettuale e fascino del linguaggio corporeo. Sempre alla ricerca di una libertà espressiva ed eclettica, capace di coniugare pluralità di ricerche legate alla tecnologia, alla danza, al suono e al colore, ElectriCity assicura:

Un’esplosione di energia e dinamismo allo stato puro!!!

story:
MaineStage Shakespeare is returning to Kennebunk for its third season! Because it's 2013, we're looking for $2013 to help fund our company.

In case you don't know about us, here's the scoop.

  • We perform Shakespeare's plays each summer for the people of southwest Maine -- free of charge.
  • We teach local kids about acting and Shakespeare at our ShakeStars summer camp. 
  • We are run by and employ young actors who are passionate about performing and teaching.
  • We are funded in large part by donations from people like you.

If you've seen us before and love what we do, or if you just think bringing Shakespeare to the people is a good thing (we do!), consider donating. Every dollar you give us goes to pay actors, buy sets and props, and support the family programming that is one of our hallmarks.

Plus, depending on how much you donate, you could earn cool swag like MaineStage T-shirts, tote bags, or even a custom-written sonnet! Everyone who helps us, no matter the amount, will be mentioned in our programs over the summer.

For info, pictures, and our performance calendar, check out our website:

www.mainestageshakespeare.com

And be sure to come visit us this year! Our three shows are

HAMLET

MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHING

and THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE, ABRIDGED

all performed in the open air of Lafayette Park. And, for the first time ever, we'll be performing in Kennebunkport: on Tuesdays at the Village Green and on Wednesdays at the Colony Hotel!

 

See you soon!

Love,

MaineStage Shakespeare

story:
Short Summary

Intersect Dance Collective is taking the show on the road! We will be teaching and performing in Tennessee, Kentucky, Ohio, and New York during July.

What We Need & What You Get

We need funds for transportation and lodging. Some funds will be used to purchase costumes.

The Impact

We are known for a unique blend of humor, passion, and technique that inspires audiences of all ages and backgrounds. Help us share the love, hope, and joy through dance!


Risks & Challenges

Our dancers will be taking time out from their day jobs to go on this tour, which means they will lose some income. We believe we have a calling to do what we do, however, and trust that we won't actually become starving artists!

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Share our campaign on social media. In addition, we would love your prayer support. Or you could send us some rice and beans...

story:
Short Summary

I am producing this play as part of my master's thesis in Central and Eastern European Studies (CEES) at La Salle University.  In doing so I educate others while educating myself about modern Ukrainian history and literature.  This play will promote a greater understanding of Ukrainian culture and will spark an interest in Ukrainian literature, which is relatively unknown in America.

Oleksandr Irvanets, the playwright, has not yet had any plays produced in the United States.  He is well known in Ukraine as part of a group in the late 80's and early 90's called Bu-Ba-Bu.  This group wrote and performed poertry in a carnival fasion, incorporating all the arts in their performances.  They had a great impact on the youth of Ukraine before and after Independence in 1991. 


A Little Play About Betrayal For One Actress is about ONA, a young adult who now lives in a small apartment in a wheelchair.  We learn she was once a student protester.  The world of the play is not specific to constraints of time and place, but through ONA's words we learn more about the fight for Ukrainian Independence from the Soviet Union in 1991 and the effects of that independence, including a weak economy and a government run by former Communist leaders. 

I think anytime we learn more about someone else's history and culture, we learn about ourselves, and realize that we are all alike and all different.  Sometimes differences in others are visually apparent, but often we forget that  people who look alike are not alike at all.  It is important to remember the very modern history of the impact of the Soviet Union, and not take for granted all the advantages we currently have in America. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

This project costs $4000.  This amount covers the rental fee of the Walnut Street Theatre, the pay for the designers, director, and actress, and the cost of building the set and securing the props.  I also have received many donated services.  If I raise the entire cost of producing, I would like to provide the playwright and translators a modest honorarium, even though they have given me permission to perform this play for no charge.

In addition to providing a free cultural and educational program, I am also providing jobs to Philadelphia artists. 


The $2000 I am trying to raise on Indiegogo is half the cost--it covers the space, the set, and the props.

Your support is greatly appreciated.  In exchange for various levels of support, we can add your name to our website and to our program.  We can reserve you  a seat, sign a poster, frame a poster, and invite you to the after party.  Please consider being a part of the US Premiere of this production.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please spread the word...every $10 adds up and really helps cover the cost of this production.
  • Buzz, buzz, buzz
  • Please read the website jenniferhoffmaster.wordpress.com for updates and dramaturgical notes.

 

The Players:

Oleksandr Irvanets-playwright

Taras Koznarsky and Marta Baziuk--translators

Lorna Howley--director

Sarah Schol--Actress

Lance Kniskern--Set Designer

Amanda Jensen--Lighting Designer

Christine Bater--Stage Manager

Julee Mahon--Choreographer/ House Manager

Emma MacDonald--Asst. Lighting/ Asst. Stage manager

Julian Mykytiuch--Musician/ Composer

John Lopes--Voice of Newscaster 1

Benjamin Carlson--Co-Producer/ Webmaster/ Sound Designer

Jennifer L. Hoffmaster--Producer/Dramaturg/ Voice of Newscaster 2


Mykola Riabchuk--political scientist, after-show speaker on June 6

Dr. Leonid Rudnytzky--thesis advisor and panel scholar for talkback on June 6 and June 8

Dr. Mark Andryczyk--Ukrainian literature scholar for talkback on June 8

story:
"You might not know the Gurg by name,
But this is their revue,
Come see invention's inspiration,
Let it inspire you!"

-Thomas Edison

Funding musical comedy is no laughing matter.

Me Prometheus is scheduled to premier at Wesleyan University, April 10-12. To produce the show, we'll need to cover the following costs:

  • Materials for the construction of a set.
  • Rental lighting equipment.
  • Props.
  • Costumes for a cast of twenty.  Loincloths may be cheap, but fur coats certainly aren't.
  • Printing of posters and playbills.
  • Filming of the production.
  • And, should we end up with any extra money, we'll put it into the production of a high-quality soundtrack.

story:
The who & why:

Hi there! We are ImprovCity, a clean improvisational comedy troupe based out of Orange County, CA. We began in March 2009 and in just five short years we’ve been named “The Best Place to Laugh in Orange County” three years in a row by the OC Hotlist, “The Best Comedy/Improv in Southern California” by The LA Times, and “The Best Improv Show in Orange County” by CBS Los Angeles. We did all that and started an after school improv arts program at five local high schools, one middle school and two elementary schools.

For the past five years we’ve moved from rented space to rented space - garages, lofts, galleries, conference centers, etc. - and it’s time we try to get our own theater space. We want to build a place that not only offers somewhere to bring the entire family for a night of great live entertainment, but also a place that offers classes, workshops and education in the areas of acting, comedy, improvisation and more to people of all ages.

And that's not all we'd use the theater for. We'll also put on musical and play productions, bring in musical guests, have guest speakers on various topics with question and answer forums, have open mic nights for standup comedy and poetry readings, hold movie nights...anything and everything that has to do with the arts and entertainment.


What We Need & What You Get

We have set a goal of $40,000 to help us not only secure a location for our theater, but also pay for all the things that go with it - insurance, licenses, stage, seating, sound, lighting, concessions, advertising and other improvements. Please help us hit that goal by sharing away on all social media networks!

Your support means the world to us. Your love (signified by your dollar) allows us to bring to life a creative vision we want to share with the community.

Show us you love us a LOT and we will show our appreciation with some awesome perks such as an ImprovCity t-shirt, private shows, or free admission to our shows for six months, a year or LIFE!



The Impact

If we are successful in getting our own theater space, it would be a great addition to the cultural community in both arts and education. ImprovCity has a business licenses in both education and entertainment, and many of our professional improvisers are fully licensed and certified teachers in the Orange County Unified School District . 

Here are just a few of the benefits that would come with us having our own theater space:

  • Classes would be offered for kids, teens and adults in acting, improv, standup comedy, sketch, comedy writing and more.
  • Businesses (or individuals) could rent out our theater for corporate retreats, business meetings, or office get-togethers.
  • After school art programs for students in a creative environment.
  • Aspiring actors and actresses could get stage time through play/musical productions that we put on.
  • Open mic nights at our theater would give stage time to up-and-coming and professional comedians, poets, musicians and others.


Other Ways You Can Help

No amount is too small (or too big!), but we understand that not everyone can make a monetary donation. You can still help!! Spread the word about our campaign and share our video on Facebook and Twitter and tell people to visit our website  www.improvcityonline.com for more information.

story:
The Play Ballet Mat

The "Play Ballet Mat" is a dance game that guides young dancers through their first ballet positions in the format of an exciting game.

The Five basic foot positions are laid out in an  intuitive and familiar "Hop Scotch" format, making it easy for small children to utilize and learn.  As the game progresses children are guided through, arm positions, rises, plie' and basic ballet jumps. Using core terminology children will learn proper turn out in positions along with its correlating name. 

Ballet teachers who work with young children know, the hardest thing to teach is proper turn out. That is; your feet, legs and hips properly turned in steps, extensions and jumps.

My "Play Ballet" mat lets children practice in between classes in a fun progressive game and teaches "turn out" through repetition, body memory and fun.

It is a no-slip material, easy to roll up and store.

I have been hand inking these mats for the past 6 months and selling them in my classes . It is a pain staking process but, completely worth my efforts as the feed back I have received from children and parents has been overwhelmingly positive.  The kids love to tell me how far they have gotten in the game and the parents are so pleased to have an active indoor game when the weather turns sour.

ME

I started out dancing on the discarded siding of an above ground pool. I remember summers, bringing my "tape deck" out into the grass and spending hours practicing, choreographing dance moves. I was dedicated. Through injury, sweat and tears I danced. I felt like I was flying. I pretended I was on "Star Search" and the world stopped and opened for me. I paid for and took my first Ballet Class at 15. I was up on point at 16. Today, I teach. I teach children the joy of dance though Ballet.
I am a ballet teacher, dancer and mommy . I have been teaching for Four years and dancing since I could walk. I put myself through ballet school at 15. Growing up poor has made me resourceful, and annoyingly tenacious about the things I am passionate about....
And I am passionate about dance, kids and giving back to the world at large. This is my campaign to fulfill all three.

For more information on what I do please visit my website. 

www.polkadotsdance.com


An Easy Plan in Two Parts

This campaign will help spread the joy of Dance in Two fundamental ways.

1)  By having an easy to store, intuitive play mat children can practice the five major ballet positions in their own home assuring proper turn out, all within the parameters of  a fun game. As your child's ballet skills improve the game progresses and becomes more advanced. Until your child finishes the game as a "Prima Ballerina"

I have been using the prototype I invented of this mat in my classes for the last year. It has become so popular that my students now request it even when it is not part of our weekly curriculum.  Siblings as young as 2 years of age have been known to successfully and merrily utilize it during and after  classes. 

2)  15% of all profits will go to charity supporting dance education in under served, under supported areas.

My school "PolkaDots Traveling School of Dance" currently works with community centers, schools and after care programs to bring children Tap, Ballet and movement classes to a wide range of economical backgrounds at a base cost.

15% of the profits from these dance mats will enable our dance teachers to go into schools all over northern California and teach dance series with no charge to students or their families, further spreading my philosophy that dance IS for everyone.

What We Need & What You Get

What we need:

* Funds to pay for the first 1000 mats to be printed, plus taxes, basic packaging, (I am hand packaging to cut costs) shipping and incidentals.

What you get:

* PolkaDots Traveling School of Dance "Shwag," (based on the amount  that is contributed,) 

* A tax deductible donation  for your end of the year filling.

* A happy heart knowing that your contribution will continue to  teach underprivileged students the joy of dance with 15% of the profits going to charity. (Profits begin after the second round of 1000 mats is paid for)

The Impact

 Once we get started our mats and charity work propagate each other. The more mats we sell the more Free classes are taught. The more classes that are taught, the more people see the mats and inevitably want to purchase one, not only for practice and play sake but, to propogate more classes.

Other Ways You Can Help

I know we don't all have money to contribute. Goodness knows that when i was a single mother, just starting my dance teaching, my daughter and I saw a pretty slim year..... It's still slim, to tell you the truth. 

So, if you are reading my profile and want to act but, don't have the funds, contribute by spreading the word with friends, family, social media and good ol' fashioned word of mouth.

The Math

Why $16,000? well, $13,000 will cover the cost of 1000 mats to be printed, shipped, packaged and 1/4 of them mailed. The other $3,000 is to cover taxes and crowd funding dues. If I use half of my stock as thank you gifts in my fund,  I am left with 500 mats to sell, the proceeds from the sale of those mats will be used to fund my next round of play ballet mats. the math is portioned to the penny. No more, no less.

story:
WHAT'S APRIL'S FOOL?                 

April's Fool is a metaphysical comedy by Kelly McAllister having it's world premiere at the New York International Fringe Festival this August in the beautiful Connelly Theatre, directed by Bronwen Carson and produced by Craig Nobbs.  FringeNYC is the largest performing arts festival in North America- and we are going to make this production something people will be speaking of for years and decades to come. You can be a part of this!

FATE HAS A SENSE OF HUMOR

The play takes place over 24 hours in New York City. It starts at a costume party on April Fools Day- where Fate, in human form, crashes the party. She brings with her a decorative axe. What follows is a hilarious, often harrowing examination of the question: can we change our fate, or are we meant to end up where we end up? And if we could change things- should we?

 First off, here's who we are:

  • Kelly McAllister is an award winning playwright whose work has been published and produced from NYC to Prague to São Paulo. His plays include: Last Call (winner of Excellence in Playwriting FringeNYC 2002); Burning the Old Man (NYIT 2005 Outstanding Full Length Play); & Hela and Troy (Finalist Humana Festival Heideman award 2010). His plays have been published by Applause Books, Playscripts Inc., Smith & Kruas, and NYTE.
  • Bronwen Carson is an accomplished director/choreographer based in NYC. Her credits include:  Viva America- B'dway Workshop, The Cherry Orchard - Off-B’dway, In The Key of Cy - Off B'dwy, Myopia - Neighborhood Playhouse, Dim Sum - The Neighborhood Playhouse, Sunday in the Park With Phil- Piney Fork Festival, NYC, Fugue- The Neighborhood Playhouse, the world premiere of “Jack’s Back”  - Gloria Maddox Theatre NYC , 49th Street and Other Stories, Playing With Fire  - The Private Theatre, The Dragon Play -Articulate Theatre Company, NYC, Two Days til Dawn - Off B'dwy, and A Tribute to Michael Jackson- 2010 Astaire Awards. 

  • Craig Nobbs is an award winning playwright, screenwriter and producer. He was recently Associate Producer and Production Manager on the feature film SAM, directed by Nicholas Brooks and is currently producing the short film The Cat's Cradle, written by Tawny Sorenson and directed by David Spaltro,  His plays include A New York Hamlet and Other Stories (adaptations of Chekhov short stories), In the Shadows (commissioned adaptation of Maxim Gorky's The Lower Depths), $175/hr, Coffee, Morning is Broken and many other plays that have had readings and productions in New York City.  He is a graduate of NYU's Tisch School of the Arts' Dramatic Writing Program and New York Foundation for the Arts' Artist as Entrepreneur Program.  

The cast:

  • Sarah Wharton (April)
  • Ian Campbell Dunn (Ahab)
  • Liz Conway (Moira)
  • Daniel Keith (Jaypes)
  • Heather McAllister (The Norn)
  • We also have a lovely group of understudies / interns: Laura Jervidalo Ravn (Norn understudy), Laura Epperson (Moira understudy), Johanna Block (April understudy) and Bill Reilly (Jaypes understudy).


Where we've been

The play was originally written as part of Rough Writers, a writing contest at the Fine Arts Center of Colorado Springs. It quickly evolved into a strange, exciting, unique piece of theatre that could be called magic realism. This past April, it was given a staged reading as part of the Playwrights Festival at The Western Stage in Salinas, CA. And now, it's time for it's world premiere at FringeNYC!                                                 

What We Need 

We need to raise funds to cover the costs of putting up a show in NYC- which can be pretty expensive, as you can imagine. Here's a list of where you contribution will go:

  • Rehearsal space- four weeks rehearsal in New York City
  • scenery for the production-  a pinball machine, a rolling bar, and a very ugly chair
  • costumes, make-up, hair
  • Insurance covering auditions, rehearsals, and performances
  • registration fees
  • paying our cast and crew- they don't get a lot, but they certainly deserve it!
  • advertising-  graphic design, photos, email blasts, ad space. REMEMBER, the more funds we raise, the better we can advertise the show!
  • All funds raised will go towards April's Fool- so if we raise twenty thousand bucks, we place the full page ad in the NY Times.

What You Get

  • We have lots of cool perks to offer- everything from a thanks in the shows program to 25 plays for your digital library courtesy of Indie Theater Now to having your fortune read to hanging out with the cast and crew on opening night!

Your Impact

Just by reading this far, you are helping! Spread the love and tell everyone you know about this show!

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand that some of you just can't contribute financially at this time, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Like us on Facebook at: facebook.com/aprilsfoolplay
  • Follow us on Twitter at: @AprilsFoolplay
  • You can get the word out and make some noise about this campaign!
  • You can share this on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Tumblr or whatever social network you like!

It's as simple as that.

B'dwy, and A Tribute to Michael Jackson- 2010 Astaire Awards. 







Craig Nobbs is an award winning playwright, screenwriter and producer. He was recently Associate Producer and Production Manager on the feature film SAM, directed by Nicholas Brooks and is currently producing the short film The Cat's Cradle, written by Tawny Sorenson and directed by David Spaltro,  His plays include A New York Hamlet and Other Stories (adaptations of Chekhov short stories), In the Shadows (commissioned adaptation of Maxim Gorky's The Lower Depths), $175/hr, Coffee, Morning is Broken and many other plays that have had readings and productions in New York City.  He is a graduate of NYU's Tisch School of the Arts' Dramatic Writing Program and New York Foundation for the Arts' Artist as Entrepreneur Program.  
The cast:
Sarah Wharton (April)
Ian Campbell Dunn (Ahab)
Liz Conway (Moira)
Daniel Keith (Jaypes)
Heather McAllister (The Norn)
We also have a lovely group of understudies / interns: Laura Jervidalo Ravn (Norn understudy), Laura Epperson (Moira understudy), Johanna Block (April understudy) and Bill Reilly (Jaypes understudy).Where we've beenThe play was originally written as part of Rough Writers, a writing contest at the Fine Arts Center of Colorado Springs. It quickly evolved into a strange, exciting, unique piece of theatre that could be called magic realism. This past April, it was given a staged reading as part of the Playwrights Festival at The Western Stage in Salinas, CA. And now, it's time for it's world premiere at FringeNYC!                                                 What We Need We need to raise funds to cover the costs of putting up a show in NYC- which can be pretty expensive, as you can imagine. Here's a list of where you contribution will go:
Rehearsal space- four weeks rehearsal in New York City
scenery for the production-  a pinball machine, a rolling bar, and a very ugly chair
costumes, make-up, hair
Insurance covering auditions, rehearsals, and performances
registration fees
paying our cast and crew- they don't get a lot, but they certainly deserve it!
advertising-  graphic design, photos, email blasts, ad space. REMEMBER, the more funds we raise, the better we can advertise the show!
All funds raised will go towards April's Fool- so if we raise twenty thousand bucks, we place the full page ad in the NY Times.
What You GetWe have lots of cool perks to offer- everything from a thanks in the shows program to 25 plays for your digital library courtesy of Indie Theater Now to having your fortune read to hanging out with the cast and crew on opening night!Your ImpactJust by reading this far, you are helping! Spread the love and tell everyone you know about this show!Other Ways You Can HelpWe completely understand that some of you just can't contribute financially at this time, but that doesn't mean you can't help:
Like us on Facebook at: facebook.com/aprilsfoolplay

Follow us on Twitter at: @AprilsFoolplay

You can get the word out and make some noise about this campaign!
You can share this on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Tumblr or whatever social network you like!
It's as simple as that.

story:
When You Turn 23, It’s Time To Get Your Own Place

With twenty-two successful years of producing original theater in Chicago under their belt, The Factory Theater is moving back to where they started: Rogers Park. The Factory Theater's new home is located at the historic Howard Theater in Rogers Park, at 1621-23 W. Howard. The new 80 seat theater will open officially at the start of Factory's 23rd Season in fall 2015. "When you turn 23," The Factory said in a recent email to patrons, "it's time to get your own place."  

Why is The Factory so vital? Factory Theater delivers unexpected, unapologetic theatrical experiences through original works forged and assembled by our shameless ensemble. We believe in partnering with our community to become a fixture in Rogers Park, providing a home for original works in Chicago, and contributing to not only Rogers Park’s growth, but the growth of Howard Street to become a cultural destination for patrons and artists from all over the city and surrounding areas.

What others say about The Factory Theater:

"May we all just take a moment to agree that Factory Theater is a goddamn Chicago Treasure?'  -- Time Out Chicago

"We are witnessing the birth of a new theatrical form." -- The Chicago Reader

"This irreverent theater company does multiple comedy shows, late night and prime time, the titles of which--''White Trash Wedding and a Funeral,'' ''Second City Didn't Want Us,'' ''Bitches''--tell you what to expect. The work ranges from crude to brilliant and changes so fast it's impossible to categorize."  -- Metromix.com

THE IMPACT:

We are thrilled to have already raised over 20% of the funds necessary to help with the costs of the project completion! With your help, we will raise the remaining $50K through this Indiegogo Campaign, as well as private funding.

  • Donations will go towards completing construction, buying theatrical equipment, hiring new staff, and covering transitions costs.

  • Have you seen the perks? Look to your right. Go. Look! They’re awesome!

  • All funding goes directly into the building of our new home. There’s a lot of work to do, but with your help, our dream will become a reality!

With your help, we can bring you Season 23’s new, original works:

ZOMBIE BROADS
written by Corrbette Pasko & Sara Sevigny

Maxine and Marco, and their book club “The Zombie Broads”, have all the weaponry and knowledge they’ll even need for the zombie uprising. Their daughter, Shelby, is trained for the worst, but would really just like to get a cell phone and date her secret boyfriend. Besides, zombies won’t happen. It’s not like a scientist is accidentally gonna do anything stupid, right? By the way, you smell really good...delicious even...you should probably run.

THE LAST BIG MISTAKE
written by Ernest Deak

In one savage night in the summer of ‘75, Lola Knight & Roxy Aguilar make a series of increasingly awful decisions, all of them surrounding a strange little package they were hired to transport. Meanwhile, the rightful owner of that package is in town, bent on revenge and leaving a trail of bodies in his murderous wake as he searches for his property. Lola & Roxy fight their way across town; and though the night is over, their troubles have only just begun. They really can’t remember their first big mistake, but it’s likely they won’t forget their last big mistake.

DATING & DRAGONS
written by Mike Ooi

Jack loves to play games. He’s really good at knowing the rules, especially when the game involves swords, sorcery, and a dragon or two. But when he meets Diane and falls under her spell, which rules should he follow? How do you win at dating? Join Jack and his friends on a journey through the rules of dating, dragons and doing the right thing.

We are thrilled to present this new season, but it is impossible without your support. The Factory Theater must raise $20,000 in this campaign in order to complete our new home, produce these three fantastic new works and continue to grow for years to come.

What We Need & What You Get

We need your support- whether its $10, $25 or $50, any amount helps, and we want to thank you for it!  For your tax deductible donation, we'd like to give an extra thank you by sending you gifts.  Because we love you.  Because our audience is who we do this for, and because we can't wait for you to see our new space.

Other Ways You Can Help

Unable to throw us a cash donation right now? Share this on your social network of choice, email, text message, or phone call.  As we say every night, "Word of mouth is the best form of advertising".  Thanks for the last 22 years.  Let's keep it going!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
We will ALWAYS know how many years it's been since Line Between premiered at ODC in San Francisco. Because, as it happened, our son Niko was born a week before the show opened. (He came a little early. Our theory is that he wanted to see for himself what all the ruckus was he'd been hearing in utero for eight months). Four years have passed since that very special double feature. 


The short schpiel:

Now, the door to Asia has been opened and we've been invited to re-mount Line Between.

The Seoul International Dance Festival (SIDance) has offered inkBoat the opportunity to perform this October and we humbly ask for your help to make it happen.

The opportunities from this are magnified by the fact that the festival overlaps with the Performing Arts Market Seoul (PAMS), which takes place October 5-9. Presenters and venues from around Asia will be attending PAMS, and our performance, which will take place October 6th, was scheduled intentionally in order to maximize our exposure and exchange with these international presenters.

We have the chance to leverage future performances and tours throughout Asia, which would be a dream come true.  To make it happen, we need your help to get there!

The longer story:

The offer to perform at SIDance came late and on the condition that we get ourselves there. The festival is offering us a modest fee ($1,500) and hotel accommodations for 6 nights. We have also secured an emergency grant from American Dance Abroad for $2,000. We have a solid start to raising what we need to get ourselves and our set to Seoul, but we have $5,000 to go and we're turning to you now for help.

There are six of us traveling- 3 dancers, 2 musicians, 1 set designer/ lighting technician. If we raise this $5,000 we will have enough to cover our airfare, set transport, with a little bit left over to pay our hardworking team, who are otherwise working for peanuts, or rather, kimchee.

Your contribution would be not only helping us get to this gig in Korea, it would be helping pave the road for future inkBoat performances in Asia. It would be a gift toward a very specific purpose as well as an investment in our future.

The even longer story:

One of the many reasons we are excited about this opportunity to perform Line Between at SIDance is that we seldom have the chance to revisit any of our past works. Typically, artists are funded to make new work rather than to develop old material. We are thrilled to get the chance to return to past material and develop it further. A human being goes through a lot of changes in four years, as Niko so boldly illustrates. How have we grown as artists, and how will this production of Line Between reflect our growth?

Back in 2011, Line Between was made through the collaborative efforts of Shinichi Iova-Koga, Dohee Lee and Peiling Kao as performers, Suki O'Kane and Jason Ditzian as musicians, and Dana Iova-Koga as director.  The design team (which won an "Izzie" award for outstanding stage design) included Amy Rathbone (set and instillations), Frank Lee (set), Allen Willner (lighting and stage), and Alice Wu (costumes). 

We are faced with some challenges in this endeavor. The first has to do with embracing change. The irreplaceable Dohee Lee and Jason Ditzian are unable to join us for this performance. However, we are thrilled to have on board with us Jubilith Moore (performer) and Katherine McDonald (musician), two wonderful artists who bring their unique talents to the work. Peiling's role will be played by Dana (who wanted to do it back in 2011, but couldn't due to being extremely pregnant.) 

The second big challenge has to do with funding. Which is, of course, why we are doing this darn crowdfunding thing. As we have discovered, there are very few grants out there that will fund international touring performances. And even if there were, this invitation came too late to give us ample fundraising time.

We were fully aware of these challenges when we said yes. But it is a yes we feel very excited about proclaiming.

Will you join us in this affirmative?

Even if you can't or don't want to contribute to this campaign, will you say "YES!" out loud on our behalf? (With the echoes of that YES touching all of the creative risks that you and we and all of us take.) And/or, will you do the digital version of that and spread the word on your digital platform of choice?

Thank you very much.

story:
About PLAY Conservatory

  • PLAY Conservatory was born in summer 2007, when children's Theater director and veteran teacher Jonathan Dunski was asked to offer a summer Theater program for children and youth as part of the summer enrichment programs at St. Pius X High School.  Since then the company has grown to offer year-round programming and has partnered with several local theater organizations and venues to produce a an ambitious array of unique and challenging projects. 

  • PLAY has always worked to bring theater to children who may not ordinarily have the opportunity to become involved in stagecraft. Our desire to become more inclusive has pushed us to find new ways to look at productions to make theater accessible for children of all abilities. 

How you can help:

  • Every workshop and performance that PLAY Conservatory invests in is dedicated to the idea that Theatre fundamentally provides opportunities for children and youth to develop skills in self-confidence, cooperation, and critical thinking. We strive for excellence, innovation, and professionalism in our work. In order to continue growing and producing inclusive programs, we need your help to fund our productions.
  • Shows like this summer's Children of Eden would not have been possible without donations that allowed PLAY Conservatory to bring in a professional ASL Master to teach American Sign Language to the entire cast. Not only were we privileged to work with amazing Deaf talent, but we had the opportunity to learn about Deaf Culture while we learned a new language. 
  • Your donations allow PLAY to bring professionals in to work with the youth, provide studio time for rehearsals, access to theaters for shows, and scholarships for children to attend workshops and theater camps.

Our Goal:

  • Our goal is to raise $12,000.00 with this campaign. We have one donor that has agreed to match donations to $6,000.00! We are so excited about this!
  • Every penny we raise goes to providing the best experience possible for the youth involved in PLAY's projects. Our future plans include pursuing more inclusive  theater.
  • PLAY Conservatory intends to build on the lessons learned from Children of Eden by continuing our connection with the Deaf and Hard of Hearing theater community. 
  • Our goal always includes making the theater experience accessible to every child. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Follow the links and sign up to volunteer for our next project.
  • Follow the links and check out the videos from our previous projects and from some of our alumni.
  • Tell everyone you know about the wonderful work PLAY Conservatory is doing for the kids in our community.
  • Please share this campaign and help us get the word out.

PLAY Conservatory was born in summer 2007, when children's Theater director and veteran teacher Jonathan Dunski was asked to offer a summer Theater program for children and youth as part of the summer enrichment programs at St. Pius X High School.  Since then the company has grown to offer year-round programming and has partnered with several local theater organizations and venues to produce a an ambitious array of unique and challenging projects. 
PLAY has always worked to bring theater to children who may not ordinarily have the opportunity to become involved in stagecraft. Our desire to become more inclusive has pushed us to find new ways to look at productions to make theater accessible for children of all abilities.

We strive for excellence, innovation, and professionalism in our work. In order to continue growing and producing inclusive programs, we need your help to fund our productions.
Shows like this summer's Children of Eden would not have been possible without donations that allowed PLAY Conservatory to bring in a professional ASL Master to teach American Sign Language to the entire cast. Not only were we privileged to work with amazing Deaf talent, but we had the opportunity to learn about Deaf Culture while we learned a new language. 
Your donations allow PLAY to bring professionals in to work with the youth, provide studio time for rehearsals, access to theaters for shows, and scholarships for children to attend workshops and theater camps.

Our Goal:

Our goal is to raise $12,000.00 with this campaign. We have one donor that has agreed to match donations to $6,000.00! We are so excited about this!
Every penny we raise goes to providing the best experience possible for the youth involved in PLAY's projects. Our future plans include pursuing more inclusive  theater.
PLAY Conservatory intends to build on the lessons learned from Children of Eden by continuing our connection with the Deaf and Hard of Hearing theater community. 
Our goal always includes making the theater experience accessible to every child.

Follow the links and sign up to volunteer for our next project.

Tell everyone you know about the wonderful work PLAY Conservatory is doing for the kids in our community.
Please share this campaign and help us get the word out.

story:
Originally from upstate New York, I trained at The Draper Center for Dance Education, then continued on to graduate from New York University's Tisch School of the Arts in 2008.

Since that time, I have been fortunate to work with artists such as Adam Barruch, Margie Gillis, Sidra Bell, and Steven Petronio.  I was able to create site specific art films with mishmash* in Japan and Sarah Elgart (arrogantelbow) in New York, and spent almost four years with London-based immersive theatre company Punchdrunk in their production 'Sleep No More.' These amazing opportunities have challenged and expanded my physical and performative worlds, and it is because of these experiences that I am extremely excited to share with you the next and newest adventure : my first ever solo show. 

 

After learning, working and growing in the New York art scene for the last 11 years, I began to notice shifts in my perception. My idea of success (and what it looks like) has changed, as has my idea of what I need versus what I want. So, when a dear friend suggested I present a solo show, the idea marinated for almost a year and a half, until I realized: one, I CAN and WANT to do this, and two, this IS the RIGHT time. Deciding to present this solo show feels like a continued evolution of myself as human and artist. 

 

Once I made up my mind I knew it would be no small task: trying something fresh, learning something new, the possibility of failure overwhelmed by the determination to succeed.  Understanding that ideas are best when vetted, I created a board of artistic advisors - people who inspire, challenge and support me - to guide me along the way. I am honored to have legends: Margie Gillis and Gus Solomons Jr. act as mentors on the project.

 

The show will be a evening of 4 solos presented as part of Gina Gibney's POP Series at the Agnes Varies theatre in downtown Manhattan next June 29th, 30th and July 1st.  I am honored to announce I will be creating work in collaboration with the brilliant artists : Pavel Zustiak , Gabrielle Lamb, Adam Barruch and a piece of my own. 

 

What I am seeking is your support of reaching an initial fundraising goal of: $10,000. This will be divided among rehearsal space and time, the artists time and collaboration, costumes, lighting, PR materials, theatre staff, and theatre rental. I am committed to honoring each artists’ time and dedication to this project by compensating them, for which I am asking your support.

 

I so deeply appreciate your support, and couldn’t do this without you.  Boundless thanks - for you I am infinitely grateful.

story:
Who Are We and What Are We Doing?

For 30 years Borderlands Theater has produced award-winning theatre reflecting the diverse voices of the US-Mexico border region.  We want to make our latest and most ambitious project, BARRIO STORIES, accessible to 1000 Tucson Unified School District (TUSD) students and anyone else without the means to experience this innovative, oral history, theatrical spectacle. 

About Barrio Stories

Staged outdoors on the grounds of the Tucson Convention Center, BARRIO STORIES brings to life the oral histories of Tucson’s original Mexican American neighborhood demolished with the building of the convention center in the 1960s. Precious memories come to life as audience members take a theatrical tour of what used to be the bustling epicenter of commerce and public celebrations for Tucson’s Mexican-American community.  Find out more about this important history at barriostories.org.

BARRIO STORIES is a large-scale (the size of two football fields), site-specific, fully immersive theatrical event involving: 40 principle actors, 75 extras, 10 youth mariachi and baile folklorico ensembles, 4 giant puppets, over 100 volunteers, and dozens of technicians, designers, and staff.

You Get What You Give:

We need $7,500 to underwrite the cost of tickets for 1000 TUSD high school and middle school students and anyone else who may not have the means to purchase a ticket to this history making (and history preserving) event.  Your donations will cover costs such as:
  • Hiring extra staff for eight weeks to produce this event
  • Offsetting substantial equipment and venue costs for a project of such large scale. 
  • Administrative overhead to produce this event  (office rent, utilities, insurance, overnight security, web designers, graphic design, printing, etc.)

As a theatre company, tickets sales are our life blood. They pay our staff salaries, and all the administrative costs that grants (often restricted to artist fees, and direct project expenses) do not.  BARRIO STORIES will be a completely donation based event. Though some patrons will donate at the door, we know there will be many who cannot pay.  AND WE WANT THEM TO COME!!  TUSD has generously donated all the buses needed to bring 1000 students. We are hoping the COMMUNITY can underwrite these tickets sales so necessary to the basic operation of the company.

Perks:Though the biggest perk is knowing you've made it possible for youth and community members to see their history outside of books and museums, in the very spaces where this history was made, please check out the lovely additional benefits we've put together for donors.  

What If We Don't Make Our Goal? Borderlands Theater is committed keeping BARRIO STORIES a donation based event no matter what.  If we don't reach our fundraising goal we will have to continue fundraising after the event in order to cover the costs outlined above and avoid ending the season in a deficit.

The Impact

For some, BARRIO STORIES will be their first live theatre experience.  For those with a direct connection to this Tucson history, BARRIO STORIES amounts to a public validation that HISTORY MATTERS.  The over 200 local actors, musicians, dancers, and performers involved will walk away with memories for a lifetime, knowing that they helped bring Tucson's Hispanic heritage to life. For the scores of audiences hearing these narratives for the first time, BARRIO STORIES will help them understand the city we call home.

Only at Borderlands Theater

Over the last 30 years Borderlands Theater has garnered an outstanding reputation locally and nationally for the award-winning theatre we make.  Previous oral history/docu-theatre projects like Arizona: No Roosters In The Desert (2011), and Más (2015) culminated in sold out runs and rave reviews.  Director Marc David Pinate has assembled the very best technicians and designers Tucson has to offer to go over every possible contingency to ensure we pull this off successfully.

Other Ways You Can Help

BARRIO STORIES has 120 volunteer shifts that need staffing.  We understand that not everyone can make a financial contribution. If you can't give from your pocket, give of your time by signing up to volunteer though our online volunteer sign up page or by calling 510-882-8607.
story_txt:
Who Are We and What Are We Doing?

For 30 years Borderlands Theater has produced award-winning theatre reflecting the diverse voices of the US-Mexico border region.  We want to make our latest and most ambitious project, BARRIO STORIES, accessible to 1000 Tucson Unified School District (TUSD) students and anyone else without the means to experience this innovative, oral history, theatrical spectacle.  
About Barrio Stories

Staged outdoors on the grounds of the Tucson Convention Center, BARRIO STORIES brings to life the oral histories of Tucson’s 
original Mexican American neighborhood demolished with the building of 
the convention center in the 1960s. Precious memories come to life as 
audience members take a theatrical tour of what used to be the bustling 
epicenter of commerce and public celebrations for Tucson’s 
Mexican-American community.  Find out more about this important history at barriostories.org.
BARRIO STORIES is a large-scale (the size of two football fields), site-specific, fully immersive theatrical event involving: 40 principle actors, 75 extras, 10 youth mariachi and baile folklorico ensembles, 4 giant puppets, over 100 volunteers, and dozens of technicians, designers, and staff.   You Get What You Give:
We need $7,500 to underwrite the cost of tickets for 1000 TUSD high school and middle school students and anyone else who may not have the means to purchase a ticket to this history making (and history preserving) event.  Your donations will cover costs such as: 
Hiring extra staff for eight weeks to produce this event
Offsetting substantial equipment and venue costs for a project of such large scale. 


Administrative overhead to produce this event  (office rent, utilities, insurance, overnight security, web designers, graphic design, printing, etc.) 


As a theatre company, tickets sales are our life blood. They pay our staff salaries, and all the administrative costs that grants (often restricted to artist fees, and direct project expenses) do not.  BARRIO STORIES will be a completely donation based event. Though some patrons will donate at the door, we know there will be many who cannot pay.  AND WE WANT THEM TO COME!!  TUSD has generously donated all the buses needed to bring 1000 students. For the scores of audiences hearing these narratives for the first time, BARRIO STORIES will help them understand the city we call home.

Over the last 30 years Borderlands Theater has garnered an outstanding reputation locally and nationally for the award-winning theatre we make.  Previous oral history/docu-theatre projects like Arizona: No Roosters In The Desert (2011), and Más (2015) culminated in sold out runs and rave reviews.  Director Marc David Pinate has assembled the very best technicians and designers Tucson has to offer to go over every possible contingency to ensure we pull this off successfully.
