story:
Indiegogo Summary

The Asheville Butoh Collective, are co-presenting two performances scheduled at The RAMP Gallery in Asheville’s River Arts District.  Additionally, in the fall of 2018, ABC and ACDT will present the 12th Asheville Butoh Festival. Seisaku and Yuri Nagaoko are coming from Tokyo!

With your support, we can meet our fundraising goals and together we can bring to life these exciting events.

What we need - what you get

Every single dollar brings us closer to our $3,000 goal with all contributions going straight into the production costs. These costs include: music commissions and set design fees, construction materials, lighting and seat rental, costumes, props, as well as administration and publicity costs. We are working hard to raise the money needed to produce a wonderful spring show and fall festival through local grants and in-kind donations. We hope you will join us now with your generous patronage. Every dollar helps - no donation is too small!

Unique Perks:

$1,000+ Producer Level 2 Be a guest of honor at the closing champagne party. Garner a beautiful Sandee Johnson print of your choice. Be our VIP for a behind the scenes peek of a rehearsal. Receive a special invitation to the opening night party and get an enthusiastic thank you on our websites

$500+ Producer Level 1 Garner a beautiful Sandee Johnson print of your choice. Be our VIP for a behind the scenes peek of a rehearsal. Receive a special invitation to the opening night party and get an enthusiastic thank you on our websites

$250+ Supporter Level 3 Be our VIP for a behind the scenes peek of a rehearsal. Receive a special invitation to the opening night party and get an enthusiastic thank you on our websites

$100+ Supporter Level 2 Receive a special invitation to the opening night party and get an enthusiastic thank you on our websites

$50+ Supporter Level 1 Get an enthusiastic thank you on our websites

ALL DONATIONS ARE FULLY TAX-DEDUCTIBLE

The Impact

Join us! It’s your patronage that makes this production possible. Dance is an ephemeral art form and we ask that you unite with us to express the intrinsic value that comes when people share the beauty of a live performance. With extreme dedication, passion, and commitment, we work without the expectation of a monetary gain and we embrace all the challenges that go along with staging live performances. We do this to bring a unique and powerful experience to our audience and to make our world a better place by connecting people through the creative experience. We hope that you will consider building this exciting new work with us today. Become a patron of the Asheville Butoh Collective and you become an artistic collaborator. You can make art possible!

Risks & Challenges

By undertaking such a large scale production in an alternative space, we have some special challenges. We will need to load in lights, sound systems, and set up chairs for the audience. All of these things are additional expenses but are also of the utmost importance to the professional level of the production. With the many new collaborations in music, set design, and digital media we will need extra support this year. There are always surprises along the way but with such a seasoned and experienced group of artists and administrators, we can easily overcome any obstacles. Let’s establish a strong arts community - right here and right now! As an individual donor, you can take a stand and make the arts a meaningful and important part of our world!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute right now, we can still use your help! Please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign on social media. It’s easy when you use the Indiegogo share tools. Thank so much!

story:
Short Summary

I am Monique Farnum, the founder of Divine Dance International New York.  I have worked for ACS, New York state child services for the last 10 years.  I grew up dancing and believe that it has helped me reach many of my goals. 

Monique has engaged Larendee Roos, a strategic business advisor to assist with her business launch. Since 2003 Larendee has provided consulting services, career development, coaching services and turn-around consulting services to over 100 organizations.

Prior to 2003, Larendee was the Executive Vice President for Extra Space Storage, a leading operator of 700 plus self-storage facilities nationwide. She was responsible for leading the teams that analyzed, developed, and implemented all of the systems for the tactical sales, marketing, operations, and accounting at Extra Space Storage. Larendee also served as a strategic advisor relative to development, acquisitions and mergers, and business development. She has a Liberal Arts Education in Psychology from the University of Phoenix, Evangel University, and the University of Utah.

Dance allows a full physical and spiritual growth experience. It builds the confidence of the artist in a palatable manner. As a dancer, I believe that there is a level of freedom that experienced when the artist, on any level, is allowed to ind and use their voice. I want to offer an environment that will be conducive to this growth.

My personal definition of success is to use the gifts that I have to reach the goals set. In my opinion, success is progressive. Success for Divine Dance will be to create healthy artists that embody the ability to use their own choreographically sound  voice, enhanced by training,  to communicate a message and/or story to an assembly of onlookers.

What We Need & What You Get

We are opening a studio in Brooklyn, New York and need money for the following:

  • Studio renovations
  • Website development
  • Instructor compensation
  • Marketing and advertising
  • Utilities
  • Insurance

You will be providing children and adults therapeutic recreation and a physical, emotional and spiritual experience through dance.

story:
Update 4/15:

We have now reached our official goal! Thank you to all of our donors for your generosity. We'd now like to introduce a stretch goal: If we reach a total of $2300 in contributions by April 23rd, we will make a behind-the-scenes video for all of our donors! You'll see exactly what goes on during rehearsals & meetings. So donate now and become part of the GAWI club!

P.S. From now on, if you'd prefer, you can send us a check instead of paying by credit card. Contact Justin by email if you're not sure how to get a check to us. Address is: JustinWCornell (at) gmail (dot) com

Let's Put On A Show!

We are bringing New Jersey talent to New York theatre, with a new collection of original short plays & interruptions. Getting Away With It runs at the Paradise Factory in New York from May 15th to June 4th. It's part of the Planet Connections Theatre Festivity.

We give you not one, but TWELVE plays, all smushed together. They're full of songs, dances, monologues, parodies, vaudeville, experimental pieces, a lot of yelling, and—I promise—not very much politics.  So, what exactly are we trying to get away with here? Find out for yourself:

Dates:

Thursday, May 15th @ 6:00pm
Sunday, May 25th @ 7:30pm
Tuesday, May 27th @ 6:00pm
Saturday, May 31st @ 1:00pm
Sunday, June 1st @ 3:30pm
Wednesday, June 4th @ 9:30pm
(All performances at the Paradise Factory Downstairs Theatre, 64 East 4th Street, NYC.)

You can buy tickets here: http://planetconnections.org/getting-away-with-it/

Who Is Who

From the Playwright: I'm Justin Cornell. This is the second show I've written to be produced in New York. The first was Nothing's Going To Happen, last spring at the Gene Frankel Theatre. Getting Away With It is even more of a passion project, in some ways. I started writing the earliest of these plays in 2005, a third of my life has gone into this show. But it took the brilliance & dedication of this cast & crew to bring it to the stage, led by Christina Balkovic.

From the Director:  Hi! My name is Christina Balkovic. This will be my third time working on a Justin Cornell play: I stage managed Nothing’s Going to Happen last summer and directed If You See Something in the MITF’s Short Play Lab this past fall. Getting Away With It is unlike any show I have been a part of and I am so excited to begin work on this production! I look forward to collaborating with the immensely talented team and challenging myself as a director. I also hope for audiences to think outside of the box and have fun in this kooky little world we’re creating!

Cast:
Peter McPherson
Molly Rodino
Craig Wolfe

Music Director: Craig Wolfe
Choreographer: Vanessa Rappa
Stage Manager: Allie Polan-Clarke

Set & Props Designer: Stephanie Gonzalez
Costume Designer: Anne Liberman
Lighting Designer: Caroline Harvey
Sound Designer: Nick Cornwell
Video Designer: Aaron Biston

Producers: Christina Balkovic & Justin Cornell
Associate Producer: Sara DiGuardia

Poster Designer: Chelsea D. Lennon

We've got the team, we've got a script, and we've got the talent & energy to take us to opening night. What we don't have yet is money. That's why we're reaching out to you for help.

How to Help

We could really use your help funding this production. We need to raise a total of $1800. This money will be used for:

  • Stipends for the cast & crew. This is where about two thirds of the funds will go.
  • Props, costumes, and audio/visual effects. What we can't find, we will have to build. What we can't build, we will have to buy.
  • Festival fees & incidental expenses. None of these are very large, but they add up.
  • Marketing the show. We want as many people as possible to see this show, because this team is doing some remarkable work. But to fill the seats, we need to get the word out, through online, print, & word-of-mouth marketing.

If we reach our goal, Indiegogo takes 4% for administrative costs. But if we don't reach the goal, they take 9%. That's why it's important for us to raise the entire $1800.

We are serious about our work, and we do not take your support lightly. We promise to be responsible stewards of your funds. Last year, we used the funds from a similar campaign for a successful Planet Connections Festivity run of Nothing's Going To Happen, and we hope that this show will be even better. 

If you can't donate, you can still help us out. "Like" our Facebook Page, and invite your friends to like it, too. Please share the link to this Indiegogo page with anyone who might be interested. And when the show opens, we hope that you'll come see it, of course. Tickets will be on sale soon.

If you can make a donation, it need not be just out of the goodness of your hearts. We've got lots of great perks for donors.

Perks!

Yes, we've got a bit of quid pro quo going on here. Make a donation through paypal or with a credit card, and you'll get something back, as a token of our appreciation. There are so many to choose from! Check out the right side of the page.

Please note: We don't have control of ticket sales for Planet Connections, so we are unable to offer tickets to performances as one of our perks.  So the budget-minded theatre lover may want to keep in mind that tickets will cost between $15 and $20. 

Also: You can donate more than the minimum for each perk. Maybe you'd like to give $150, but you don't want Peter to dedicate a show to you in-character. Although I can't imagine why anyone wouldn't want that.


Thank you all very much. It's people like you who help make independent theatre happen.

If you've got any questions, or you're confused about anything, please feel free to contact ChristinaBalkovic (at) gmail (dot) com, or JustinWCornell (at) gmail (dot) com.

story:
*Check out the above trailer for our 2011 SummerWorks Festival production

Support Praxis Theatre's National Tour of You Should Have Stayed Home:

Our award-winning production of You Should Have Stayed Home at the SummerWorks Festival in 2011 generated significant interest from a number of theatre companies and organizations and has been invited to be presented as far away as The Yukon Arts Centre. After months of planning, we have confirmed performances in these cities:

Whitehorse, Yukon: Yukon Arts Centre, Sept 12-15 2013 
 
Vancouver, British Columbia: Firehall Arts Centre, Sept 24 -Oct 5, 2013
 
Toronto, Ontario: Aki Theatre, Oct 16 -27, 2013
 
Montreal, Quebec: October/November 2013. Stay tuned for exact dates!
 
Ottawa, Ontario: November 2013. Stay tuned for exact dates!
 

1000 people were arrested at the 2010 G20 Summit in Toronto.

We aim to collect one thousand $10 donations in support of our theatrical adaptation of Tommy Taylor's Facebook note, "How I Got Arrested and Abused at G20 in Toronto."

If we reach our $10K goal, we will donate $1000 to the Canadian Civil Liberties Association (CCLA).  If we exceed our goal, we will continue to contribute 10% of total Indiegogo proceeds to the CCLA.

 

About the Production

You Should Have Stayed Home is a play about Tommy Taylor's experience over 48 hours at the 2010 G20 weekend in Toronto. While trying to return home from his first ever protest as a law-abiding citizen at the "Free Speech Zone" at Queen's Park, Taylor was swept up in a mass arrest, caged with 40 other people in a ten foot by twenty foot cage and denied drinking water until he passed out from dehydration.

The play is an adaptation of Tommy’s Facebook note,  How I Got Arrested and Abused at G20 in Toronto. The note went viral and has been translated into seven languages and appeared in twenty-one countries – a detailed, frightening and often funny account of the largest mass arrest in Canadian history. Tommy’s story has been covered by national and international media, including a Gemini-nominated CBC documentary named after the production.

After winning the largest cash award at the 2011 SummerWorks Festival, and becoming one of the festival’s highest grossing shows, Praxis Theatre, in association with The Original Norwegian, is about to embark on its largest project ever: a cross-Canada tour to Whitehorse, Vancouver, Toronto, Montreal, and Ottawa.

You Should Have Stayed Home is a one-man piece of storytelling in the tradition of Spalding Gray, with Taylor moving around a replica Eastern Avenue Detention Centre cage as he recounts 48 hours in his life as a citizen on the streets and eventually incarcerated. Part-way through the narrative, there is a scene that incorporates twenty-six participants that can be played by actors and non-actors when the action arrives at a cell in the Eastern Avenue Detention Centre.

Taking advantage of new possibilities available through social media, volunteer detainees were crowd-sourced on the internet for the 2011 SummerWorks production. As the show tours cities across Canada, the company will continue to use online tools to work with community members in each city as Tommy’s fellow detainees. Praxis is proud to be working with the support of the Canadian Civil Liberties Association, Council of Canadians and the Toronto office of Amnesty International, who will be putting calls out for volunteers in each of our cities.
 
Additional thanks to those donating by cheque:

Naomi Campbell - $100 "Street Marcher"
 
*Donations by cheque can be sent to 204 Indian Grove, Toronto ON  M6P 2H2

About Praxis Theatre

Established in 2003, Praxis Theatre has created eleven original socio-politically themed works. In 2006, the company established praxistheatre.com, a quintessential independent theatre site, winner of #1 Blog Post and #1 Arts and Culture Blog in The Canadian Blog Awards, which has become integrated with many of the company’s productions and creative processes.

Current Praxis projects include collaborating with The National Arts Centre on The SpiderWeb Show, an online theatre production; guest curatoring Harbourfront Centre’s HATCH performing arts residency series; and a new adaptation by Nicolas Billon of Brecht’s Senora Carrar’s Rifles (which Michael directed as a Shaw Festival Director's Project last year). In 2012, Praxis Theatre’s Artistic Producer Aislinn Rose and Artistic Director Michael Wheeler were named “People to Watch” by Torontoist, and “Toronto Theatre MVPs” by The Grid.

About the CCLA

The Canadian Civil Liberties Association is a national organization that was constituted to promote respect for and observance of fundamental human rights and civil liberties, and to defend, extend, and foster recognition of these rights and liberties.

The fight against abuse of state authority has not always won popularity contests for CCLA, but the Association has been a leader in protecting our fundamental freedoms, and has earned widespread respect for its principled stands on such issues as censorship, capital punishment, and police powers.

The Association is sustained by several thousand paid supporters drawn from all walks of life.
story_txt:
*Check out the above trailer for our 2011 SummerWorks Festival production
Support Praxis Theatre's National Tour of You Should Have Stayed Home:
Our award-winning production of You Should Have Stayed Home at the SummerWorks Festival in 2011 generated significant interest from a number of theatre companies and organizations and has been invited to be presented as far away as The Yukon Arts Centre. After months of planning, we have confirmed performances in these cities:

Whitehorse, Yukon: Yukon Arts Centre, Sept 12-15 2013 
 

Vancouver, British Columbia: Firehall Arts Centre, Sept 24 -Oct 5, 2013
 

Toronto, Ontario: Aki Theatre, Oct 16 -27, 2013
 

Montreal, Quebec: October/November 2013. Stay tuned for exact dates!
 

Ottawa, Ontario: November 2013. Stay tuned for exact dates!
 
1000 people were arrested at the 2010 G20 Summit in Toronto.
We aim to collect one thousand $10 donations in support of our theatrical adaptation of Tommy Taylor's Facebook note, "How I Got Arrested and Abused at G20 in Toronto."
If we reach our $10K goal, we will donate $1000 to the Canadian Civil Liberties Association (CCLA).  If we exceed our goal, we will continue to contribute 10% of total Indiegogo proceeds to the CCLA.
 
About the Production

You Should Have Stayed Home is a play about Tommy Taylor's experience over 48 hours at the 2010 G20 weekend in Toronto. While trying to return home from his first ever protest as a law-abiding citizen at the "Free Speech Zone" at Queen's Park, Taylor was swept up in a mass arrest, caged with 40 other people in a ten foot by twenty foot cage and denied drinking water until he passed out from dehydration.The play is an adaptation of Tommy’s Facebook note,  How I Got Arrested and Abused at G20 in Toronto. The note went viral and has been translated into seven languages and appeared in twenty-one countries – a detailed, frightening and often funny account of the largest mass arrest in Canadian history. Tommy’s story has been covered by national and international media, including a Gemini-nominated CBC documentary named after the production. After winning the largest cash award at the 2011 SummerWorks Festival, and becoming one of the festival’s highest grossing shows, Praxis Theatre, in association with The Original Norwegian, is about to embark on its largest project ever: a cross-Canada tour to Whitehorse, Vancouver, Toronto, Montreal, and Ottawa.You Should Have Stayed Home is a one-man piece of storytelling in the tradition of Spalding Gray, with Taylor moving around a replica Eastern Avenue Detention Centre cage as he recounts 48 hours in his life as a citizen on the streets and eventually incarcerated. Part-way through the narrative, there is a scene that incorporates twenty-six participants that can be played by actors and non-actors when the action arrives at a cell in the Eastern Avenue Detention Centre.Taking advantage of new possibilities available through social media, volunteer detainees were crowd-sourced on the internet for the 2011 SummerWorks production. As the show tours cities across Canada, the company will continue to use online tools to work with community members in each city as Tommy’s fellow detainees. Praxis is proud to be working with the support of the Canadian Civil Liberties Association, Council of Canadians and the Toronto office of Amnesty International, who will be putting calls out for volunteers in each of our cities.
 
Additional thanks to those donating by cheque:

Naomi Campbell - $100 "Street Marcher"
 
*Donations by cheque can be sent to 204 Indian Grove, Toronto ON  M6P 2H2

In 2006, the company established praxistheatre.com, a quintessential independent theatre site, winner of #1 Blog Post and #1 Arts and Culture Blog in The Canadian Blog Awards, which has become integrated with many of the company’s productions and creative processes. Current Praxis projects include collaborating with The National Arts Centre on The SpiderWeb Show, an online theatre production; guest curatoring Harbourfront Centre’s HATCH performing arts residency series; and a new adaptation by Nicolas Billon of Brecht’s Senora Carrar’s Rifles (which Michael directed as a Shaw Festival Director's Project last year). In 2012, Praxis Theatre’s Artistic Producer Aislinn Rose and Artistic Director Michael Wheeler were named “People to Watch” by Torontoist, and “Toronto Theatre MVPs” by The Grid.

The fight against abuse of state authority has not always won popularity contests for CCLA, but the Association has been a leader in protecting our fundamental freedoms, and has earned widespread respect for its principled stands on such issues as censorship, capital punishment, and police powers.

story:
We're Easy Leap Theatre Company, and we want your help to realize our first production, William Shakespeare's Love's Labors Lost, which will be taking place this October at the Access Theater in New York City. 

What We Need & What You Get

Whether or not we meet our goal, we're committed to making this show happen. But that said, there are a few things we could use a little help with. We're hoping to raise $3500, which will break down as following: 

$1675 to rent the Gallery at the Access Theater. 

$1115 for insurance. 

$710 for costumes, props, posters, and other minor expenses. 

Any money we raise above our goal will go to this latter category, allowing us to purchase even fancier props and costumes. Think giant, furry Russian hats. 

We have some fun incentives to offer in return for your help!

$10-- Two tickets to the performance of your choice! This is half-off the price at the door in October, so if you're going to come anyway, why not grab a pair in advance? 

$25-- Two tickets to the show, plus a signed poster from the cast and crew. 

$35-- Two tickets, a poster, and a mix CD of the music from the show. Music has been an essential aspect of the storytelling from the start of this idea, so we're very excited to share what we've come up with you! 

$50-- Two tickets, a poster, a mix CD, and the character of your choice will record a video serenade of their favorite love poem or song. 

$75-- Two tickets, a poster, a mix CD, a personalized serenade, and a copy of the script, specially annotated with all of the stupid jokes and comments that come up in rehearsal, as well as slightly more serious commentary about the text and our interpretation of it from the director and dramaturg. 

$100-- Four tickets, a poster, a mix CD, a personalized serenade, an annotated script, and baked goods of your choice, made by a cast member and hand-delivered to you at the performance. 

$200-- Four tickets, a poster, a mix CD, a personalized serenade, an annotated script, baked goods, and a DVD of the show, to be delivered after performances are completed! 

Why This Show? 

According to the Victorians and others in the centuries since Shakespeare’s death, Love’s Labors Lost… kind of sucks. But today, the odd ending feels surprisingly contemporary, and the world it shows looks a lot like our own: where the hazy space between the end of education and the beginning of adult responsibility seems like it might last forever, when you’re only beginning to realize that who you are and who you’re supposed to be might be very different, and all the other deep thoughts that arise when your smartest friends come over for the most eloquent house party in history.  

Performed by a company of women, this courtly tale of courtship becomes not only a battle between the sexes, but an investigation of the who and the how and the why of finding oneself somewhere in the modern sea of social expectation, and when you have a group of friends who are sure that rhyme is more important than reason. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't give now, we hope you'll join us at the show in October! And as with any social media-based campaign, the absolute best way to help out is to spread the word! 

Thank you so much for your support!

story:
Get Kayleigh to Verve

Hello everybody!

My name is Kayleigh Price, I am 22 years old and am a Contemporary Dancer. I recently graduated from the Northern School of Contemporary dance, NSCD! Woop Woop! The training consisted of vigorous hours that made me work at my dance practice which led me to gain a 1st in BPA Honors Contemporary Dance degree.

I auditioned for a company called Verve, which is a postgraduate company that allows recent graduates to further their studies as well as take a big step into the professional industry. With Verve, I am fortunate enough to be guaranteed a place as a dancer. Being a dancer verve allows me to work with 4 amazing choreographers in which I get to learn a lot of new skills and become a better performer taking a big step into the professional world. I get to tour around the world to beautiful European countries I have never imagined going to as a dancer, performing in such countries as Italy and Holland!!!!!!!!! :D :D :D :D :D :D :D

But in order for me to take this fantastic opportunity I need to raise £3,760 for the tuition fee. This is a large amount that unfortunately I can not afford. :( :( :( :( :( !!!!!!!!

This is where you come in!

I am asking for any donation towards the tuition fee as it will help me immensely. In doing so will get me to further my career and network with renown artists across the globe allowing me to expand my practice. 

What will you get from me in return for your donation? Prizes!

Different contributions will allow you to win prizes depending on the quantity of donation.

£5 - A wave from me. Queen style. or if you like, a big cheesy smile.

£10 - A thank you email of appreciation

£25 - A handwritten Thank you.

£50 - A short video clip of me saying your name and thank you via Instagram or Youtube.

£100 - A fun dance video mentioning your names and my appreciation performed by me via Youtube.

Can't afford to donate? You are still able to help!

By spreading the word of my experience and what you just witnessed. That way you'll be able to tell the people who are lucky enough to have that spare change to donate towards my tuition. So please tell your brother, your sister, your cousin, your mum's friend's uncle's dog named Tony! Tell the world!

Share this campaign or Copy this link and post it everywhere!

igg.me/at/kayleightoverve

So please be apart of the start of my career, the start of my journey and the start of a dream.

I really hope you like my video! oooh and don't judge me, i was nervous speaking in front of the camera :) 

Enjoy!

and don't forget to donate!

LOL (lots of love)

Kayleigh Price

story:
Following my Dream…THEATRE!

“Our stories come from our lives and from the playwright’s pen, the mind of the actor, the roles we create, the artistry of life itself and the quest for peace.” –Maya Angelou

My ardent passion for writing resonated within me from the first moment I picked up a pen at the age of four, and I’ve never stopped writing since.  I was always intrigued by stories, particularly colorful tales that illuminated and humanized the lives of African Americans.  Influenced by the literary works of Lorraine Hansberry, Maya Angelou, and Langston Hughes, my fascination with the world of theatre blossomed and a career in the arts seemed destined.  Now, as a playwright, actress, director, and producer, my theatre credits include Storyville Blues, Blood Water, and Indigo.  My theatre productions have premiered most recently Off-Off-Broadway, New York and to sold-out audiences in Virginia and Atlanta.  My work has also garnered national attention being selected for the Midtown International Theatre Festival in New York, the D.C. Black Theatre Festival and the Atlanta Black Theatre Festival. 

My goal is to continue following my dream and writing thought-provoking works that show the world the dynamics and essence of African American culture.  Also, as a producer, I want to continue to open doors for aspiring artists so that they will have an opportunity to showcase their talents and reach their artistic dreams as well.  Through Yellow Dream's National Theatre Tour, we will be able to reach and empower diverse audiences in theaters across the country, and hopefully, make it to Broadway!

So far, it has been a huge challenge juggling a full-time job and trying to pursue my dream career in theatre, so I finally made the long-awaited decision to follow my dream full-time!  I humbly appreciate all support for this campaign, which will help to bring me one step closer to my dream and with your help, Broadway won't seem so far away after all!

Yellow Dream Productions

A place where theatre is unconventional and art is a REVOLUTION...

Yellow Dream's mission is to create profound, artistically innovative theatre productions that illuminate the African American cultural experience and inspire a movement towards social change. 

A couple of years ago, I founded Yellow Dream Productions to provide a place where my dreams could flourish, and I would have the freedom to create original, ground-breaking theatre productions, open doors for aspiring artists, and bolster efforts to revolutionize the black theatre experience.  Although my works are deeply entrenched in the African American experience they also permeate with universal themes of freedom, love and identity that educate and speak to diverse audiences.  Fascinated with history, period pieces have become my staple, and my work has been termed as “culture-binding, strong and universal.” 

Blood Water

Blood Water is a bold artistic portrayal of the demoralizing system of slavery and the struggle for freedom. An ancient well on the McCreary Plantation, owned by a mulatto slave owner, holds a daunting mystery that reveals the brutalizing aftermath of slavery and redefines the ideal of freedom.  Blood Water not only captures the darkness of the slavery era, but it also resonates with rich, colorful and mysterious characters, which humanize the African American experience in the Deep South.  Ultimately, it  challenges the ideal of freedom and manhood and explores the historical context of slavery from two different angles: the oppressed slave and the tragic mulatto slave owner.  Thus, the depth of artistry, level of suspense and dynamic talent in this production makes Blood Water my most compelling theatrical piece yet.

National Theater Tour

There was once a historical myth that “all-Negro” shows were considered unprofitable because black people did not go to the theater.  According to Broadway League, less than 10% of Broadway theatre-goers are African Americans.  However, a big reason for the absence of black audiences is due to the limited number of African American shows on Broadway and in national theaters.  As an African American woman playwright and producer, I hope to shatter this myth and diversify the national theatre experience by bridging the gap between theatre and black audiences. 

 


What We Need & What You Get

Your Help Makes a Difference!

We are seeking help to make our national theatre tour a reality.  Your support will be greatly appreciated and will make a huge difference in our artistic mission!! Please check out the break-down of estimated costs that will help get us started on our theatre tour.  The bulk of the expenses for the theatre tour will include marketing, theater rental fees and travel/rooming costs.

  • Theater Rental Fees (includes space, light/sound tech, dressing room, etc.) $5000

  • Marketing (print/radio/online advertising, promotional material, box-office, playbills, flyers, photos, programs, DVDs, etc.)    $2,000
  • Rehearsal space $500
  • Set Design/Construction/Props  $1000
  • Costumes $500
  • Travel expenses/Rooming fees ($6000)

Total: $15,000



The Impact

Essentially, there is a lot of history, education and enlightenment that people of all ages and backgrounds can attain from the theatre and black audiences should not be isolated from that experience.  Thus, Yellow Dream Productions plans to jumpstart a three-state tour for 2015, which will provide an opportunity for diverse audiences from small, rural and large states to experience our quality, entertaining and cost-effective theatre productions.  Hopefully, this will attract more black theatre goers and encourage more African American artists, playwrights, directors and producers to help promote and sustain the integrity of black theatre.  Essentially, the national theater tour will provide us with the recognition, financial help and support we need to continue our artistic mission and change the social and economic climate of theatre.

 


Risks & Challenges

The challenge in producing any theatre production is establishing an effective marketing campaign that will attract target audiences and help to sell tickets.  As a producer, you always face the risk of losing money if the ticket sales are not good.  The primary goal for this campaign is to raise enough money to help jumpstart a national tour with a creative marketing campaign that will appeal to first-time and loyal theatre patrons so that we stand a great chance of packing the house! The reward is that we will be able to reach diverse people with this compelling work, and help to revolutionize the black theatre experience.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word to your friends and family through email, social media (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter), blogs.  Like our Facebook Page, invite your friends to like our page and support our Indiegogo campaign.  And support black theatre!!!! LET’S GO!!! BROADWAY HERE WE COME!!!

story:
Hello!

My name is Aviwe November and I am a dancer from South Africa. Born and raised in a small township called Zolani located 200km outside of Cape Town. I was raised by a single parent (she works 4 months a year) and I live at home with her and my 5 older siblings.
This year I had the privilege of attending a summer ballet intensive program at Alonzo King LINES BALLET in San Francisco, CA with a full scholarship and the sponsorship of Kristine Elliott (formerly of ABT) and generous individuals. Words can't describe how amazing this experience has been and how much I've grown in the past 5 weeks. 
I've been offered a 2-year scholarship to train at Alonzo King LINES BALLET but the scholarship only covers tuition. In order for me to make my dream a reality, I need to raise money to pay for my living expenses: rent, food, transportation... in addition to a plane ticket and visa.
Dancing has always been a big part of my life since a very young age. My 3 cousins and I were the only dancers in our community performing a South African style called Kwaito and we got invited to perform at many events.
In 2008, I decided to try ballet with Fiona Sargent who was teaching ballet in Zolani and  I immediately fell in love with it! After watching my first production of SWAN LAKE in 2009 on a professional stage, I knew that's what I wanted to do and where I had to be - on stage performing!
In 2011, I received a scholarship to study at the Cape Academy of Performing Arts for 3 years. That is where I had my more advanced ballet training. I was fortunate to be a participant in Kristine Elliott's Gugulethu Project and over the years Kristine has seen me grow, mature and develop. She choose to sponsor me to come to San Francisco to study further at Lines Ballet. With the support and assistance of Kristine Elliott and Nani Venegas, I have found a second home in the Bay Area.
Any help is very much appreciated as I pursue my dream to dance professionally.
Thank you for your time and consideration.
God Bless! Enkosi (Thank You is Xhosa)
story_txt:
Hello!
My name is Aviwe November and I am a dancer from South Africa. Born and raised in a small township called Zolani located 200km outside of Cape Town. I was raised by a single parent (she works 4 months a year) and I live at home with her and my 5 older siblings.This year I had the privilege of attending a summer ballet intensive program at Alonzo King LINES BALLET in San Francisco, CA with a full scholarship and the sponsorship of Kristine Elliott (formerly of ABT) and generous individuals. Words can't describe how amazing this experience has been and how much I've grown in the past 5 weeks. I've been offered a 2-year scholarship to train at Alonzo King LINES BALLET but the scholarship only covers tuition. In order for me to make my dream a reality, I need to raise money to pay for my living expenses: rent, food, transportation... in addition to a plane ticket and visa.
Dancing has always been a big part of my life since a very young age. My 3 cousins and I were the only dancers in our community performing a South African style called Kwaito and we got invited to perform at many events.

In 2008, I decided to try ballet with Fiona Sargent who was teaching ballet in Zolani and  I immediately fell in love with it! After watching my first production of SWAN LAKE in 2009 on a professional stage, I knew that's what I wanted to do and where I had to be - on stage performing!

In 2011, I received a scholarship to study at the Cape Academy of Performing Arts for 3 years. That is where I had my more advanced ballet training. I was fortunate to be a participant in Kristine Elliott's Gugulethu Project and over the years Kristine has seen me grow, mature and develop. She choose to sponsor me to come to San Francisco to study further at Lines Ballet. With the support and assistance of Kristine Elliott and Nani Venegas, I have found a second home in the Bay Area.
Any help is very much appreciated as I pursue my dream to dance professionally.Thank you for your time and consideration.God Bless! Enkosi (Thank You is Xhosa)

story:
Broken Dolls Synopsis

"I'm dead inside...just a whore. This is all I know how to do...so, I willingly came back..." Narcisa, a young Moldovan woman, is tricked and sold into the sex industry, systematically engineered to indoctrinate the victim; leaving her no choice, but to become the perpetrator. With accounts of broken lives, endless cycles of rape and shattered dreams of escape... this is the reality of the post-communist, free-market shadow-economy.

Our Goal

Our aim is to raise awareness of the devastating psychological trauma suffered by victims of sex-trafficking. Theater is a medium uniquely suited to convey a message in the most direct and intimate manner possible - and through Broken Dolls we aim to bring about a much needed shift in understanding of the enormity of the problem and the devastating consequences of not actively taking a position on it.

We have been offered the opportunity to bring Broken Dolls to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in Scotland this year, to be preceded by an Off-Broadway preview at 59E59 Theaters in New York City. After presenting the play in Edinburgh, we plan to bring its message back to the states, with the view of taking it on the road and making the context of the play relevant to the complex realities of the sex-trafficking industry in a country as demographically diverse and economically well-off as the US. 

Fiscally our aim is to donate 33% of the box-office proceeds to NGOs and Non-Profits who are actively engaged in the rescue and rehabilitation of victims.

Why we need you

To achieve our goal we need your help. Putting on a show of this scale is an expensive enterprise. We have been fortunate to find funds to cover some of our initial costs, like deposits for the theater space in Edinburgh and flights. We have assembled a wonderful cast and a minimal and very dedicated crew. We are off to a great start, but without your help our success is in question. 

We urge you to take a stand against sex-trafficking and help us spread the message. No donation is too small and your donations are tax deductible. 

If you are not in a position to donate but still want to contribute to this cause - please spread the word about our campaign.

Thank you. 

Meet The Team

Ilona Saic (actress)
NARCISA - A young Moldovan victim of sex-trafficking. 

Thrilled to be making her off-Broadway debut in Broken Dolls, Ilona recently graduated from The William Esper Studio in Manhattan, New York. Her credits include: The Vagina Monologues (Charring Cross Theatre - London), Broadening (Lost Theatre Company - London). Television: "Law & Order SVU" (NBC). Film: 79' Parts, Le Fear and Back It Up.
Ilona is a member of SAG-AFTRA.
www.ilonasaic.com

Vanina Kondova (actress)
TANYA LUPEI - A Moldovan recruiter for trafficking networks.
YOUNG TANYA - Tanya Lupei, young and already broken by her pimp, Murat.

Vanina is proud to be making her Treasure House Theater debut. A receiver of the Extraordinary Abilities in the Arts visa and an alum of The Atlantic Acting School and The Bulgarian National Theater and Film Academy, where she won Best Actress Award, Vanina has most recently been seen in The Last 15 Minutes of a Dinner Between Old Friends (Atlantic Stage 2), Belgrade Trilogy (4th Street Theatre) and Sleep No More (Punchdrunk), as well as the Bulgarian TV show The Tree of Life.
www.vaninakondova.com

Javed Khan (actor)

MURAT - A Turkish sex-trafficker and Pimp

Javed, British actor based in London, known for: Adha Cup (Channel 4), Pack Of Pain(Winner of Phoenix Comicon ‘Best action film award’), 7 Welcome To London, Musafir(Nominated Best UK Short at Raindance) and Rukhsati. RAZBITYE KUKLU (Broken Dolls) marks Javed’s Off-Broadway debut. Javed is a member of Spotlight and British Actors’ Equity Association. He is represented in the UK by VJ Management.
www.javedk.com

story:
A BRIEF LOOK AT THE AFTERGLOW – FOUNDLING’S THEATRE CO.

Video produced by The Foundling’s Theatre Company

“Dark Night of the Soul” music used by special permission from Philip Wesley

www.philipwesley.com 

Featuring actors Stephen Bisinger, D.J. Douglass, Kayla Conrad, Ryan Zimmer, and Nicholas Wicht

Our Project

A Brief Look at the After Glow is a play that has been in development for three and a half years. It began as a writing exercise for Resident Playwright Robert Francis and eventually became a one act production through Cold Basement Dramatics. For the past two years through table readings and numerous drafts, it has been developed into a full length two act production. It is the directorial debut of company member Stephen Bisinger and boasts an ensemble cast of nine actors. The play is slated to perform in late August and early September at the Heartland Studio in the Roger’s Park neighborhood of Chicago, Il.

The play itself is a raw and gritty tale of a young woman traveling through a post-Rapture landscape in an attempt to find her father. At the edge of the world sits his cabin. Inside the cabin are other survivors who know the truth about what happened to the young woman’s father. As she tries to learn their secrets, the end of existence seems to inch closer and closer towards them.

This will be the debut production of The Foundling’s Theatre Company’s second season.

Who We Are

The Foundling’s are a group of young theater artists looking to find their own home in the Chicago Theater Scene. Most of our work is about being separated from family. Since most of our company members are not originally from Chicago, it is a topic we all feel very deeply.

The company was founded in November of 2012 by then recent graduates D.J. Douglass, Robert Francis and Matthew Pratt.

Our current company consists of: David Servillo (Artistic Director), D.J. Douglass (Managing Director), Rachel Himmel, Harrison Hapin, Tara Grace Southard, Bryan Kravitz, Sara Linker, Alyssa Thordarson, John Mobley, Stephen Bisinger, Matthew Duncan, Kayla Conrad, and Robert Francis.

Why We Need Your Support

As a small, emerging theater company, we need help from patrons like you in order to give our productions the level of quality we know we can achieve. Your donations will go towards costumes, make-up, props, set, and lighting. Every penny will be used to create a world within the space that is as real and terrifying as the Apocalypse can be. You would be a tremendous help to us and to the show we are producing.

THE ARTISTIC TEAM

Stephen Miles Bisinger (Director)

Stephen graduated Columbia College Chicago with a Bachelors in Art & Design and a minor in theater. A few past credits include: Of Mice and Men (George), A View from the Bridge (Marco), All My Sons (Joe Keller), Twelfth Night (Malvolio), Antigone (Creon), and A Christmas Carol (Young Scrooge)

Stephen has been with the Foundling’s Theater Company for almost a year now. He has been a part of every Foundling Production. His past credits with the Foundlings have been Windblown Wail (Jack) and Twelfth Night (Orsino). This is Stephen's directorial debut and he is very excited to expand his knowledge of theater. He hopes to be able to achieve a new and fresh perspective on the way he views performance arts.

“Art is a lie that makes us realize truth.” – Picasso

Robert Francis (Writer)

Robert graduated from Columbia College with a B.A. in Theatre Arts and Creative Writing. His written works include A Brief Look at the After Glow , Bright Light America or The Pull-Out Play , Dial with a Smile: An Office Musical, Windblown Wail (2012), and Lay Thee Down, and he is currently developing an modern adaptation of Oscar Wilde’s The Importance of Being Earnest. He has also served as director for the debut production of The Foundling’s Theatre Company, Windblown Wail, and as Assistant Director for William Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night.

 “Show me a hero and I’ll write you a tragedy.” – F. Scott Fitzgerald

story:
Short Summary

The Bachelors is a play by Caroline V. McGraw that will be directed by SCAD Performing Arts Junior, Ian Mather. The story focuses on three frat brothers who are long past their college days but still live on frat row. They’ve drunkenly stumbled through thousands of parties and girlfriends as the years passed them by, but everything will change on this one pledge night. Expect catastrophe, new lows, fighting, Patron, drugs, and love in this darkly hilarious work. 

We chose this play because it is relevant to an audience of SCAD students, and the literary style is unlike works that have recently been produced at SCAD.  This is an important learning opportunity for all the students involved, and will generate conversations about gender, friendship, the objectification of women, morals, and the reason why we love.

Stage Manager: Joan Figarella

Producer: Anna Walker

Asst. Director: Sara Turner

Cast: James Edwards, Deron Horton, Timmy Gibson

Lighting Design: Chelsey Kruschwitz

Graphic Design: William Santiago

Scenic Design: Ryan Gillam


What We Need & What You Get

In order to produce this work we are asking for $5,000.00.  Everyone involved in the project is generously donating their time and energy to make the project possible.  While we will all be making many in-kind donations ourselves, we cannot afford to create a work of incredible caliber without monetary donations from those who support and believe in us.  

License                                                                       $400.00

Space Rental                                                              $2,750.00

Set/Lights/Costumes/Make-up                                   $600.00

Receptions/Promo Events                                         $600.00

Director/Producer/Performer/Designer Stipends       $650.00

A gift to us is a gift back to the Savannah and SCAD communities who will be able to benefit from this work.  We thank you so much for supporting us in our creative endeavors.  Because of generous supporters like you, we are able to DREAM BIG :)

All donors will receive an e-mailed picture of the cast and crew, thanking them for their donations.  

Donors who give over $100 will have their names printed in the program as funders.

Donors who give over $500 will have their names printed in the program as partners and will receive a signed cast photo.

Donors who give over $1,000 will have their names printed in the program as producers, will receive a special thanks during the pre-show speech each night, and will receive a signed cast photo. 


The Impact

Your contribution will make a HUGE DIFFERENCE.  No matter how little you feel like you are able to give, it will make a big impact on our campaign.  Every few dollars really does go a long way to helping us reach our goal.  

Even if you can only give $20 or $5, know that your contribution is still a vital part of our creative success.  

Last year we produced a play called Scooter Thomas Makes It To the Top of the World.  This play had a large impact on the SCAD community, resulting in news articles in the SCAD paper, as well as articles in the actors' hometowns.  We have done this before and are excited to do it again!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute money, you can still help out! Getting the word out there is a big part of this project.  Share a link to this campaign on your social media sites.  We are also interested in donations that may help us build our set or costume our actors.  For more information about how you can donate in that way, e-mail Anna at thebachelors2014@gmail.com

story: Check out some of the comments about this truth based story: "It is amazing how the playwright managed to keep it short, sweet, colorful and positive considering the hardship the main characters go through". "If this is not attractive enough, its unusual ending embodying.. jubilation and justice will do the trick". ... "spot on conversations"... "Musical accompaniment and the plot of the play come together like crackers and cheese, completing and empahsizing each other's flavor." "Energetic and talented actors... were magnificent" "leaves the viewers with a feeling that even though life is not a bed of roses, everything is possible". "Even though the play is set in history, it speaks to its contemporaries as well which makes "One Drop" even more touching and relevant". "most charming and gratifying" "inspires good thoughts in a world full of negativity." These are just some of the comments received about this work. It is a play based on the playwright's family history, my family history! You now have a never before opportunity to do several once in a lifetime things regarding this work. 1. Help it make the trip from New York to Louisiana where the truth based story took place over a hundred years ago! 2. Help it get the exposure it needs. 3. Help one of the few surviving community theatres in the country continue to survive by bringing this work to it. 4. Help honor the Theatre's Artistic Director who finds this work worthy and should be recognized for bringing such non commercial and conceivably sensitive and controversial subject matters to the fore. 5. Help make a difference in race relations in the south where it has historically needed it the most. 6. Help bridge racial divides by bringing a play to light which promotes understanding and acceptance regarding differences and sensabilities. 7. Help remind people that family composition is what you make it, not necessarily what you are born into. We are best a product of the love we share, not the hatred or lack of love of which we may be victims. 8. Help promote an international cast all of which all are little known but very much deserving of your support. Most importantly come out and allow yourself to be captivated by their passion and their skill. 9. Honor the commitment of this dedicated team, one that is truly like a family, all of which have been repeatedly underpaid. 9. Help support a talented Director and talented crew. 10. Help support talented and worthy musicians with unique and interesting skills and capabilities. 11. Come and enjoy the splendor of the exclusive little City in Louisiana that boasts one of the most scenic and serene coasts in the south, grass lined with hundred year old Oak Trees and fronted by old and newly restored antebellum homes. 12. Support the Gulf Coast which is still undergoing it's fight to revitalize since being hit with multiple natural and unnatural disasters. 13. While on your trip to see this show and support everything associated with it, see and support New Orleans, only 30 miles from the area where the play is set and will be brought home. 14. See the parts of New Orleans that were damaged the most by Hurricane Katrina, some of which are still struggling to rebuild and maybe never can. See the classic areas that were not damaged and continue to thrive and charm jazz and creole and cajun food lovers from around the world. 15. Gain the pride of knowing you helped give light to a show that is CREATIVE and POWERFUL and and EDUCATIONAL and ENTERTAINING and TRUTH BASED and INSPIRING and ORIGINAL!... qualities that are truly rare among a sea theatrical replicas that exist throughout the world. 16. Support this playwright who should be encouraged to do more and should be rewarded or minimally reimbursed for having spent so much for so long to do what she could do personally to create, develop and showcase remarkable stories and remarkable talent. 17. Support the acting industry in general by supporting this play. The success of one is the success of all! 18. Help keep the arts alive!
story_txt:
Check out some of the comments about this truth based story:



"It is amazing how the playwright managed to keep it short, sweet, colorful and positive considering the hardship the main characters go through".  



"If this is not attractive enough, its unusual ending embodying.. jubilation and justice will do the trick". ...



"spot on conversations"...



"Musical accompaniment and the plot of the play come together like crackers and cheese, completing and empahsizing each other's flavor."  



"Energetic and talented actors... were magnificent"



"leaves the viewers with a feeling that even though life is not a bed of roses, everything is possible".



"Even though the play is set in history, it speaks to its contemporaries as well which makes "One Drop" even more touching and relevant".



"most charming and gratifying"



"inspires good thoughts in a world full of negativity."



These are just some of the comments received about this work.  It is a play based on the playwright's family history, my family history!  You now have a never before opportunity to do several once in a lifetime things regarding this work. 

1.  Help it make the trip from New York to Louisiana where the truth based story took place over a hundred years ago!

2.  Help it get the exposure it needs.

3.  Help one of the few surviving community theatres in the country continue to survive by bringing this work to it.

4.  Help honor the Theatre's Artistic Director who finds this work worthy and should be recognized for bringing such non commercial and conceivably sensitive and controversial subject matters to the fore.

5.  Help make a difference in race relations in the south where it has historically needed it the most.

6.  Help bridge racial divides by bringing a play to light which promotes understanding and acceptance regarding differences and sensabilities.

7.  Help remind people that family composition is what you make it, not necessarily what you are born into.  We are best a product of the love we share, not the hatred or lack of love of which we may be victims.

8.  Help promote an international cast all of which all are little known but very much deserving of your support.  Most importantly come out and allow yourself to be captivated by their passion and their skill.

9.  Honor the commitment of this dedicated team, one that is truly like a family, all of which have been repeatedly underpaid.

9.  Help support a talented Director and talented crew.

10.  Help support talented and worthy musicians with unique and interesting skills and capabilities.

11.  Come and enjoy the splendor of the exclusive little City in Louisiana that boasts one of the most scenic and serene coasts in the south, grass lined with hundred year old Oak Trees and fronted by old and newly restored antebellum homes.  

12.  Support the Gulf Coast which is still undergoing it's fight to revitalize since being hit with multiple natural and unnatural disasters.

13.  While on your trip to see this show and support everything associated with it, see and support New Orleans, only 30 miles from the area where the play is set and will be brought home.  

14.  See the parts of New Orleans that were damaged the most by Hurricane Katrina, some of which are still struggling to rebuild and maybe never can.  See the classic areas that were not damaged and continue to thrive and charm jazz and creole and cajun food lovers from around the world.

15.  Gain the pride of knowing you helped give light to a show that is CREATIVE and POWERFUL and and EDUCATIONAL and ENTERTAINING and TRUTH BASED and INSPIRING and ORIGINAL!... qualities that are truly rare among a sea theatrical replicas that exist throughout the world.

16.  Support this playwright who should be encouraged to do more and should be rewarded or minimally reimbursed for having spent so much for so long to do what she could do personally to create, develop and showcase remarkable stories and remarkable talent.

17.  Support the acting industry in general by supporting this play.  The success of one is the success of all!

18.  Help keep the arts alive!

story:
Our Story

1242 pacific productions is raising money for a June 2012 production of the wall: a story of the land, written and directed by Noelle Ghoussaini. The performances will take place in various locations in Brooklyn. There will be live music, shadow puppetry and of course – an epic story! 

The Impact

Raising funds for this project will enable us to bring political, evocative theatre to non-traditional spaces, such as a community garden and old public baths at a low-cost and for free. We will also have a special performance just for high school playwriting and theatre students. 

What the wall is about:

the wall is an allegorical, science-fiction performance piece that explores a projected future society, depleted of the earth’s resources. In this society, the dominant community, living in the Vast Lands, live off of their oppressed neighbors by confining them within Honeycomb Reserves (walled-off communities) and using their energy to sustain their more luxurious lifestyle. The piece explores the perspectives of inhabitants on both side of the wall and the external and internal barriers each of them face in relation to the imposing structure that separates their communities.

The History

the wall was inspired by exploring the personal and political motivations of barriers and boundaries that have been created throughout history. Then, asking the question: what are the roots and effects of internal and external barriers?

An excerpt of the piece was performed in June of 2011 at La Mama Theatre and in December of 2011 at a site-specific location in Brooklyn, NY. Most recently, the the play received a staged reading at Judson Memorial Church's MagicTime series in February of 2012.

What We Need 

The money raised for this production will go towards funding:

 

  • â€¨the design team (costume, set and lighting designers)
  • the performers
  • rehearsal and performance space
  • materials for the set
  • marketing

What You Get

By funding this project, you can get:

 

  • a raffle ticket to win an original painting by Valerie Ghoussaini, valued at $2,000 http://valerieghoussaini.com/works/252274/pink-flamingos
  • a personalized haiku written for you, by the playwright
  • an "wall" tote bag.
  • 2 seats to opening night.
  • A DVD of the production
  • producer credit

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not support us financially, you can help us with the campaign by spreading the words to your friends and networks by sharing the link on Twitter, Facebook, or emailing!

story:
Welcome

Cadence: Home is offering an opportunity for everyone who believes in the transformative power of theatre to co-produce an eight-performance, Off-Broadway run of a cutting edge, theatrical performance piece that bridges the gaps in experience, understanding, and mutual regard that divide those of us who have served in the military from those of us who haven’t – gaps that generate profound challenges and difficulties for the veterans coming home from Iraq and Afghanistan today, and for the friends and family who love them.

What is Cadence: Home?

Cadence: Home offers you an intimate, honest, and compassionate entry into the world of four Americans recently returned to New York from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. You will journey with each of them as they reconnect with their friends, their lovers, and their losses. You will deepen your insight into their cares, their courage, and the ghosts that haunt them. You will come to understand these characters in their own terms—their flaws, their fears, their strengths, their triumphs.

Why support Cadence: Home?

We all know it takes a village to raise a child – an attentive, understanding, supportive village.

It also takes a village to welcome home the veterans who have served in the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan – an insightful, compassionate, welcoming village – a village of military and non-military civilians alike.

Don’t you want to be part of that village?

Of course you do.

The artists and creators of Cadence: Home posed a question to scores of veterans recently returned from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

“If you could have the conversation with the American people that you would like to have, what would like to speak about, and what would you hope might be the result of that conversation.”

Don’t you want to be part of that conversation – and to learn what they said to us?

Of course you do.

Don’t you want to deepen your insight into the emotional strength and resiliency it takes for our veterans to come home – and for their friends and family to receive them?

Of course you do.

Don’t you want to know what it might really mean to say, “thank you for your service”?

Of course you do.

Cadence: Home is all these things. It is a welcome home, a true tale of emotional strength and resilience, a thank you, and an invitation to the village.

Why are we launching this Cadence: Home Indiegogo campaign?

Cadence: Home is part of a larger collaborative strategy spearheaded by Intersections International that we anticipate will ripple across the Nation. We envision a time when non-military civilians understand how to do for our veterans what they have done for us: how to help them bear the burdens of war they bring home in their minds and bodies as they have helped us bear the burdens of security and freedom on the field of battle, and how to engage with them in a cadence home that is open-hearted, harmonious, and understanding – not tentative, dissonant, and confused.

FROM SEPTEMBER 18 TO OCTOBER 17 ONLY, we are launching an Indiegogo campaign to raise a minimum of $15,000 (US). **VERY IMPORTANT** We have only 30 days to reach out goal. If we don’t raise at least $15,000 (US) by October 17th, 2012, we don’t receive ANYTHING. Going over our goal is great. We can earn more, not less. So we really need your help in co-producing our performance run of Cadence: Home!

Go to the gallery above to see some pictures of our process!

What are veterans saying about TE’A and Cadence: Home?

In my Insight conversation with TE'A, I was able to give a voice to my experience as a vet, to speak of things I had never spoken of before. And to see what TE'A is doing theatrically with all the stories they heard was powerful and validating for me. It was a privilege and a pleasure to work with TE’A, an opportunity to help us all move toward a more aware society.

Rob Obayda
Missile Technician, United States Air Force, 2002-2006

The experience of every veteran while deployed is unique, so it is hard to capture even one of these voices, let alone many. But TE’A has done it. TE'A has created a theatrical performance that speaks to, and for, veterans and their families.

Ann Little
Army. Corp of Engineers. Alpha Company, 94th Engineer Combat Battalion (Heavy).  Baghdad, Iraq in 2003  Mosul, Iraq in 2005.

How can you support Cadence: Home?

1.     Contribute to our Indiegogo campaign at whatever level feels
        comfortable (from $10 on up)! 100% of your contribution will go to
        producing Cadence: Home, and your contribution is
        tax-deductible!

2.     Please SHARE this Indiegogo link with your family, friends,
        co-workers, clients, email lists … SPREAD THE WORD BY ANY AND
        ALL MEANS POSSIBLE: email about it, talk about it, text about it,
        tweet about it, post about it, blog about it …

3.     Gather some friends, buy some tickets, and come to the show!
        Cadence: Home, performing in the heart of the theatre district in
        NYC at the Metro Baptist Church, 410 West 40th Street right off
        9th Avenue. Performances are Wednesday through Saturday,
        November 7-10th at 7pm, and November 14th -17th at 7pm.
        We are grateful to be collaborating with the deeply caring, smart
        people at MBC, especially Pastor Alan Sherouse.

4.     Email us with your ideas, suggestions, input, encouragement,
        inspiration – we’d LOVE to hear from you!

What do you get if you support Cadence: Home?

First off, our heartfelt thank you! Also take a look at your options from our fun, creative perks, like a customized ringtone.

Above all, you will be a part of something incredibly important, meaningful and vital~ this movement is about all of us…it is about the way we see and treat each other and ourselves – about the kind of country we want to be.

* Music used for the video is by Kevin MacLeod entitled Confused State (incompetech.com)

story:
It’s a PLAY!!!

Your participation is cordially requested for:

A Play Shower 

honoring

All in the Shuffle

by Natalie Wilson

A play written in only 9 months, from its conception on January 15th to its due date on October 8th, 2010, culminating Natalie’s Birth of a Play(wright) project.

 

Like any expecting mother, Natalie needs some help preparing for the “birth” of her play! But instead of baby food blenders, Baby Einstein DVDs, and onesies in every possible size, she needs help producing a public, staged reading to introduce her play to the world. Her registry of desired gift levels is listed below (under “how the funds will be used”). However you can help out is most appreciated!


About the play

All in the Shuffle is an intensely moving, naturalistic drama about a deeply wounded family struggling to heal.  Set in 1978, Frank, suffering from Parkinsons, grieving the loss of his wife, and estranged from his daughter Vivian, struggles to find a reason to go on.  His granddaughter Angie, torn between her own dreams and caring for her ailing grandfather, tries to mend the deep rift between Frank and Vivian, as Vivian searches for a new lease on life.  Be sure to click on the video link above to meet the actors and hear excerpts from the script.


About the project

An opera singer in a previous life, Natalie stepped off the stage and behind the pen a year a half ago when she discovered a new talent and a new love in playwriting. Back in January, having so far written the book for a children's cabaret show and a dozen or so short plays, she decided it was time to attempt her first full-length play.  Inspired by the movie Julie and Julia, she decided to give herself 9 months to complete it and to blog about the process.  Why 9 months? When creating a work of art, that art feels like your "baby" (and is as close as Natalie ever plans to get to giving birth to something).  She "conceived" on January 15th, making her "due date" October 8th.


Why contribute?


Because the world needs more great theater!  Theater to bring us together, to touch and move us, to make us look at ourselves and the human condition in a new way.  Just as it takes a village to raise a child, it takes a community to put on a play.   Lacking a patron, a government grant or a personal fortune, Natalie can’t bring this little play into the world all on her own.  Whether this play sits on a shelf, only to be heard or read by a handful of people, or gets brought to life so it can be shared and enjoyed by many, is up to you.  Give whatever you can, whatever feels good.  Come be a nanny, a big brother, and aunt, or a stork to this little play, and help bring a creation into the world that didn’t exist before.

story:
Our Story

 

Inspired by Boston’s revolutionary past, New Exhibition Room develops original and cheeky theatrical events with a local interdisciplinary ensemble. Our work celebrates play, incites dialog, and champions affordability.

 

Little did we know when we started the company in 2008 with dreams in our hearts and pennies in our pockets, that the end was so near.

 

We have grown from a two woman founding artistic director team (Dawn M. Simmons & A. Nora Long) to a bustling company of five (now six) in four years (Alejandro Simoes, Hannah Husband, Robin Allen LaPlante and our latest edition Lyndsay Allyn Cox) and a host of favorite collaborators. We’ve tackled the nuances of censorship (Shh!), revealed the comedy of recession (Candyland) and battled the real and metaphorical dragons of gender politics (The Paper Bag Princess).

New Exhibition Room is part of the Emerging Theatre Company Program at the Boston Center for the Arts.

 

The Impact

 

We are faced with our biggest challenge to date: the Zombie Apocalypse. In the spirit of the Grindhouse Double features of the golden age of the drive-in movie, we will create two comically horrifying works about the impending Zombie Apocalypse. You’ve read right, friend, a Zombie Double Feature: a one-two punch of Zombie movie-ish magic in a live theatre event in August of 2012 at the Boston Playwrights’ Theatre. Double the mayhem, double the fun, and at least three times the cost.

 

We don’t want to suggest this is a life and death situation, friend, but when zombies are involved, the stakes are pretty high. Without your help, we won’t have the necessary weapons, medical supplies, or food (let alone costumes, props, and special fx magic) to survive the apocalypse. Zombies don’t take well to mime, and frankly, neither do we.

 

But you have the opportunity to save humanity (as represented by our company of artists).  

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

Sets, costumes, gore and therapy cost dollars. Your contributions will go to the containment of the zombies, the research into what caused this plague and the care and feeding of survivors (if there are any), but that’s not all your contribution, nay investment, nay charity will help us procure:

 

Viscera

Blood

Make-up

Tattered Clothing

Weapons

Shelter

Rations

Smart-alecky dialogue

A live band

Zombie Dance lessons

Laundry

Misguided Law Enforcement and/or Military Personnel

And of course… Brains

 

How much will the Zombie Apocalypse cost? We estimate we can bring the reckoning for about $5,200. We began preparing people for the Zombie Apocalypse in July 2011 with Zombie Survival Training . At this fundraiser NXR’s expert Zombologists debunked popular zombie myths, demonstrated how to domesticate a zombie (they love Rock Band), and allowed one audience member volunteer to transition from living to living dead! For your protection NXR will hold other Zombie Education events between now and August. To help build on the momentum of last summer and prepare for Armageddon we look to the good people of the world (that’s you) to help us raise at least $2500 on Indie Go Go. We’ve heard of your generosity and though you can’t prevent the Zombie Apocalypse you can help us survive it!

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Hoarding is never pretty, friends, so don’t be shy about spreading the word. You are our best form of advertising now and during the inevitable media blackout. What’s better than giving us some dollars? Getting your friends to give us more!
